Control Risks KIDNAP RESPONSE AND TRAINING PROPOSAL WORLDPAY 5th Floor The Walbrook Building 25 Walbrook London EC4N 8AF CONFIDENTIAL 09 MAY 2017 Control Risks Group Limited | Cottons Centre | Cottons Lane | London | SE1 2QG T: + 44 (0)207 970 2363 www.controlrisks.com TASK No. SL00068541 CONFIDENTIAL I TABLE OF CONTENTS INTRODUCTION 1 WORKSHOP PREPARATION 2 WORKSHOP DELIVERY 3 WORKSHOP CONTENT 4 TIMELINES AND DELIVERABLES 5 PROFILES 6 GENERAL TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF BUSINESS 8 SIGNATURE PAGE 15 This proposal, and any report generated hereunder, is for the benefit of the client only (including its directors, officers and employees) and may not be disclosed to any third parties without the prior written consent of Control Risks. Copyright © Control Risks Group Limited (“CRGL”). All rights reserved. This document cannot be reproduced without the express written permission of CRGL. Any reproduction without authorisation shall be considered an infringement of CRGL’s copyright. Prepared by Control Risks For WORLDPAY INTRODUCTION This proposal follows discussions between Karl Gibbs, Corporate Security Manager (global) at Worldpay (“the Client”), and Sean Cunningham and Alex Martin of Control Risks. The Client has requested the delivery of a one-day Kidnap Incident Management Workshop in order to improve their preparedness to respond to a kidnapping incident, The objective of the workshop will be to train key stakeholders in relation to their roles and responsibilities during the initial stages, on-going incident management and resolution of a kidnap event. The workshop will also provide an opportunity to exercise core skills in the context of a realistic scenario. This proposal should be read in conjunction with Control Risks’ General Terms and Conditions of Business as incorporated herein. To instruct us, please complete the acceptance form of this proposal. Please read our General terms and conditions of business. -1 - Prepared by Control Risks For WORLDPAY WORKSHOP PREPARATION Overview Control Risks has been asked to deliver a one day Kidnap Incident Management Workshop for 8-12 staff at the client’s offices in London or at another mutually agreed location. The workshop will enable delegates to understand the key issues to be managed in the initial response to a kidnap-for-ransom incident, i.e. until such time as the input of a specialist consultant(s) can be provided. Facilitated by expert practitioners, the workshop will provide: ■ An understanding of the policy, organisational, and detailed procedural issues to be considered in the event of an incident; ■ An understanding of the long-term operational aspects and the interface with key participants throughout the incident. ■ An overview of current global kidnap-for-ransom threats and any specific regional threats/trends requested by the Client). Operational experience Control Risks’ Response team has an unparalleled expertise in resolving cases of kidnap, piracy, extortion, threat, and detention. Since its foundation in 1975, Control Risks has worked on 3,072 cases of kidnap, extortion, and other crises in 136 countires. Breakdown by type Kidnap and piracy 1,431 Product contamination/extortion 336 Threat and threat extortions 1,015 Short-term hostage extortion 27 Bomb extortion 35 Other 228 This experience equates to a total of 49,728 case days for all incidents, or more than 136 years of accumulated experience. -2- Prepared by Control Risks For WORLDPAY WORKSHOP DELIVERY Approach The workshop objectives, content and the exercise scenario will be developed with the client in advance of the delivery date this development can take place by phone or during a face-to-face meeting as preferred. The approach will reflect Worldpay’s global business with a particular focus on Mexico, Brazil and India. The workshop will make full use of Control Risks’ unparalleled experience in supporting clients responding to kidnap incidents. Training will be interactive, combining formal presentations with audio-visual materials illustrated by case studies and underpinned by Control Risks' exceptional insight and understanding of managing such crises. A kidnap scenario will run throughout the workshop, enabling delegates to confirm the learning objectives and gain experience through role-play in semi-real time. The workshop will be designed to reflect the client’s existing crisis management organisation and core content will include: « Responding to and containing the initial report of the abduction incident ■ Setting up an effectively-manned crisis management organisation ■ Preparing for and controlling the initial contact from the kidnappers ■ Dealing with the other participants, both planned and un-planned ■ Developing and implementing a negotiation and financial strategy, including the mechanics of communicating with the kidnappers themselves ■ Managing the concluding stages of a kidnap incident. The workshop will allow attendees to practise their roles in an incident management context and provide an opportunity to validate crisis management procedures. -3- Prepared by Control Risks For WORLDPAY WORKSHOP CONTENT In terms of best practice and key methodology, the workshop will cover the following topics. The semi¬ live table-top exercise will run in parallel: Introduction Strategy, policy, and organisation
■ Control Risks and crisis response ■ Principles of crisis management
■ Definitions and a history of kidnap ■ Crisis management strategy
■ Types of kidnap and factors to consider ■ Objectives
■ The role of Control Risks in an incident ■ Policy
■ Global kidnapping threats and trends ■ Legal considerations
Initial notification and response ■ Government perspectives
■ Sequence of events Key participants
■ Methods of communication ■ Hostage(s)
■ Initial notification procedures ■ Families
■ Response to the initial notification ■ Media
■ Establishing a crisis management organisation ■ Authorities ■ Third-party intermediaries
■ Urgent issues and decisions Financial factors
Preparation for immediate contact ■ Financial criteria
■ Role, selection, and training of the communicator ■ Target settlement figures
■ Preparation for communication ■ Initial offers
■ Scripting, briefing, and rehearsing the communicator ■ Negotiating strategies ■ Resistance and response to pressures
■ Handling the initial call Final stages
■ Contact with the hostage(s) ■ Collection of payment and payment sequence
■ ‘After action’ procedures ■ Release, recovery, and debriefing
■ Proof of life ■ Post-incident rehabilitation
-4- Prepared by Control Risks For WORLDPAY TIMELINES AND DELIVERABLES This plan will be drafted by a senior consultant by the end of April 2017. The workshop will be at a time and location suited to the client. The consultant’s profile is attached. Fees T otal ■ Workshop £9,860 To instruct us, please complete the ‘acceptance’ form of this proposal. Please read our general terms and conditions of business. Notes on fees Please see Clause 4 of Control Risks’ General Terms and Conditions of Business. Our fees exclude out-of-pocket expenses and, where applicable, database expenses. In addition, an administrative expense of 5% of the fees will be added to cover non-recoverable costs that cannot be separately identified. Travel time will be charged at a half-day rate of £1,000 per day. All fees and expenses are quoted net of any applicable taxes, which will be added when required by law. Invoices are payable within thirty (30) days of the date of the invoice. This proposal is valid for thirty (30) days from the date of this document, provided that Control Risks has not previously withdrawn it. Please read Control Risks’ General Terms and Conditions of Business carefully, as they include limitations on our liability. In the event of any inconsistency between the terms of this proposal and the General Terms and Conditions of Business, the latter shall prevail. -5- Prepared by Control Risks For WORLDPAY PROFILES Sean Cunningham Senior Consultant Sean joined Control Risks in 2017. He delivers consulting support to Control Risks’ clients across Europe and Africa. Prior to working at Control Risks Sean served with the Metropolitan Police in London for 30 years, was employed as Director of Security for a FTSE 250 company and more recently he was the operational lead for kidnapping for a specialist security company in the UK. Sean's most significant experience and highlights include: • Front line leadership and management of tiger kidnap investigations as part of the Metropolitan Police's specialist robbery unit, The Flying Squad. • Senior Investigating Officer and Controller for four years in domestic and criminal kidnap cases. • Head of the Hostage and Crisis Negotiation Unit at New Scotland Yard. • Member of the UK Government's Crisis Group (COBR) advising on international and terrorist kidnapping in cases involving UK subjects as individuals or part of multi¬ national groups. • Being awarded the OBE by Her Majesty the Queen in 2011 for services to International Hostage Negotiation. • Sean holds a BA (Hons) in Policing and Police Studies from Portsmouth University and an MSc in Critical and Major Incident Psychology from the University of Liverpool. Following this latter period of study he became joint author of a published paper titled “The impact of accountability on advice quality in police negotiations” Psychology Public Policy and Law 19(2):137 ■ May 2013 He has also been a mentor for the FBI’s Hostage Negotiator Course and the Australian Counter-Terrorism Negotiation Course. -6 - Prepared by Control Risks For WORLDPAY Kevin Curreri Senior Consultant Kevin joined Control Risks after serving with the United Nations in Somalia for five years as a security advisor and justice sector development expert. He served as a member of the United Nations Hostage Incident Management (HIM) Course training team and was actively involved in the coordination of the UN HIM Programme, which manages the response to the kidnapping of UN staff members and their dependents throughout the world. Kevin has also served as a police crisis/hostage negotiator both in the United States and Australia. As the State Negotiations Training Officer, he was responsible for training crisis/hostage negotiators in the Queensland Police Service (Australia). He has also delivered crisis/hostage negotiation training internationally to agencies such as: • Los Angeles Police Department, • New York Police Department, • Baltimore Police Department, • Royal Canadian Mounted Police, • New Zealand Police, • Australian Federal Police (and all other Australian police jurisdictions), • London Metropolitan Police, • Norwegian Police Service, • French National Police, and • The United Nations. Kevin has investigated several hundred domestic and international kidnappings, extortions and other crisis incidents. He holds a Master of Arts Degree in Crisis Negotiations from Charles Stuart University (Australia) and is a graduate of the FBI Hostage Negotiation Course, the New Scotland Yard Advanced Hostage Negotiation Course, the Australian Counter-Terrorism Negotiation Course amongst others. He also has extensive experience in policing investigations and has served as a tactical officer (SWAT) in the United States. - 7- Prepared by Control Risks For WORLDPAY GENERAL TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF BUSINESS 1. Interpretation and Application of Terms 1.1. The provision by Control Risks of its services (the “Services”) to a client (the "Client”) is subject to these terms and conditions (the "Terms and Conditions”). 1.2. “Control Risks” shall refer to the contracting party in the Control Risks Group. "Control Risks Group" shall be defined as Control Risks Group Holdings Limited, its subsidiaries, branches and affiliates. “Client Group” shall refer to the Client, its holding company or companies, and their respective subsidiaries, branches and affiliates. 1.3. These Terms and Conditions, together with the terms of any proposal (the "Proposal” and, together, the "Agreement”), set out the entire agreement and understanding of the parties and supersede all prior oral and written agreements, negotiations, understandings or arrangements between the parties relating to the subject matter of the Proposal and, unless otherwise agreed, any extension thereof. In the event of any inconsistency between the terms of the Proposal and these Terms and Conditions, these Terms and Conditions shall prevail. 1.4. The Agreement shall be deemed to be effective as of the date of signature by the Client hereof. 1.5. Unless instructed otherwise, Control Risks shall assume that all of the Client's employees, directors and officers who give instructions to Control Risks are authorised to do so and that Control Risks may act on oral instructions. 2. Services 2.1. The Services to be provided in relation to any matter will be described in the terms of the Proposal and may be varied only by written agreement between the parties during the course of the matter. The Services shall be provided at times, on dates and at the place(s) as agreed between Control Risks and the Client from time to time. 2.2. Control Risks shall provide the Services using reasonable care and skill. 2.3. Control Risks reserves the right to make changes to the Services which are necessary to comply with statutory requirements or which do not materially affect the nature or quality of the Services. 2.4. The Client acknowledges that Control Risks may from time to time engage the services of subcontractors to assist in carrying out particular aspects of the Services. Control Risks undertakes that any subcontractor shall be bound by the same confidentiality obligations as Control Risks and that Control Risks shall remain liable for the acts or omissions of its subcontractors. 2.5. Reports (where they form part of the Services) will be delivered in PDF format by email, unless otherwise specified by the Client, in which case the Client shall cover any additional costs that may be incurred. The Client accepts that the use of email may be less secure than delivery of a hard copy of reports and shall notify Control Risks in writing if any particular privacy markings or security arrangements are required with regard to correspondence relating to the provision of the Services. Each party shall be responsible for protecting its own IT systems and neither party shall be responsible to the other for any loss, damage or omission in any way arising from the use of electronic data (including email) as a form of communication. 2.6. Unless otherwise expressly agreed in writing, the Services are provided solely for the benefit of the Client. Control Risks accepts no responsibility to any other party. 2.7. Reports and their subject matter are for the benefit of the Client only (including its directors, officers and employees) and may not be disclosed to any third parties without the prior written consent of Control Risks (such consent not to be unreasonably withheld). Disclosure to third parties shall at all times be subject to the reasonable instructions of Control Risks and shall require such third parties to sign a non-disclosure agreement with Control Risks. -8 - Prepared by Control Risks For WORLDPAY 2.8. The Client warrants not to use any report or other document prepared by Control Risks as part of the Services other than for legitimate business purposes and agrees to compensate Control Risks for the amount of any loss or damage resulting from any third party claims that may arise from the Client's misuse of, or disclosure of, such documents (including reasonable legal and preparation costs). 2.9. The Client acknowledges that Control Risks’ work and findings shall not in any way constitute recommendations or advice regarding the Client’s ultimate commercial decision, which shall, in all respects, remain the Client’s own. 2.10. The Services provided by Control Risks may be available in languages other than English. Where available, these will be provided at no extra cost. An additional charge will be levied for written reports required in more than one language. It is the responsibility of the Client to specify language requirements at the time of requesting the Services. Control Risks is not responsible for any inaccuracies in translation or in interpretation resulting from discrepancies between the English version and any translation thereof, and the English version shall be the definitive one. 3. Obligations of the Client 3.1. Throughout the duration of the Agreement and in order for Control Risks to carry out the Services in a prompt, effective and professional manner, the Client shall provide full assistance to Control Risks including, without limitation, the provision of information, documentation and other materials relevant to the provision of the Services in a timely manner. The Client shall keep Control Risks fully apprised of any developments and/or information which may come to its attention and which may be of relevance to the provision of the Services. 3.2. The Client acknowledges that Control Risks shall be entitled to rely on any information, documentation or other materials that may be provided by the Client to Control Risks, and that relate to the Client’s own business, as being accurate and complete in all material respects. Control Risks shall not be liable for any loss, damage, costs, expenses or other claims for compensation arising from the inaccuracy or incompleteness of any such materials. 3.3. Neither party shall be liable for any accidental loss or damage howsoever caused to any documents or materials provided to it by the other party. 3.4. Where relevant, the Client shall afford Control Risks such access to the Client’s premises at which Control Risks is to provide the Services (the "Premises”) as Control Risks may reasonably require. Furthermore, the Client shall: (a) advise Control Risks of the rules and regulations which are then in force for the conduct of personnel at the Premises, and Control Risks shall ensure that its personnel comply with any such rules and regulations; (b) make available such working space and facilities at the Premises as Control Risks may reasonably require; (c) make available appropriate personnel to liaise with Control Risks; and (d) secure and otherwise keep safe all and any property of Control Risks which Control Risks may reasonably require at the Premises for the provision of the Services. 4. Fees 4.1. The fees in respect of the Services are set forth in the Proposal. The Client shall pay to Control Risks the fees, together with any expenses as referenced in clause 4.2 below, without any deduction (whether by way of set-off, counterclaim, discount or otherwise) within thirty (30) days of the date of receipt of Control Risks’ invoice.. Each invoice shall quote this Agreement, the Client’s purchase order number, and contain such other information as the Client may reasonably require from time to time Any applicable value added tax, sales tax, withholding tax or other local equivalent shall be added to the fees and expenses and invoiced accordingly. If the Client is required to deduct or withhold from the amount due to Control Risks any sum on -9- Prepared by Control Risks For WORLDPAY account of taxes or charges, the fees will be increased by the amount of such taxes or charges such that Control Risks will receive an amount equal to the original fees which would have been due under this Agreement if no tax deduction or withholding had been required. 4.2. The Client shall reimburse Control Risks all reasonably and properly incurred travel, accommodation, subsistence and other out-of-pocket expenses, relating to the provision of the Services, which shall be billed at cost as disbursements. An administrative expense of five percent (5%) of the fees will be added to the invoice. The administrative expense covers non-recoverable costs that cannot be separately identified, such as telephone calls (including mobile phones), stationery, photocopying, printing and facsimile transmissions. Where applicable, database or document retrieval expenses shall also be added to the invoice. 4.3. The Client acknowledges and agrees that the timely payment of invoices within the aforementioned thirty (30)-day period is a critical condition to the Services being provided. Control Risks reserves the right to charge daily interest on the total undisputed sum outstanding beyond the relevant due date at the rate of two percent (2%) above the annual base rate published by Barclays Bank PLC at the time, subject to any statutory limitation which may apply. 4.4. Fees will be payable in the British pounds sterling. 4.5. In the event the Client cancels the provision of Services at any point in time (whether or not such cancellation is concurrent with a formal termination of the Agreement), Control Risks shall invoice the Client for any fees and/or expenses incurred to date and the Client shall settle the invoice in accordance with this paragraph 4. 4.6. If any amount owed by the Client to Control Risks remains outstanding for more than thirty (30) days after the date of the relevant invoice, then until all amounts have been paid, Control Risks reserves the right to cease providing the Services with immediate effect and to retain documents and papers belonging to the Client until such time as any outstanding amounts have been paid in full. 5. Intellectual Property 5.1. The copyright and any other intellectual property rights, whether registered or unregistered (including, but not limited to, design rights, trademarks, patents, database rights, confidential information and knowhow), in: (a) any reports, documents, materials, data or other information created by or provided by the Client relating to the Services shall belong to the Client; and (b) any reports, documents, materials, data or other information created by or provided by Control Risks relating to the Services shall, unless otherwise agreed in writing between the Client and Control Risks, belong to Control Risks, but the Client shall be entitled to use such documents or information for legitimate business purposes by way of a non-exclusive worldwide non-transferable licence, subject to payment in full of all sums payable under this Agreement. 5.2. Each party warrants that it, or any person making disclosure of information on its behalf, has the right to supply all the information being supplied to the other party and that the supply of such information, and its receipt and use by such other party, will not infringe any rights, including any intellectual property rights, held by any third party or result in a breach by the disclosing party (or any person making disclosure on its behalf) of any law, regulatory obligation or fiduciary duty owed to any third party. Each party agrees to indemnify the other party against any loss it may suffer as a result of the breach of this warranty by the disclosing party (or any person making disclosure on its behalf). 6. Data Protection 6.1. Each party warrants that any personal data and sensitive personal data that is provided to the other party for the purposes of the provision of the Services has been collected and is being disclosed in accordance with the provisions of any applicable data protection and/or privacy legislation (including, without limitation, the U.K. Data Protection Act 1998) and that consent to the transfer of such personal data to the other party, and by such other party to reputable third parties, has been obtained where required. - 10- Prepared by Control Risks For WORLDPAY 6.2. Each party warrants that any personal data or sensitive personal data provided to it by the other party shall be processed in a manner consistent with such receiving party’s obligations under applicable data protection or other legislation and that the receiving party shall treat such data in a manner consistent with the principles set out in such legislation. 6.3. Control Risks undertakes that it will not transfer personal data of the client to any third party without the Client’s prior written consent. 7. Anti-Bribery and Anti-Corruption 7.1. Control Risks hereby warrants and agrees that: (a) it shall not (and shall ensure that its directors and employees shall not) engage in any activity, practice or conduct which would constitute an offence under the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act of 1977, the U.K. Bribery Act 2010, legislation implementing the 1997 OECD Convention on Combating Bribery of Foreign Public Officials in International Business Transactions or the United Nations Convention Against Corruption and/or the anti-corruption or anti-money laundering laws of any country in which it conducts business; and (b) it has, and shall maintain in place throughout the term of the Agreement, appropriate policies, procedures and training including, but not limited to, adequate procedures under the U.K. Bribery Act 2010 designed to prevent acts of bribery by its directors and employees. 8. Limitation on Liability 8.1. Nothing in this Agreement shall limit or exclude the liability of either party for: (a) death or personal injury resulting from its negligence; (b) fraud or fraudulent misrepresentation; (c) breach of the confidentiality or data protection provisions hereunder; or (d) any liability which cannot be excluded or limited by law. 8.2. Subject to clause 8.1, each party’s entire liability for losses suffered by the other arising out of or in connection with the provision of Services under the Agreement (including any liability for the acts or omissions of its employees, agents and subcontractors), shall be limited as follows: (a) neither party shall be liable for any of the following losses suffered by the other: loss of profit; loss of revenue; loss of anticipated savings; loss of business opportunity; loss of goodwill; loss of and/or corruption of non-personal data; and/or any indirect or consequential losses; and (b) Each party's maximum aggregate liability for any other loss suffered by the other shall be limited to 125% of the amount of Control Risks' fees received for the provision of the Services. 8.3. Control Risks shall have no liability to the Client for any matter which falls outside the scope of the instructions provided by the Client in relation to the Services. 9. Term and Termination 9.1. The Agreement is effective as of the date indicated in clause 1.4 and shall continue until the Services have been completed and paid for in full, unless terminated by either party in accordance with this paragraph 9. 9.2. Either party may terminate the Agreement at any time upon thirty (30) days written notice to the other party. 9.3. Either party may terminate the Agreement with immediate effect upon written notice to the other party: (a) if the other party commits any continuing or material breach of any of the provisions of the Agreement and, in the case of such a breach that is capable of remedy, fails to remedy the same within fifteen (15) days after receipt of a written notice by the terminating party giving full particulars of the breach and requiring it to be remedied; -11 - Prepared by Control Risks For WORLDPAY (b) if the other party becomes insolvent or is unable to pay its debts as they fall due or goes into liquidation either voluntarily or as required by law; (c) if, in its sole discretion, there is a breakdown of trust and confidence with the other party; and/or (d) under the circumstances described in clause 12.1. 9.4. On termination of this Agreement for any reason; (a) the Client shall immediately pay to Control Risks all of Control Risks' outstanding unpaid invoices and any interest thereon and, in respect of Services supplied and costs incurred but for which no invoice has been submitted, Control Risks shall be entitled to submit an invoice, which shall be payable immediately on receipt; and (b) the accrued rights and liabilities of the parties as at termination shall not be affected, and any provision of this Agreement relating to or necessary to enable the enforcement of such rights and discharge of such liabilities shall survive termination, as shall the provisions of paragraph 10 (Confidentiality) and paragraph 11 (Non-solicitation). 10. Confidentiality 10.1. As used herein, “Confidential Information" shall mean, with respect to either party, any proprietary or confidential information or data concerning the business, technology, products or affairs of such party furnished or made available by it (the “Disclosing Party”) to the other party (the “Receiving Party”) in connection with this Agreement. A Receiving Party shall not disclose the Disclosing Party's Confidential Information to any third party without the prior written consent of the Disclosing Party, except in connection with its performance under this Agreement or pursuant to clause 10.3, and shall protect the Disclosing Party's Confidential Information against unauthorised use or disclosure using at least those measures that it takes to protect its own Confidential Information of a similar nature, but no less than reasonable care. Notwithstanding the foregoing, disclosure of Confidential Information is permitted on a need to know basis to the directors, officers, employees, professional advisers and insurers of the Client Group or, as the case may be, the Control Risks Group, provided that each such person is made aware of the confidential and proprietary nature thereof and agrees to abide by confidentiality obligations no less onerous than those contained herein. 10.2. The parties agree that "Confidential Information” does not include information which: (a) was available to the Receiving Party on a non-confidential basis at the time of or prior to the receipt of the information by it; (b) is or becomes publicly available on a non-confidential basis through no fault of the Receiving Party; (c) is received in good faith by the Receiving Party from a third party, provided that such third party is not bound by a confidentiality agreement with the Disclosing Party or otherwise legally prohibited from transmitting the information; and/or (d) is, or can reasonably be proved to have been, developed independently by the Receiving Party. 10.3. In the event the Receiving Party receives an order to disclose any Confidential Information by a court of competent jurisdiction, a recognised stock exchange, governmental department or agency or other regulatory body to which it is subject, it shall promptly notify the Disclosing Party in writing and use reasonable good faith efforts to: (a) disclose only the specific Confidential Information legally required to be disclosed; and (b) assist the Disclosing Party (at the Disclosing Party's request) in obtaining a protective order or other appropriate assurances that the confidential nature of the Confidential Information shall be protected and preserved. Any costs incurred by the Receiving Party in resisting or complying with the disclosure efforts described in this clause 10.3 (including reasonable legal costs) shall be borne by the Disclosing Party. -12- Prepared by Control Risks For WORLDPAY 11. Non-solicitation Neither party shall (during the term of this Agreement or for a period of twelve (12) months after its termination, whether due to the completion of Services or otherwise) directly or indirectly solicit, encourage for employment, employ or otherwise engage the services of any employee, consultant or subcontractor of the other party that was introduced to such party in connection with the Services provided hereunder, except with the prior written consent of the introducing party. This paragraph 11 shall not prohibit employment solicitation methods aimed at the general public and not specifically targeted at personnel of the other party. 12. General 12.1. Force majeure Neither party shall be liable to the other for any loss or any failure or delay to perform any obligation under the Agreement which is due to causes beyond its reasonable control (including, without limitation, acts of God, industrial disputes, protests, fire, flood, storm, epidemic, explosion, breakdown of plant or machinery, act of terrorism, war, national emergency or military operations). Should such circumstances continue for more than ninety (90) days, either party may terminate the Agreement in accordance with paragraph 9 above. 12.2. Amendment No amendment to this Agreement shall be effective unless expressly agreed in writing and signed by a duly authorised representative of each party. 12.3. Waiver All waivers shall be in writing. Any failure by either party to exercise (or any delay in exercising) a right or remedy provided by this Agreement or by law does not constitute a waiver of the right or remedy or a waiver of any other rights or remedies available to such party. 12.4. Assignment This Agreement may not be assigned in whole or in part by either party without the prior written consent of the other party. 12.5. Counterparts This Agreement may be executed in counterpart, each of which shall constitute an original, but which taken together shall constitute one and the same agreement. 12.6. Third party rights Other than as may be expressly provided in this Agreement, the parties do not intend that any person who is not a party to the Agreement shall have any rights to enforce any term hereof. 12.7. No partnership or agency Nothing in this Agreement is intended to or shall operate to create a partnership or joint venture of any kind between Control Risks and the Client or to authorise either Control Risks or the Client to act as agent for the other, and neither Control Risks nor the Client shall have authority to act in the name or on behalf of or otherwise to bind the other in any way (including, but not limited to, the making of any representation or warranty, the assumption of any obligation or liability and the exercise of any right or power). 12.8. Severance (a) If any provision of this Agreement shall be found by any court or administrative body of competent jurisdiction to be invalid or unenforceable, such invalidity or unenforceability shall not affect the other provisions of this Agreement which shall remain in full force and effect. - 13- Prepared by Control Risks For WORLDPAY (b) If any provision of this Agreement is so found to be invalid or unenforceable but would be valid or enforceable if some part of the provision were deleted, the provision in question shall apply with such modification(s) as may be necessary to make it valid. 12.9. Notices Any notice (including a consent or waiver) given under the Agreement shall be in writing and signed by or on behalf of the party giving it and may be served by delivering it personally or sending it by recorded delivery, registered mail, a commercial courier company or email to the address of the relevant party notified by that party to the other or it shall be sent by email to the email addresses previously exchanged by the parties. Any such notice shall be deemed to have been received: (a) if delivered personally, at the time of delivery; (b) in the case of recorded delivery or registered mail within the same country, on the second business day after posting; (c) in the case of a commercial courier, on the date and at the time that the courier’s delivery receipt is signed; and (d) in the case of email, when receipt of such notice is acknowledged by the recipient. 12.10. Governing law and jurisdiction The Agreement shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of England and Wales, and any dispute arising under the Agreement shall be submitted to the exclusive jurisdiction of the English courts. 12.11. Entire Agreement This Agreement constitutes the whole agreement between the parties, and replaces and extinguishes all previous agreements, undertakings, or collateral contracts of any nature made by the parties, whether oral or written, in relation to its subject matter. Nothing in this Clause shall limit or exclude any liability for fraud. 12.12. Publicity Control Risks shall not make any announcement regarding the existence of this Agreement, or the fact that it is working with the Client, to any third party without the prior written consent of the Client. Control Risks shall have no right to use the Client name or any of its brand names, logos or trademarks without the prior written consent of the Client. 12.13. Modern Slavery Act The Client is subject to the provisions of the Modern Slavery Act 2015 and accordingly must satisfy itself as to the identity and working practices of its supply chain. To this end, Control Risks agrees to sign the Client s Supplier Code of Conduct attached at Appendix 1 hereto. - 14- Prepared by Control Risks For WORLDPAY APPENDIX 1 - SUPPLIER CODE OF CONDUCT Introduction At Worldpay, we hold ourselves to high business standards and we want to work with suppliers who do the same. We work smart, we're spirited and we're supportive, and these values are evident in all we do. That's why we promote high legal, ethical, corporate and employee-related standards in our own business and ask our suppliers to do the same. We realise you will have values of your own. Not all statements below are contractually binding, but we hope that our respective values and standards will be compatible so we can do great work together. We are seeking your commitment to work with us to the spirit of the standards set out below. In our interaction with each other Integrity Well always be honest and fair with each other. Clarity Our communications will be clear, unambiguous and timely. We'll keep to the facts. Feedback We can be open in our feedback to each other and learn from each other's good practices. We'll talk at appropriate intervals when things are going well, and talk more often when they're not. Value-focus We try to continuously improve the value of our services. We'll work together to identify and communicate opportunities to innovate, improve efficiency and avoid waste. Assets We'll respect and protect each other's physical and intellectual assets as if they were our own. Health and safety We'll protect the physical safety of our colleagues and minimise their exposure to health risks. Respect We will respect each person’s right to their opinion. There will be no harassment or bullying behaviours. Exchange of trade We won't buy products or services based solely on a reciprocal arrangement nor do we promise or threaten to leverage existing or potential business in order to gain preferential treatment. In our dealings with the wider world Bribery and corruption We won't take advantage of others through manipulation, concealment, abuse of confidential information, misrepresentation of facts or other unfair business practises and all our staff complete training in this area to ensure they understand appropriate behaviours. Bribery and corruption won't be tolerated. Corporate responsibility We’ll act in a socially responsible manner appropriate to the countries where we operate. We'll seek to protect and sustain our environment, and to support local charities, community groups and initiatives that have an ambition to improve life in the communities in which we work. Diversity and inclusion We strive for our culture and ways of working to be fully inclusive. We will engage, promote and manage our people's performance based on merit and we won't tolerate discrimination on any grounds. Human rights We will respect all internationally proclaimed human rights. Child labour We won't engage in or support child labour. We will employ only workers who meet the minimum legal age requirement for their country. We look forward to working with you. Thank you. Signed on behalf of: Worldpay Print Name: Philip Jansen Job Title: Chief Executive Officer Supplier Name: Print Name: Alex Martin Job Title: Director Date: 1st September 2015 Signature: Date: 12th May 2017 Signature: - 1 - Prepared by Control Risks For WORLDPAY SIGNATURE PAGE To instruct Control Risks to commence work on this assignment, please complete and sign this page, and return this document to: Alex Martin Control Risks Group Limited | Cottons Centre | Cottons Lane | London | SE1 2QG T: + 44 (0)207 970 2363 alex.martin@controlrisks.com We agree to the services and fees described in this proposal and to Control Risks’ General Terms and Conditions of Business. Our invoice information is as set out below and should be used for billing us. WORLDPAY WORLDPAY Control Risks Group Limited Alex Martin Director Control Risks 12th May 2017 -1 - Prepared by Control Risks For WORLDPAY
