data.text: PROCUREMENT CONTRACT SUPPLEMENT Fidelity information Services, LLC, an Arkansas limited liability company located at 601 Riverside Avenue, Jacksonville, Florida 32204 (“FIS") and Cyber-Ark Software Inc., a Delaware corporation, located at 57 Wells Avenue, Newton, MA 02459 ("Provider") agree that the terms set forth below are incorporated into the Software License and Maintenance Agreement between them dated June 26 , 2013 (the "Agreement"), which is being executed concurrently with this Procurement Contract Supplement ("Supplement"). Definitions appearing at the end of any Part of this Supplement shall apply to the words or phrases defined wherever those defined words or phrases are used in this Supplement. Unless the context clearly requires otherwise, the word "include" is non-limiting, and the words "agree" and "notify* (or "provide notice") mean to do so in writing. In the event of a conflict, ambiguity or contradiction between this Supplement and any other part of the Agreement, this Supplement takes precedence. PART1. TERM a. EXPIRATION AND RENEWAL. (1) Provider shall notify FIS of each date that the Term is set to expire, within one hundred eighty (180) but at least ninety (90) days before that date. (2) If the Agreement provides for automatic renewal or extension of the Term or for automatic renewal or extension of any Service, lease or license, or if the Agreement provides for renewal or extension at the option of FIS, Provider shall notify FIS of the date by which FIS must give any notice required to prevent or elect renewal, as the case may be. within ninety (90) but at least forty-five (45) days before that date. Provider shall include in any such notification the requirements for a timely notice by FIS. (3) During the period following any notification by Provider under paragraph (1) or (2) above, Provider and FIS shall mutually discuss the basis upon which they may wish to renew or extend the Term, Service, lease or license, as applicable. However, FIS's right to prevent automatic renewal or extension or elect a renewal or extension, as the case may be, shall be unconditional, subject only to its giving timely notice of nonrenewal or renewal. b. TERMINATION. FIS may terminate the Agreement, or any Services thereunder, without penalty (i) at any time upon giving Provider sixty (60) days prior notice of its intent to do so or (ii) in the event of a Change in Control of Provider, upon thirty (30) days notice to Provider. In the event of any termination by FIS pursuant to this Section b, FIS shall be obligated to pay for Products purchased and Services providedby Provider through the effective date of such termination. c. DEFINITIONS (1) A "Change in Control" of Provider is any event or series of events by which (i) any person or entity or group of persons or entities shall acquire control of Provider, where "control" is the possession, directly or indirectly, of the power to direct or cause the direction of the management and policies of Provider, whether through record or beneficial ownership of voting securities, by contract or otherwise or (ii) if Provider is a corporation, limited liability company or other entity having a board of directors or other group of individuals having equivalent functions, during any period of 12 consecutive months commencing before or after the date hereof, individuals who at the beginning of such 12-month period were members of Provider's board of directors or other such group shall cease for any reason to constitute a majority of the members. (2) The "Services' are services of any kind and in any form provided under the Agreement, including data processing, software hosting, software as a service, knowledge or information services, provision of work or workers on an outsourced basis, production management, consulting, customization or other custom development, facility management, maintenance, training and support. (3) The “Term" is the term of the Agreement, including any extensions or renewals. PART 2. SAFETY AND SECURITY a. SAFETY AND SECURITY ON PREMISES. Provider Personnel must comply with all FIS postings and notices regarding safety and security when on the premises of FIS, and with the postings and notices of FIS Clients or their customers when on their premises. Provider Personnel must not carry weapons or ammunition onto the premises of FIS, FIS Clients or their customers and must not use or carry weapons or ammunition while attending FIS-sponsored events. b. ACCESS PRIVILEGES AND RESTRICTIONS. In the event that Provider Personnel will receive user-IDs to access FIS's applications, systems or servers, or those of FIS Clients or their customers, the following provisions shall also apply: wpp-Pnxttfcmcnt ('ootnxi SuppfcuKui i ovmjui 1 (1) Provider shall provide FIS with the full legal names of all personnel that will be issued user-IDs, and Provider shall not request that such a user-ID be provided or provide such a user-ID or to any individual that will not be directly engaged by or at the request of FIS to provide Services. (2) FIS reserves the right to deny any user-ID request or terminate any user-ID that has been provided. Provider shall notify FIS within twenty-four (24) hours of any changes to the Provider Personnel for whom such a user  ID has been requested or to whom such a user-ID has been provided. (3) Provider shall not permit any such user-id to be used by more than one individual. c. INFORMATION SECURITY PROGRAM. Provider shall be responsible for establishing and maintaining an information security program to (i) ensure the security and confidentiality of FIS's data or that of FIS Clients or their customers that may come into the possession or control of Provider, (ii) protect against any anticipated threats or hazards to the security or integrity of such data that may be in the possession of Provider, and (ill) protect against unauthorized access to or use of such data that could result in substantial harm or inconvenience to FIS, or to any FIS Clients or their customers. In the event Provider may have access to any such data, the following provisions apply: (1) Provider shall maintain security for its own systems, servers, and communications links as necessary to protect FIS's or Clients* networks or those of their customers. Provider's security controls must include (i) anti- virus/malware devices, (ii) DMZ subnet and firewall controls, (iii) IDS/IPS controls, (iv) patch management controls, (v) physical security controls, and (v) change management controls. (2) Provider shall contract with an appropriately qualified third party security assurance vendor, to have performed, on a semi-annual basis, a security assessment that includes intrusion testing. Results of these tests will be forwarded to FIS within ten (10) business days of the receipt by Provider from the Provider. If after reviewing such test results, FIS believes that additional testing is warranted, Provider shall discuss such additional testing with FIS in good faith. (3) Provider shall notify FIS of any and all breaches to Provider’s security and work with FIS management to identify the root cause of the incident and the potential impact to FIS, as reasonably requested by FIS. (4) Not less frequently than once each year during the Term, Provider shall conduct, or have a third party conduct, vulnerability scans and penetration tests of those components of Provider's environment required to support any Product and shall provide to FIS the results of any such scans and tests. In addition, Provider shall allow FIS or one of FIS's approved third-party security vendors to perform periodic vulnerability scans and penetration tests of those components of Provider's environment, if any, required to support any Product. FIS agrees to share the results of any scan or test it performs In Provider's environment to assist Provider in correcting any security vulnerabilities identified. Provider shall correct any security vulnerability identified in FIS's scans and penetration tests in accordance with the following schedule which based on severity level: (a) High severity vulnerabilities will be corrected within sixty (60) business days; (b) Medium severity vulnerabilities will be corrected within ninety (90) business days; (c) Low severity vulnerabilities will be corrected within one hundred eighty (180) business days. Provider will be considered to have access to such data in the event that a communications link (defined as a pre-established communications path from the customer premises, through a carrier network, to the FIS network) exists between any of Provider s* systems or servers and any of FIS's systems or servers on which such data is stored. d. PCI DATA SECURITY STANDARD. If and to the extent Provider or any Product is subject to the Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS) requirements, Provider shall comply with said requirements during the Term. e. DEFINITIONS (1) An ‘‘Affiliate'' of a party is an entity which, directly or indirectly is controlled by, or is under common control with that party, where “control" of the party or other entity is the possession, directly or indirectly, of the power to direct or cause the direction of the management and policies of the party or other entity, whether through record or beneficial ownership of voting securities, by contract or otherwise. (2) A “Client" or "FIS Client" is any current or prospective client or other customer of FIS or an FIS Affiliate. (3) A "Product" is any item of goods of any kind and in any form provided under the Agreement, including equipment, supplies, data and software. Procurement Contract Supplement Pg 2 of 9 (4) "Provider Personnel" are employees of Provider, or of any Subcontractor, which are assigned to perform Services. (5) A ‘Subcontractor* is any individual other than an employee of Provider, or any corporation or other entity, which is engaged directly or indirectly by Provider to perform any obligations of Provider obligations under the Agreement, in whole or in part. PART 3. SAFEGUARDING OF INFORMATION a. PROTECTION OF FIS CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION. Provider must protect all FIS Confidential Information with at least the same degree of care as it uses to protect its own confidential information, but in no event shall Provider use less than a reasonable standard of care for any FIS Confidential Information. (1) Provider shall (i) restrict the use and disclosure of the FIS Confidential Information to its employees solely on a "need to know" basis in order to perform Provider's obligations in accordance with the Agreement, (ii) ensure that its employees are bound to it by confidentiality obligations at least as protective of the other as FIS’s Confidential Information as the provisions of this PART 3, (iii) require employees to protect and restrict the use of all FIS Confidential Information, (iv) establish procedural, physical and electronic safeguards, designed to prevent the compromise or unauthorized disclosure of FIS Confidential Information and to achieve the objectives of the Guidelines, (v) not use or disclose any FIS Confidential Information except as expressly provided in the Agreement, (vi) promptly investigate any security breach to determine whether such incident has resulted or is likely to result in misuse or unauthorized possession or disclosure of FIS Confidential Information; (vii) promptly notify FIS of any release or breach of FIS Confidential Information and to the extent requested by FIS, if an incident has resulted or is likely to result in misuse of NPI, PHI or payment card data, notify FIS and each affected FIS Client or of their affected customers as soon as possible; and (viil) comply with the Guidelines and all current and future Privacy Regulations to the extent applicable to Provider, with regard to any NPI, PHI or payment card data which Provider may receive or to which Provider may have access. (2) In providing any notices of release or breach of FIS Confidential Information, Provider shall use commercially reasonable efforts to confirm that the individuals receiving such notifications (including any one or more of FIS's managerial staff) are generally responsible for security matters relating to such FIS Confidential Information. Provider shall notify FIS within twenty-four (24) hours of: (i) any actual or attempted unauthorized possession or use of FIS Confidential Information; (ii) the effect of such use or possession; and (iii) the corrective action taken in response thereto and shall reimburse FIS for its costs in notifying FIS Clients or their customers of any such actual or attempted unauthorized possession or use, in making available to them any credit monitoring services, any other costs reasonably incurred by FIS with respect to any such unauthorized actual or attempted possession or use. (3) FIS Confidential Information shall remain the property of FIS, its Affiliate or other party from or through whom it was provided. Except for NPI, PHI or other information protected by the Privacy Regulations, or any payment card data, the following exceptions shall apply to this Section a: (a) Provider shall not be obligated to preserve the confidentiality of any information that: (i) was previously known; (ii) is a matter of public knowledge; (iii) was or is independently developed; (iv) is released for disclosure with written consent; or (v) is received from a third party to whom it was disclosed without restriction. (b) Disclosure of FIS Confidential Information shall be permitted if it is: (a) required by law; (b) in connection with the tax treatment or tax structure of the Agreement; or (c) in response to a valid order of a U.S. court or other governmental body, provided that Provider provides FIS with written notice and FIS is afforded a reasonable opportunity to obtain a protective order. (4) At the end of the Term, or upon termination of the Agreement, Provider shall destroy all FIS Confidential Information in a manner designed to preserve its confidentiality, or, at FIS's written request and expense, return it to FIS. b. PRIVACY. If in connection with the Agreement Provider receives, stores or accesses any NPI, PHI or other information or materials that are subject to the Privacy Regulations, Provider shall comply with the applicable requirements of such Privacy Regulations. Without limiting the foregoing, and in addition to the confidentiality and security obligations otherwise set forth in the Agreement, Provider shall (i) ensure the security and confidentiality of such information or materials; (ii) protect against any anticipated threats or hazards to the security or integrity of such records; (iii) detect unauthorized access to or use of such records or information and (iv) protect against unauthorized access to or use of such records or information that would result in harm or inconvenience to any FIS Client or any customer of an FIS Client. Provider acknowledges that the Guidelines include provisions regarding the safeguarding consumer information, response programs and notice in the event of unauthorized Procurement Contract Supplement Pg J of* access to consumer information, that FIS provides information processing services to Clients subject to the Guidelines, and that FIS may be required to notify Clients, their customers or other third parties of security incidents that result, or are likely to result, in the in misuse or unauthorized possession or disclosure of NPI, PHI, payment card data or other Confidential Information. Provider agrees to cooperate with FIS in making any such required notifications. c. SPECIFIC PRECAUTIONS. Provider represents and agrees that it has and will maintain in place commercially reasonable precautions to safeguard the confidentiality, security and integrity of FIS Confidential Information in a manner designed to meet the requirements of this PART 3. These precautions shall include (i) contractual restrictions on access to the information by Provider's vendors and contractors, (ii) intrusion detection systems on all information systems of FIS maintained or controlled by Provider, and (iii) notification procedures for notifying FIS promptly in the event a security breach is detected or suspected, as well as other response programs when there Is a suspected or detected unauthorized disclosure, access or attempted access of non-public personal information. These precautions shall also include, as appropriate: (i) access controls to FIS information systems, including controls to identify and permit access only to authorized individuals and controls to prevent access to FIS Confidential Information through fraudulent means; (II) employee controls and training; (ill) physical access restrictions at locations where FIS Confidential Information is located; (iv) encryption of electronic FIS Confidential Information when appropriate or legally required; and (v) a disaster recovery plan as appropriate to protect against loss or damage to FIS Confidential Information due to potential hazards such as fire or water damage or technological failures. Provider shall (i) monitor the foregoing measures with periodic audits or testing and provide copies of the same sufficient to assure to FIS or its regulatory authorities that Provider is implementing these precautions and (ii) notify FIS immediately in the event there is any suspected or actual unauthorized access, use, disclosure or alteration to FIS Confidential Information. d. DEFINITIONS (1) “FIS Confidential Information" is information disclosed in any form in connection with the Agreement to Provider, or to a Provider Affiliate or Subcontractor, by FIS, an FIS Affiliate or an FIS Client, or by a customer of an FIS Client, regardless of the manner of disclosure (including disclosure by giving access), that constitutes or contains either (a) NPI, PHI, or payment card data (b) other data or information which is not generally known, including business information, specifications, research, software, trade secrets, discoveries, ideas, know-how, designs, drawings, flow charts, data, computer programs, marketing plans, budget figures, and other financial and business information. FIS designates the Agreement as FIS Confidential Information, as well as (i) FIS’s business strategy and direction, (ii) FIS's operating or marketing plans, (iii) FIS's employee records (name, address, phone number, salary, taxpayer or government identification number, date of birth, health records, bank account information, labor party), (iv) memos or other documents or communications pertaining to pending litigation or contracts, (v) any information disclosed by FIS that is designated as "confidential" at or prior to disclosure and (vi) information of the kind described by any of the foregoing categories that is of or disclosed by an FIS Client, an FIS Affiliate, or a customer of an FIS Client. (2) The "Guidelines" are the standards and guidelines established pursuant to the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act of 1899, relating to the protection of nonpublic personal information provided to financial institutions CNPI"). pursuant to the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996, relating to the protection of protected health information ("PHI"), pursuant to or other relevant privacy laws, or the Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS), relating to cardholder data ("payment card data"). (3) The "Privacy Regulations" are the standards, guidelines and other regulations established by various federal or state regulatory agencies to protect the privacy and security of customer or patient information held by financial institutions, medical service providers and other entities. PART 4. PURCHASE AND USE OF PRODUCTS a. PURCHASING BY FIS AFFILIATES. Any FIS Affiliate may purchase Products under the Agreement to the same extent as FIS, so long as it continues to be an FIS Affiliate. Each FIS Affiliate is an intended third party beneficiary of the Agreement, entitled to rely upon all rights, representations and warranties made by Provider under the Agreement to the same extent as if such Affiliate were FIS hereunder. b. TRANSFER AND USE. Notwithstanding any restrictions on assignment or transfer of less than full ownership of any Product procured by a Purchaser under the Agreement, the Purchaser may (i) freely transfer the Product to any FIS Affiliate, together with the Purchaser's rights in the Product and (ii) allow any FIS Affiliate to exercise any rights which the Purchaser may exercise under the Agreement with respect to the Product. Procurement Contract Supplement Pg 4 of 9 c. SHRINK WRAPS AND SIMILAR AGREEMENTS. Neither Provider nor any Provider Affiliate shall impose upon FIS or any FIS Affiliate, as a condition to purchasing any Product, that FIS or the FIS Affiliate agree to any shrink wrap, click-wrap, Web-wrap, browse-wrap or other agreement that is to be made without signature by FIS or the FIS Affiliate. If Provider or a Provider Affiliate has entered into or hereafter enters into an agreement of such a nature with FIS or an FIS Affiliate, Provider agrees on behalf of itself or the Provider Affiliate, as the case may be, that such agreement shall in any event be subject to this Supplement. d. SURVIVAL. Termination of the Agreement for any reason shall not terminate any right acquired by a Purchaser with respect to the Product, including any right to use the Product or perform other activities in support of such use. e. DEFINITION (1) The “Purchaser" of a Product is the party that has purchased or otherwise procured the Product under the Agreement. PART 5. FEES a. PAYMENT TERMS. FIS shall not be obligated to pay Provider fees or other amounts under the Agreement less than thirty (30) days following FIS’s receipt of a correct and undisputed invoice submitted to FIS by Provider. Except as otherwise expressly set forth in the Agreement, Provider shall not invoice FIS for any Products or associated expenses prior to completion of the requisite delivery or other performance, or the end of the month or other agreed time period for which the fees are being charged, in the case of Services provided on a time and materials basis. FIS may withhold payment of any amount disputed in good faith pending resolution of such dispute. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in any contract, invoice, document or form issued by Provider, whether signed or otherwise accepted by FIS, FIS will not be obligated for the payment of interest on late payments, late payment fees or penalties of any kind whatsoever. b. BILLING RECORDS. Provider shall create and maintain accurate records and supporting documentation for all invoices during, and for two (2) years following the end of the Term. Upon thirty (30) business days' prior notice, FIS may verify Provider’s compliance with this PART 5. Such verification will be conducted by FIS auditors in a manner that minimizes disruption to Provider's business. FIS may use an independent auditor to assist with such verification provided FIS has a written confidentiality agreement in place with such independent auditor. Provider agrees to provide to FIS and its auditors accurate electronic and written records, system tool outputs, and other requested system information sufficient to provide verification that Provider’s billing invoices are accurate and in compliance with this PART 5. FIS will notify Provider in writing if any such verification indicates that Provider is not in compliance with this PART 5, and Provider shall promptly reimburse FIS for any overpayments made by FIS under the Agreement. The rights and obligations set forth in this Section shall remain in effect during the Term and for two years following the end of the Term. c. PRICE INCREASES. During the Term. Provider shall not increase the prices applicable to any Products, except as explicitly set forth in the Agreement. PART 6. INDEMNIFICATION. a. INDEMNITY. Provider shall indemnify, hold harmless and defend at its own expense FIS, or an FIS Affiliate, subcontractor or Client, and its officers, directors and employees, against any action, litigation, or claim brought against it by any third party for actual or alleged (i) infringement of any trademark, patent, copyright or other intellectual property right (including misappropriation of trade secrets) based upon, related to, or arising out of any goods or services provided under the Agreement, (ii) gross negligence, willful misconduct or failure to comply with applicable laws, rules and regulations by Provider, or by a Provider Affiliate or a Subcontractor, in connection with performance under the Agreement, or (iii) breach of any obligation under PART 3 (SAFEGUARDING OF INFORMATION). Provider’s indemnification obligations under this Section a shall include any and all liabilities, losses, costs, damages, and expenses (including court costs and reasonable attorneys* fees) associated with each Claim. No limitation or exclusion of liability or remedies shall be effective with respect to any indemnification or hold harmless obligation of Provider under the Agreement. b. CONDITIONS ON OBLIGATION. Any indemnification obligation of FIS to indemnify an Indemnified Party for a Claim is contingent upon: (i) the Indemnified Party promptly notifying FIS in writing of the Claim; (ii) FIS having sole control over the defense and settlement of the Claim; (iii) the Indemnified Party reasonably cooperating with FIS during defense and settlement efforts with respect to the Claim; and (iv) the Indemnified Party not making any admission, concession, consent judgment, default judgment or settlement of the Claim or any part thereof. c. REMEDIAL MEASURES. If an order, judgment or settlement is obtained or reasonably anticipated against FIS’s use of any Product on the basis of any Claim, Provider shall at its sole cost and expense promptly eliminate the infringement by (i) acquiring a license or licenses on FIS’s behalf to provide the necessary rights to FIS, (ii) Procurement Contract Supplement Pg 5 of9 modifying the Product without impairing its functionality, or to the extent Provider is unable to successfully eliminate the infringement by either of the foregoing courses of action, notwithstanding Provider's best efforts, (iii) provide FIS with a non-infringing substitute for the Product that provides FIS with the same functionality as the Product. d. DEFINITIONS (1) "Claim'' means any action, litigation, or claim for which party is subject to an indemnification obligation under the Agreement. (2) "Indemnified Party" means a party that is entitled to be indemnified by FIS with respect to a Claim. The obligations of Provider set forth in this PART 6 constitute Provider's sole obligation to FIS with respect to infringement of any trademark, patent, copyright or other intellectual property right (including misappropriation of trade secrets) based upon, related to, or arising out of any goods or services provided under the Agreement PART 7. NO PREFERENCES OR EXCLUSIVITY. FIS shall not be required in any way to accord preferential or exclusive status to Provider or its Products, and FIS shall not be required to purchase or use Provider's Products to the exclusion of others or to purchase, use or otherwise achieve any minimum volumes or activity with respect to Provider's Products. PART 8. ASSIGNABILITY. FIS may, without consent or notice, assign the Agreement to an FIS Affiliate or pursuant to any merger or acquisition of all or substantially all of its assets. Provider may, without consent or notice to FIS, assign the Agreement to a Provider Affiliate or pursuant to any merger or acquisition of all or substantially all of its assets. In addition, FIS may partially assign the Agreement with respect to Products used by FIS Affiliate or a division, department or other segment of FIS or an FIS Affiliate, that is the subject of a divestiture by FIS or an FIS Affiliate (regardless of the form of transaction) pursuant to a mutually acceptable partial assignment and release agreement among FIS, Provider and the assignee. FIS and Provider hereby agree that an agreement materially consistent with the form of Partial Assignment and Release Agreement will be mutually acceptable. PART 9. LIMITATION OF LIABILITY. No limitation of the amount of Provider's liability set forth in the Agreement shall apply with respect to death, personal injury, or physical property damage due to Provider’s negligence or intentional misconduct or any indemnification obligation arising under the Agreement. No limitation of liability shall apply to limit Provider's liability to less than the total amount paid or payable under the Agreement or one million dollars ($1.000,000), whichever is greater. Under no circumstances shall FIS have any obligation to Provider under any theory of liability or otherwise for any losses to the extent caused directly or indirectly by (i) Provider, (ii) a third party other than FIS’s authorized agents, (iii) adherence to Provider's specifications, (iv) improper or incomplete systems, data, software or equipment supplied by Provider, or (v) a force majeure event not attributable to FIS or under FIS's ability to control. Under no circumstances shall Provider have any obligation to FIS under any theory of liability or otherwise for any losses to the extent caused directly or indirectly by (i) FIS, (ii) a third party other than Provider's authorized agents, (iii) adherence to FIS's specifications, (iv) improper or incomplete systems, data, software or equipment supplied by FIS, or (v) a force majeure event not attributable to Provider or under Provider's ability to control. PART 10. PERFORMANCE a. DELAYS. In the event Provider's performance is delayed, or is anticipated by Provider to be delayed, by a Force Majeure Event, Provider shall promptly notify FIS of (i) the date and details of the Force Majeure Event and the anticipated duration of the Force Majeure Event and the delay,(ii) any material changes in such details or anticipated duration, and (iii) when the Force Majeure Event or delay ends. Provider shall use its best efforts to perform in a timely manner, utilizing all resources reasonably required in the circumstances including reasonably available supplies or services from other sources. No excuse of a performance delay due a Force Majeure Event shall preclude FIS from exercising any right of termination otherwise available if the delay extends for more than two (2) business days beyond any applicable time for resumption of performance under any disaster recovery plan which Provider has agreed to follow, or if no such time for resumption of performance applies, then five (5) business days following commencement of the delay. b. SUBCONTRACTORS. Provider shall not utilize any individual, corporation or other as a Subcontractor without the prior written consent of FIS. Provider shall notify FIS of its intention to utilize a Subcontractor not less than thirty (30) days prior to the date it intends to do so. Provider shall provide such information and documentation concerning any proposed Subcontractor as FIS requests. Provider shall ensure that any Subcontractor complies with all provisions of the Agreement, including FIS's right to audit, confidentiality and privacy obligations, information security requirements, business continuity and disaster recovery programs, insurance requirements and any applicable regulatory guidelines and requirements. Provider is responsible for all Services regardless of where performed or whether performed by a Subcontractor. Procurement Contract Supplement Pg. 6 of 9 c. INSURANCE. Exhibit 1 sets forth minimum amounts of certain types of insurance coverage other requirements relating to such insurance. Provider shall maintain such insurance and comply with such other obligations during the Term, at its own expense. d. NONSOLICITATION. During the term of the Agreement, and for a period of twelve (12) months after its termination, Provider shall not, directly or indirectly (i) induce or influence any individual who is engaged or employed by FIS to terminate that engagement or employment or participate in a competitive business or activity, if the individual worked with Provider or developed a relationship with Provider in connection with FIS's engagement of Provider under the Agreement, or (ii) induce or influence any FIS Client to terminate or curtail its relationship with FIS. e. ONGOING QUALIFICATION OF PROVIDER (1) Provider shall keep complete, accurate, and up-to-date books and records in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles and sound business practices covering all transactions relating to the Agreement. (2) During the term of the Agreement and for any period FIS is subject to regulatory examination with respect to any Services, upon at least twenty (20) business days written notice from FIS, or such shorter period of time as FIS may reasonably request due to any regulatory activities or any threats or hazards described in Part 2.c clause (ii) of paragraph 2(c) above, Provider or its agents shall provide FIS's auditors and/or any of FIS's regulators with access to and any reasonable assistance that they may require with respect to any Provider office or location where the Services are performed for the purposes of performing audits or inspections of the Services and the business of FIS relating to the Services. Such audits shall be conducted during business hours at any Provider office or location where the Services are performed. If any audit by an auditor designated by FIS or a regulatory authority results in Provider being notified that Provider or Provider's agents are not materially in compliance with any law rule, regulation or any term or condition of the Agreement, Provider shall remedy any such noncompliance within thirty (30) days. Provider shall bear the expense of any such compliance. Any audit hereunder shall be at FIS expense and be subject to the following limitations: (i) use of any third party auditor that is a competitor of Provider shall be subject to Provider's prior written approval, such approval not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed; and (ii) FIS or any auditor conducting any such audit shall at all times comply with any and all reasonable security and confidentiality guidelines and other policies of Provider with respect to the audit, and not materially disrupt Provider's normal course of business. f. COMPLIANCE WITH LAW. In all circumstances, Provider shall comply with, and shall ensure that all Products comply with all any laws, codes, rules, regulations, ordinances or orders to Provider's performance under the Agreement party may be subject ("Laws"), including all Laws relating to export and import, privacy, use, disclosure or transfer of personal information, or security, and all Laws relating to the employment, health, safety and payment of Provider personnel. Provider shall perform an on-going review of Laws applicable to Provider's performance under the Agreement. Provider shall maintain the features and functions for all standard Products in accordance with all Laws applicable to such features and functions, including Laws enacted or amended after the effective date of the Agreement. Provider shall identify and procure all permits, certificates, approvals, licenses, and inspections necessary for Provider's performance under the Agreement other than such permits, certificates, approvals, licenses and inspection that FIS is directly responsible for obtaining under the Agreement. Without limiting any other obligation of Provider under the Agreement, Provider shall at all times comply with all Laws relating to the import or export of Products, including Laws relating to trade sanctions, export controls, the U.S. Foreign Assets Control Regulations, the U.S. Export Administration Regulations, and the U.S. International Traffic in Arms Regulations. Non-Discrimination and Affirmative Action: FIS is an Equal Opportunity and Affirmative Action Employer. Unless exempt, the Equal Opportunity Clauses set forth at 41 CFR § 60-1.4(a) (for women and minorities), 41 CFR § 60-250.5(a) and 41 CFR § 60-300.5(a) (for veterans), and 41 CFR § 60-741.5(a) (for disabled individuals); the provisions of 41 CFR § 61-250.10 and 41 CFR § 61-300.10 (veterans' employment reports); and the provisions of 29 CFR Part 471, Appendix A to Subpart A (posting notice of employee rights) are incorporated by reference as terms and conditions of this agreement and are binding on Subcontractors/Vendors. Subcontractors/Vendors also may be required to prepare written affirmative action programs as set forth at 41 CFR § 60-2.1 and/or otherwise comply with the regulations at 41 CFR Part 60. g. USE OF FIS NAMES. Provider shall not use FIS's names, logos, trademarks or stock exchange ticker symbol, or in connection with the Agreement those of any FIS Client, unless pre-approved in writing by FIS, and Provider shall not make any press release or other similar communication that mentions or implies a relationship between Provider and FIS, or between Provider and an FIS Client if due to the Agreement, unless pre-approved in writing by FIS. h. WARRANTIES. Procurement Contract Supplement Pg 7 of 9 (1) Provider represents and warrants that it has full right and authority to perform its obligations and grant the rights and licenses contained in the Agreement. (2) Provider represents and warrants that it has neither assigned or transferred nor entered into any other relationship by which it purports to assign or transfer any right, title or interest to any technology, process, material or intellectual property right that would be in conflict with the terms of the Agreement, and that it shall not do so in the future. (3) Provider represents and warrants to FIS that the Products, as delivered by Provider to FIS, Clients or their customers, will not contain any Destructive Elements and that Provider will not install, use, or execute any Destructive Elements on any FIS computers, or computers of FIS Clients or their customers. If FIS notifies Provider that it has been informed or has reason to believe that a Destructive Element was present in the Products as delivered by Provider to FIS, an FIS Client, or any customers of an FIS Client, Provider will promptly assist and work continuously with FIS, in conformance with FIS security requirements at no charge, until, in the determination of FIS, the Destructive Element has been eliminated. (4) Provider represents and warrants to FIS that neither the execution and delivery of the Agreement nor the other documents and instruments to be executed and delivered by Provider pursuant to the Agreement nor the consummation of the transactions contemplated by the Agreement will (a) violate any statute or law or any rule, regulation, order, writ, injunction or decree of any court or governmental authority, (b) require any action by Provider to obtain or give any authorization, consent, approval, exemption or other action by or notice to any court, administrative or governmental agency, instrumentality, commission, authority, board or body (or if so required, Provider has taken all such action and obtained all needed and necessary authorizations, consents, approvals, and exemptions), or (c) violate or conflict with, or constitute a default (or an event which, with notice or lapse of time, or both, would constitute a default) under, any term or provision of Provider's charter or bylaws or any contract, license, or legal restriction of any kind or character to which Provider is a party or by which Provider or any of its assets or properties may be bound or affected. (5) Provider represents and warrants that there is no action, suit, arbitration proceeding, investigation or inquiry pending or threatened against Provider, its business or any of its assets, nor does Provider know, or have grounds to know, of any basis for any such proceedings, investigations or inquiries, that would affect its ability to perform its obligations under the Agreement. (6) Provider represents and warrants that during the term of the Agreement Provider will maintain an adequate and trained staff of employees and adequate and proper facilities, resources and systems in order to perform the Services and otherwise provide the Products to FIS at agreed levels pursuant to the Agreement. i. DEFINITIONS. (1) A "Destructive Element" is any computer code or other technological device which (i) is intentionally designed to disrupt, disable, harm or otherwise impede in any manner, including aesthetical disruptions or distortions, the operation of a Product, or any other associated software, firmware, hardware, computer system or network (sometimes referred to as "viruses" or "worms"), (ii) would disable a Product or impair in any way its operation based on the elapsing of a period of time, exceeding an authorized number of copies, advancement to a particular date or other numeral (sometimes referred to as "time bombs", "time locks", or "drop dead" devices), (iii) would permit Provider or any Subcontractor to access a Product to cause such disablement or impairment (sometimes referred to as "traps", "access codes" or "trap door" devices), or (iv) contains any other similar harmful, malicious or hidden procedures, routines or mechanisms which would cause a Product or any other associated software, firmware, hardware, computer system or network to cease functioning or damage or corrupt data, storage media, programs, equipment or communications or otherwise interfere with operations. (2) A “Force Maieure Event" is any force majeure event condition causing a performance delay to be excused under the Agreement. PART 11. OWNERSHIP. a. WORKS FOR HIRE. Inventions and works that Provider may develop for FIS pursuant to a specific SOW shall be considered works made for hire by Provider and upon creation shall be owned exclusively by FIS. To the extent that such inventions or works may not be considered works made for hire, Provider assigns, without the necessity of further consideration, all of its right, title and interest to FIS, and FIS shall be entitled to hold same in its own name on all applicable patents, registrations and/or copyrights. b. LICENSE. To the extent that any preexisting rights are embodied or reflected in the Services, inventions or work related to the Services or inventions, Provider grants to FIS an irrevocable, perpetual, non-exclusive, world-wide, royalty-free right and license to: (i) use, execute, reproduce, display, perform, distribute copies of and prepare l*rocurcment Contract Supplement Pg 8 of 9 derivative works based upon such preexisting rights; and (ii) authorize others on FIS's behalf to do any or all of the foregoing. PART 12. DISPUTE RESOLUTION AND APPLICABLE LAW. Any dispute, difference, controversy or claim arising out of or relating to the Agreement shall be settled by binding arbitration before a single arbitrator in Jacksonville, Florida in accordance with the Commercial Arbitration Rules (including Procedures for Large. Complex Commercial Disputes) of the American Arbitration Association. Judgment on any resulting award may be entered into by any court having jurisdiction over the parties or their respective property. The arbitrator shall decide any issues submitted in accordance with the provisions and commercial purposes of the Agreement, and shall not have the power to award damages in excess of the limitations set forth in, or excluded by. the Agreement. The Agreement shall be governed by the laws of the State of Florida, without regard to internal principles relating to conflict of laws, and subject to the arbitration requirement set forth above, venue for any litigation arising out of or otherwise relating to the Agreement shall be limited exclusively to state and federal courts of competent jurisdiction located in Duval County, Florida. PART 13. AMENDMENTS; AUTHORIZED REPRESENTATIVES. This Supplement, and any agreement subject to this Supplement, may be modified only by a written instrument signed by duly authorized representatives of both parties, which in the case of FIS or an FIS Affiliate must be an officer at the level of senior vice president, executive vice president or president. PART 14 WEB-BASED PROVISIONS AND PASSIVE CONTRACTS. The effectiveness of the Agreement shall not be conditioned upon FIS becoming bound by (i) a reference in the Agreement to one or more documents maintained by Provider and made available to FIS at a Web page, by email distribution or in any other manner or (ii) a "click-through", "shrink wrap" or similar mechanism presented by Provider (whether in the past, present or future) involving the use of an action other than actual signature or electronic signature (as recognized by applicable law) to cause agreement to terms and conditions presented by Provider. The parties understand and agree that any such documents, terms and conditions shall be only for informational purposes or to set forth obligations of or rights granted by the Provider or its Affiiates, and neither FIS nor any FIS Affiliate shall be bound by any contractual obligation that might otherwise arise from any such reference or mechanism, whether in connection with the subject matter of the Agreement or otherwise. IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the duly authorized officer or representative of each party has signed this Procurement Contract Supplement as a legally binding obligation of the party. FIDELITY INFORMATION SERVICES, LLC CYBER-ARK SOFTWARE INC Name (printed) Chud (Udi) MokadV  President & CEO Title Date Signed -J By: Date Signed I*rociirenicnt Contract Supplement I'g 9 or 9 Exhibit 1 to Procurement Contract Supplement INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS TYPES & MINIMUM AMOUNTS OF INSURANCE COVERAGE Commercial General Liability Insurance: including Premises & Operations, Products/Completed Operations, Contractual, Broad Form Property Damage, and Personal Injury with a combined single limit of at least One Million Dollars ($1,000,000) per occurrence and Two Million Dollars ($2,000,000) general aggregate. Business Automobile Liability Insurance: for all vehicles to be used in connection with the Agreement, with a combined single limit of at least One Million Dollars (S1.000,000) each accident Worker's Compensation: with Alternate Employer Endorsement and including at least One Million Dollars ($1,000,000) Employers Liability coverage. Umbrella (Excess) Liability Insurance: coverage in an amount of at least five million ($5,000,000) per occurrence. Property Insurance: against all risks of physical loss or damage to any property of FIS in the care, custody, or control of Provider Professional Liability: in an amount of at least Five Million Dollars ($5,000,000) including coverage for Network Security Liability and Privacy Liability. Commercial Crime: including employee Dishonesty coverage in the amount of at least One Million Dollars (51,000,000). OTHER INSURANCE OBLIGATIONS (1) Prior to executing the Agreement and within ten (10) days of each subsequent policy renewal, Provider shall provide FIS with certificates of insurance evidencing that the coverage and policy endorsements required under the Agreement are maintained in force with insurance companies that have A.M. Best ratings of at least A- (VIII). (2) Provider or its insurers shall provide thirty (30) days written notice to FIS prior to cancellation or material change of any such policy. (3) Except with respect to the gross negligence of FIS. Provider’s policies will be primary and non-contributing with respect to any other insurance or self-insurance which may be maintained by FIS. (4) FIS shall be named as an additional insured under the Commercial General Liability, Automobile Liability, Umbrella and Professional Liability policies, as well as a Loss Payee under the Crime policy described above. (5) Provider will be responsible to ensure that any Subcontractors maintain in force coverage as outlined in this Exhibit, or that coverage is extended under Provider's policies. (6) The carrying of the above-described coverage shall in no way be interpreted as relieving Provider of any other responsibility or liability under the Agreement or any applicable law, statute, regulation or order. Exhibit 2 to Procurement Contract Supplement Form of PARTIAL ASSIGNMENT AND RELEASE OF AGREEMENT 1. Introduction. By this Partial Assignment and Release of Agreement ("Assignment"), [legal name of FIS] ("Assignor”) is assigning to [legal name of assignee] ("Assignee") certain of Assignor's obligations, liabilities, benefits, rights and privileges relating to or arising under the attached [title of Agreement, which is to be attached] (“Contract"). 2. Assignment. Assignor indefeasibly assigns, transfers, sets over, and conveys to Assignee all of Assignor's estate, right, title, and interest in all of the obligations, liabilities, benefits, rights, and privileges relating to or arising under the Contract associated with the Assignee as of {effective date of Assignment) (the "Effective Date"). Assignor represents and warrants to Assignee that as of the Effective Date there have been no amendments or modifications to or waivers of the Contract which have not been supplied and identified by the Assignor to the Assignee and that the form and content of the Contract is as supplied and identified by Assignor to Assignee. 3. Acceptance of Assignment Assignee accepts such assignment and agrees to be liable for any obligations or liabilities that arise or accrue under the Contract relating to Assignee as of the Effective Date. 3. Release. In consideration of the foregoing, Provider, its predecessors, successors, parents, direct subsidiaries, indirect subsidiaries, affiliates, assigns, heirs, agents, and attorneys hereby remise, release and forever discharge Assignor, and all its predecessors, successors, parents, direct subsidiaries, indirect subsidiaries, affiliates, and their assigns, agents, directors, officers, employees, heirs, personal representatives, and shareholders from and against all actions, causes of action, claims, suits, debts, damages, judgments, liabilities, demands and controversies whatsoever, whether matured or unmatured, whether at law or in equity, whether before a local, state or federal court or state or federal administrative agency, commission or arbitration administrator, and whether now known or unknown, liquidated or unliquidated, that Provider now has or may have had, or thereafter claims to have, regarding the issues arising out of or directly or indirectly related to the Contract in respect to the Assignee, on behalf of itself, or any other person or entity, at any time prior to and including the Effective Date. Provider warrants and agrees that it has neither assigned, pledged, hypothecated, nor otherwise divested itself or encumbered any part of the claims being released hereby; that no other person or entity has any interest in or ownership of the claims covered by this Assignment, and that Provider will indemnify, defend, and hold Assignor harmless from and against any of all of any part of the claims so assigned, pledged, hypothecated, divested or encumbered. 4. No Admission. It is understood and agreed among Provider. Assignor and Assignee that this Assignment is a compromise and shall never be construed as an admission of liability, wrongdoing or responsibility on the part of any party, or on the part of any party's predecessors, successors, assigns, agents, parents, subsidiaries, affiliates, officers, directors, employees, heirs, personal representatives, or shareholders. Rather, each party expressly denies any such liability, wrongdoing or responsibility. Moreover, neither the release set forth herein nor a party's execution and performance of this Assignment shall be construed by any person or in any court, agency or tribunal whatsoever as a present or past admission of liability, wrongdoing or responsibility. 5. Confidentiality. The parties agree that this Assignment and its terms are and shall be kept confidential by the parties. Except to the extent necessary to enforce this Assignment or to the extent that either of the parties reasonably believes it is required by law to disclose certain of the terms of this Assignment to its stockholders, or in the filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, a state or federal regulatory body; or to the extent that any of the parties is required to disclose the terms of its individual settlement to the taxing authorities, preparers, or others with respect to tax matters; or to the extent required by subpoena or other order of a court or government body of competent jurisdiction or at the request of the FCC; the terms and conditions of this Assignment, including the amounts of any payment shall remain confidential and shall not be disclosed. To the extent required by subpoena or other written order, rule, or regulation of a court or government body of competent jurisdiction, the party being compelled to provide the information will notify the other parties within five (5) business days of receipt of the subpoena or written order. Subject to the same exceptions set forth above, the parties, and their counsel, agree that they will not comment on the substance or terms of this Assignment to any person or entity unless written consent is given by the other, except to the effect that any dispute arising from the Contract was resolved amicably, that the parties and their counsel are bound by the limitations of this Assignment, and as set forth in this paragraph. Notwithstanding the foregoing, this Assignment and its terms may be disclosed to any person who releases claims or against whom claims are released under this Assignment. 6. Miscellaneous. a) Each party agrees to bear its own attorneys* fees and costs. b) The parties represent and warrant that each (i) is duly incorporated and/or organized and is in good standing under the laws of the jurisdiction set forth in the preamble above, (ii) has the right and authority to enter into, execute and deliver this Assignment as the binding agreement of such party, to agree to the terms and conditions set forth herein, and to receive payments or credits in settlement of any claims under the Contract; and (iii) that neither of the parties has disposed of any of the claims. c) The parties agree that any provision of this Assignment that is prohibited or unenforceable in any jurisdiction shall, as to such jurisdiction, be rendered ineffective to the extent of such prohibition or unenforceability, without invalidating the remaining provisions hereof or affecting the validity or enforceability of such provision in any other jurisdiction. d) The Assignment, including all matters of construction, validity and performance shall be governed by, and construed in accordance with, the laws of the State of Florida without giving effect to the choice of law or conflicts of law provisions thereof. e) The parties agree to cooperate fully, to execute any and all supplementary documents and to take all additional actions that may be necessary or appropriate to give full force and effect to the terms and intent of this Assignment, including withdrawing with prejudice the claims from the court, arbitrators, regulatory or other governmental body before which such claims were pending. f) This Assignment may be executed in counterparts, each of which shall be deemed an original, but all of which together shall constitute one and the same instrument. g) This Assignment reflects the entire agreement and understanding between the parties with respect to the settlement contemplated herein, supersedes all prior or contemporaneous agreements, arrangements, understandings, communications, representations or warranties, both oral and written, related to the Contract. This Assignment may be modified or waived, in whole or in part, only by a written document signed by all parties. h) No failure or delay by either party in exercising any right, power, or privilege under this Assignment shall operate as a waiver thereof, nor shall any single or partial exercise thereof preclude any other or further exercise of any right, power or privilege hereunder. i) Upon the Effective Date, this Assignment shall be binding on the parties and their respective successors and permitted assigns. j) The parties each covenant and agree to execute, to acknowledge and to deliver, at their own expense, such other instruments and to take such other actions as may be reasonably required to effectuate this Assignment whenever and so often as reasonably required so to do by the parties hereto, their successors and assigns. k) Failure by any party to enforce at any time any of the terms and conditions of this Assignment shall not be considered a waiver of that party's right to enforce such terms and conditions. No waiver by any party of any of its rights under this Assignment shall be valid unless in writing signed by such party, and no waiver of a breach of any provision shall constitute a waiver of any future breach of such provision or a breach of any other provision. l) This Assignment does not constitute the assumption of the Contract as that term is used under applicable bankruptcy law. IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the undersigned have caused this Assignment to be executed as of the dates written below. [full legal name of each party, with authorized signature, name/title of signatory and signature date] Exhibit 2 - Form of Partial Assignment and Release of Agreement Pg 2of2

data.text: S worldpay worldpay.com Worldpay (UK) Limited The Walbrook Building 25 Walbrook London EC4N 8AF Jonathan Gad Cymulate Limited David Saharov 19, Rishon Letzion Israel 7570723 05 January 2018 Dear Jonathan letter of Intent: Cymulate PoC As you are aware, Cymulate Limited ("Cymulate”) and Worldpay (UK) Limited ("Worldpay") have commenced discussions with respect to the possible provision by Cymulate to Worldpay of an automated pen testing capability, the PoC will deliver the pen testing capability and corresponding reports for both email and web modules (the "Service"). Whilst those discussions are continuing, although it is the intention of the parties to enter a definitive separate agreement setting out the terms and conditions that would apply to the Service should it proceed (the "Agreement"), the parties hereby agree to establish a "proof of concept" ("POC") arrangement under which testing of the Service and Its associated performance levels may commence. Parti: Joint Activities The purposes of the POC tests are to determine whether the Service is capable of providing an effective cloud based automated pen testing capability, during the tests only the web and email modules of the product will be used. Worldpay will provide a single virtual IP host in its test wDesk environment with which to install the initial agent and a Worldpay mailbox, this agent is only required for the initial installation and to configure elements to converse with the cloud portal The Virtual Machine (VM) utilized for this purpose will be decommissioned and erased after the POC. This will then be used to facilitate the Cloud service which will deliver and execute the tests, the POC takes approximately 40 minutes to run once the host has been provisioned and Cymulate will be present to assist in the exercise and tailor the execution to drive the greatest visibility and benefit for Worldpay. The POC will deliver a report on both web and email attacks that the Worldpay environment are currently susceptible to, generate a list of recommended remediation actions which will be reviewed by Worldpay's Cyber Security team and an action plan put in place to correct. This POC is an urgent requirement that needs completing within the next 7 days depending on Cymulate's availability which has already been reserved on standby. The success of the POC will be determined by the granularity of attack vectors identified in the report, the usability of the Graphical User Interface (GUI) and effectiveness of the remediation plans created by the solution, ultimately success is determined in Worldpay's sole discretion. Part 2: Binding Provisions 1. Confidentiality A J 6/ y616473890 During the course of discussions relating to the Service, the parties may each disclose to the other information related to their businesses which is clearly marked or should reasonably be recognized as confidential ("Confidential information"). Each party agrees to protect the Confidential Information of the other in the same manner as it would protect its own confidential information of like kind, but in no event using less than a reasonable standard of care. For purposes of this Letter of Intent, Confidential Information will Include information provided by one party to the other prior to the date of this Letter of Intent in regards to the POC, but will not Include Information that was independently developed by the receiving party without use of or access to information provided by the other (disclosing) party, information that was received from a third party without obligation to keep the information confidential, or information that becomes part of the public domain through no breach of this provision. If either party receives a court or administrative order requiring it to disclose the Confidential Information of the other party, it will to the extent permitted, first notify the disclosing party, and then will be entitled to comply with such order. Each party will return or destroy the other party's Confidential Information in its possession upon request by the other party, unless otherwise allowed to retain such Confidential Information. Each party may retain copies of the other party's Confidential Information required for compliance with its recordkeeping or quality assurance requirements (subject to the terms of this Letter of Intent). 2. Intellectual Property Both parties are aware that each of them will bring various assets and intellectual property rights during the discussions outlined in this Letter of Intent and that during the discussions contemplated hereunder, both parties may use such assets and intellectual property rights for the purposes set out In this Letter of Intent only. Each party acknowledges that they will not have or obtain rights in the other party's proprietary products, materials, technologies or methodologies, or intellectual property rights which may be used as contemplated by this Letter of Intent, unless pursuant to a separate written agreement on terms to be agreed. Worldpay clearly understands and agrees that Cymulate neither by this Letter of Intent, transfers or assigns any intellectual property rights to Worldpay in any of its Services and nor are any intellectual property rights transferred or assigned in relation to any data provided/retrieved as result from the POC to Worldpay. 3. Data Protection and Information Security For the purposes of this Letter of Intent, (i.e. the services performed by Cymulate in relation to the POC, Cymulate will be a Data Processor of any Personal Data provided to Cymulate by Worldpay hereunder, and Worldpay will be the Data Controller (in each case, as such terms are defined under the Data Protection Act 1998). The terms of Appendix 1 of this Letter of Intent will apply to the Data Processing activity to be undertaken by Cymulate. The terms of Appendix 2 of this Letter of Intent detail the provisions to be applied by Cymulate to ensure the security of Worldpay's data. 4. Nature of the Letter of Intent: The parties intend this Letter of Intent to be considered a non-exhaustive, non-binding agreement (except for the clauses of this Part 2) between the parties that summarizes the understandings to date and thus supersedes all communications, written or oral, between the parties in relation the transaction contemplated. This Letter of Intent does not contain all the terms and conditions of any Agreement to be concluded and does not require either party to sign any such an Agreement. Before the parties will commit to a business relationship regarding the Service, the Agreement must first be finalized and executed. 5. Costs and Liability Each party shall be responsible for all costs and expenses they Incur as a result of this Letter of Intent unless otherwise agreed in writing. In no event will either party be liable to the other (whether in contract, tort, negligence, strict liability in tort or by statute or otherwise) for any indirect, special, incidental, consequential, exemplary or punitive damages or for any form of damages other than direct damages. Worldpay's liability under this Letter of Intent shall be no more than £10,000. 6. Publicity Neither party shall, without securing the written consent of the other party, publicly announce the existence of this Letter of Intent or advertise or release any publicity concerning the commencement or contents of the discussions described in this Letter of Intent. 7. Term This Letter of Intent shall commence from the date last signed below and shall continue in full force and effect fora period of 4 weeks or the date of execution of the Agreement (whichever is the earlier). The term of this Letter of Intent may be extended for a further period by written agreement by both parties. Either party may terminate this Letter of Intent upon notice to the other. 8. Next Steps The parties agree to continue negotiations to further confirm the points where we believe we have potential agreement on the Agreement and to further address the discussion points identified above, with the goal of finalizing the specific terms of the Agreement and gaining the necessary internal management approvals prior to executing potential Agreement. Please acknowledge your acceptance of the contents of this letter, which shall be governed exclusively by the courts and laws of England by signing, dating and returning one copy to the undersigned. Yours sincerely For and on behalf of Worldpay (UK) Limited Signature: .  Name:  Date: <5Th'v ( Zc-lC Agreed and accepted on behalf of Cymulate Limited Signature: Name: C £«vt/1nZG. Date: <9 !64 j _ Cymulate LTD 516473890 Appendix 1 - Data Protection 1. All data (including Personal Data) provided by Worldpay directly or indirectly to Cymulate ("Worldpay Data") shall be and remain the property of Worldpay. Unless otherwise required by law, Cymulate shall, as soon as reasonably practicable, return or if Worldpay so elects, destroy (and in the case of destruction, certify that such destruction has taken place), all Worldpay Data upon any of the following: a. at Worldpay's request; b. the termination or expiration of this Letter of Intent (save where superseded by an Agreement); or c. when the Worldpay Data is no longer required by Cymulate for the provision of the Service. 2. Cymulate shall comply at all times with the Data Protection Legislation as applicable to the Data Processor and shall not perform any of its obligations under this Letter of Intent in such a way as to cause Worldpay to breach any of its applicable obligations under the relevant Data Protection Legislation when performing the POC. For the purposes of this Appendix, "Data Protection Legislation" means the provisions of Data Protection Act 1998, which relate to the protection of Individuals with regards to the processing of Personal Data to which a party is subject, and, where applicable, the guidance and code of practice issued by the Information Commissioner's Office from time to time, directions of any competent privacy Regulatory Authority, relevant regulatory guidance and codes of practice. 3. Cymulate shall not use any Worldpay Data for any purpose other than the rendering of the Service to World pay and shall not disclose the Worldpay Data to any third parties or commercially exploit the Worldpay Data. Cymulate shall and shall procure that its personnel shall not attempt to access or allow access to Worldpay Data to which they are not entitled or that is not required for the performance of the Services. 4. To the extent that Cymulate processes any Personal Data on behalf of Worldpay, Cymulate acknowledges that It is the Data Processor in relation to such data and shall and shall procure that its personnel shall: a. Process the Personal Data strictly in accordance with Instructions from Worldpay or the terms of this Letter of Intent unless otherwise agreed by the Parties in writing; b. immediately carry out any request from Worldpay requiring Cymulate to amend, transfer or delete the Personal Data or any part of the Personal Data; c. ensure that only its personnel engaged in the performance of the Service shall have access to the Personal Data and that all such personnel have undergone training in the Data Protection Legislation and in the care and handling of Personal Data; d. not process Personal Data in a public place or any location where such Personal Data may be viewed by others, including in waiting areas, on public transport or across unencrypted public networks; e. Process the Personal Data only to the extent, and in such manner, as is necessary for the provision of the Service or as is required by law or any regulatory authority; f. provide to Worldpay such information as may be reasonably requested in writing by Worldpay regarding what steps Cymulate has taken to comply with Its obligations under this Appendix 1; Cymulate LTD 615473890 g. notify Worldpay (and at the latest within two business days) of any queries relating to Personal Data processed on behalf of Worldpay from Data Subjects (as such term is defined under the Data Protection Act 1998), any information commissioner or any other Regulatory Authority, which Worldpay may decide to resolve at its discretion; h. at no additional cost, promptly provide such information to Worldpay as Worldpay may reasonably require to allow It to comply with the rights of the Data Subjects, including subject access rights, or with information notices or queries requested by a regulatory authority; i. obtain prior written consent from Worldpay In order to transfer the Personal Data to any sub¬ contractors or third parties for the provision of the Service; j. implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to safeguard against unauthorised Processing (including unauthorised access, use or disclosure) or unlawful Processing (including theft) of Personal Data and against accidental loss or destruction of, or damage to Personal Data; k. save for clause I. hereunder, not process or otherwise transfer any Personal Data outside the European Economic Area without Worldpay's express prior written consent and if such consent is provided, shall only process or otherwise transfer such Personal Data on terms that comply with applicable Data Protection Legislation (insofar as it relates to Worldpay as Data Controller), Including without limitation the eighth data protection principle set out in the Data Protection Act 1998. 5. Cymulate shall not appoint any subcontractors with respect to its performance of the services under this Letter of Intent. 6. If any Personal Data that is in the possession or control of Cymulate becomes lost, corrupted or rendered unusable for any reason, Cymulate shall promptly, or at least within two business days, both notify Worldpay and make all reasonable attempts to the extent technically possible to restore such Personal Data using its back up and/or disaster recovery procedures at no cost to Worldpay. 0/ Cymulate LTD 515473690 Appendix 2 - Information Security 1. Cymulate shall establish, Implement and regularly maintain security, processes and plans which shall ensure the confidentiality and security of the Confidential Information and any Worldpay Data in accordance with Good Industry Practice (meaning, the exercise of that degree of professionalism, skill, diligence, prudence and foresight which would reasonably and ordinarily be expected from a skilled and experienced person engaged in the same type of activity under the same or similar circumstances as set out under this Letter of Intent) and the requirements set out in Appendix 2A below (the "Information Security Requirements"). 2. Cymulate shall ensure that at all times it is operating in accordance with the terms of the Information Security Requirements. 3. Cymulate will provide Worldpay on written request with copies of the its security plan and will reasonably explain how this meets the Information Security Requirements. 4. In the provision of the Service, Cymulate will adopt and use good development and coding practices in line with Good Industry Practice. 5. Cymulate shall perform security tests of its systems ("Security Tests") in a manner and frequency expected in accordance with Good Industry Practice to ensure it is operating in accordance with the Information Security Requirements and will share the results of the Security Tests with Worldpay on request. 6. Upon any suspected or actual breach of any obligations or duties owed by Cymulate to Worldpay relating to information security, confidentiality, or Personal Data, including any suspected or actual non- compliance with the Information Security Requirements which impacts the security and/or confidentiality of Worldpay Confidential Information or Personal Data Cymulate will immediately remedy the breach and will promptly: a. notify Worldpay of the breach; b. implement any actions or remedial measures at its own cost which Worldpay considers necessary as a result of the breach; and c. provide Worldpay with evidence of the implementation of such remedial measures. Appendix 2A- Information Security Requirements 1. Cymulate will implement and operate: a. up to date anti-virus software; b. a patch management process, which ensures patches are appropriately tested and deployed to rectify security vulnerabilities in a reasonable timeframe; c. robust processes to ensure that access to Worldpay Data under Its control Is restricted to those Individuals who are explicitly authorised to access such data. Access shall be limited to those Cymulate LTD 7615473890 with a business need for such access and to those privileges needed to fulfil that need only, Access shall be assigned using unique logon credentials to ensure accountability Is maintained; d. strong authentication methods (two-factor authentication) for those of Its personnel who work remotely and for those with administrative privileges upon systems used to provide the services under this Letter of Intent; e. mechanisms to prevent the unauthorised removal of Worldpay Data from Cymulate's networks via technologies such as removable media devices, the internet, email or Instant messaging services; f. encryption technologies to protect Worldpay Data during any transmission and/or storage; g. encryption technologies upon portable devices such as laptops, PDAs and smartphones to the extent such devices are utilised in provision of the Services; h. physical and logical controls to mitigate the risk of unauthorised intrusion to Cymulate's premises, networks and systems; I. systems and software development processes to ensure that commonly known security flaws (such as those defined by the Open Web Application Security Project) are not Introduced Into systems used to supply the Service; j. robust processes to ensure that changes to the premises, networks, systems and software used to supply the Services are appropriately tested and Implemented to limit the potential of service degradation; and k. processes to continually monitor Its networks and systems for potential or actual security breaches. 2, Where all, or part of, the Service are provided using online services (l.e. accessible via the internet), Cymulate must ensure that adequate protection Is in place to mitigate the risk of Denial of Service threats. 3. Cymulate shall ensure that processes employed In the provision of the Service are staffed In such manner as to prevent conflicts of interest, fraud or error by invoking appropriate separation of duties.
