THIS SERVICES AGREEMENT S m3de C-n 19 December 2014 BETWEEN: (1) WORLDPAY (UK) LIMITED, a company incorporated in England with registered number 07316500, whose registered office is at The Walbrook Building, 25 Walbrook, London, EC4N 8AF (’’Worldpay"); and (2) DATAMATICS FINANCIAL SERVICES LIMITED a company incorporated in Indra with registered number U74140MH1982PLC02S446 whose registered office is at Plot No. B5; Part B Crosslane, MiDC, Andheri (Fast), Mumbai 400093, India (the "Supplier"). WHEREAS: (A) The Worldpay Group is a leading global payment processor and wishes to engage the Supplier to provide certain short-term Services (as defined below). (B) The Supplier has represented that it has specialist skill and expertise in relation to the provision of the Services of the type and nature required by Worldpay and its Group. (C) The Supplier has agreed to provide the Services to Worldpay and its Group on the terms and conditions of this Agreement. IT IS AGREED AS FOLLOWS: 1. INTERPRETATION 1.1 In this Agreement, unless the context otherwise requires, the following expressions have the following meanings: Agreement: means this Agreement, its schedules and any other document incorporated by reference that is signed by the authorised representatives of the parties and expressed to be part of the Agreement; Business Day(s): means any day from Monday to Friday on which banks are open for business in England; Charges: means the fees payable by Worldpay to the Supplier for the provision of the Services, as set out in Schedule 1; Confidential Information: means the existence and contents of this Agreement, any data and all secret and or confidential, commercial, financial, marketing, technical, know-how, trade secrets, employee or other Information relating to the Supplier or Worldpay m any form or medium whether disclosed orally, or in writing, before or after the date of this Agreement, together with any reproductions of such information -n any form or medium, or any part of such information disclosed by either Party to the other pursuant to this Agreement, including any information that by 'ts nature is confidential; Deliverables: means outputs or Materials the Supplier provides as part of the Services, as set out in Schedule 1; Effective Date: means the date of this Agreement; FCA: means the Financial Conduct Authority of the United Kingdom; Good Industry Practice: means the exercise of that degree of professionalism, skill, diligence, prudence and foresight wh'ch would reasonably and ordinarily be expected from a skilled and experienced person engaged in the same type of activity under the same or similar circumstances; Group / Group Company: means Worldpay and any holding company of Worldpay and any subsidiary of such holding company from time to time and for the purposes of this definition "holding company" and "subsidiary" shall have the meaning given to those terms m section 1159 and Schedule 6 of the Companies Act 2006; Insolvency Event: means in relation to either Party: (a) the Party becomes unable to pay its debts as they fall due, or the value of the Party's assets is less than the amount of its liabilities, taking into account its contingent and prospective liabilities; (b) a petition is presented, an order made or a resolution passed for the liquidation (otherwise than for the purposes of a solvent amalgamation or reconstruction), administration, bankruptcy or dissolution of the Party; (c) an administrative or other receiver, manager, trustee, liquidator, administrator or similar person or officer is appointed to the Party and/or over all or any part of the assets of the Parly; (d) the Party enters into or proposes any composition or arrangement concerning its debts with its creditors (or any class of its creditors) generally; or (e) anything equivalent to any of the events or circumstances stated in (a) to (d) inclusive occurs in any applicable 1 jurisdiction; Intellectual Property Rights: means (a) parents, inventions, designs, copyright and related rights, database rights, trade marks and related goodwill, trade names (whether registered or unregistered), know-how, trade secrets and rights to apply for registration; (b) proprietary rights in domain names, (c) applications, extensions and renewals in relation to any of these rights; and (d) all other rights of a similar nature or having an equivalent effect anywhere in the world (including the development, modification, or creation bf any software); Invention: means any Invention, idea, discovery, development, business method, formula, pattern, compilation, improvement or innovation made by the Supplier as a result of the provision of the Services, (including the development, modification, or creation of any software) whether or not patentable or capable of registration; Law: means all laws and regulations in force and applicable to a Party in respect of its rights and obligations under this Agreement, including any order of a court of competent Jurisdiction and the rules or directions of any Regulatory Authority; Losses: means liabilities, claims, proceedings, judgments, damages, demands, actions, costs, charges, expenses, penalties, fines and any other loss of whatever nature, Including court costs and reasonable legal fees; Material: means any document, methodology or process, Deliverable, data or other material In whatever form relating to the Services; Party: means each party to this Agreement; Personnel: means any person employed or otherwise engaged by the Supplier or its subcontractor(s) in connection with the provision of the Services (in each case, whether pursuant to an employment contract, contract for the provision of services or subcontract); Pre-Contractual Statements: has the meaning set out In clause 13.11; Regulatory Authority: means any governmental or regulatory authority, department, agency, commission, board, tribunal, crown corporation, or other law, rule or regulation-making entity that any of the Parties submit to or are subject to the jurisdiction of in respect of this Agreement, and any successor or replacement of any of the foregoing; Services: means the services set oct in Schedule 1 to this Agreement, or any other statement of work as agreed between the Parties from time to time; Term: means the duration of this Agreement as set out in clause 2, including any extensions agreed between the parties; Third Party Materials: means any materials forming part of the Works including any software, hardware, images or designs which are owned or controlled by a third party; Virus: means any software program or code intended to destroy, Interfere with, corrupt, or cause undesired effects on program files, data or other information, executable code cr application software macros, whether or not its operation Is immediate or delayed; Works: means all records, reports, documents, papers, drawings, designs, transparencies, photos, graphics, logos, typographical arrangements, software. Deliverables and all other materials m whatever form, including but not limited to hard copy and electronic form, prepared by the Supplier during the course of the provision of the Services; and Worldpay Equipment: means any equipment, facilities or software provided by Worldpay. In this Agreement: 1.2 the clause, schedule and paragraph headings are for convenience only and shall not affect the interpretation of this Agreement; 1.3 references to clauses are to clauses in the main body of this Agreement; 1.4 unless the context otherwise requires, words in the singular shall include the plural and in the plural include the singular; 1.5 any reference to a statute, statutory provision or subordinate legislation (legislation) (except where the context otherwise requires) (i) shall be deemed to include any bylaws, licences, statutory instruments, rules, regulations, orders, notices, directions, consents or permissions made under that legislation and (il) shall be construed as referring to any legislation which replaces, re-enacts, amends or consolidates such legislation (with or without modification) at any time; 1.6 unless the context otherwise requires, a reference to one gender shall include a 2 reference to the other genders; 1.7 a reference to writing or written includes faxes and e-maii; and 1.8 any phrase introduced by rhe expressions including, include, in particular or any similar expression shall be construed as illustrative and shall not limit the sense of the words preceding those terms. 2. TERM 2.1 The Agreement shall commence on the Effective Date and shall remain in force for a period of three (3) months ("Initial Term unless terminated earlier in accordance with the terms of clause 10 of this Agreement. 2.2 After the expiration of the Initial Term, this Agreement shall: (a) automatically be renewed until the first anniversary of the Effective Date; and subsequently (b) be renewed automatically for consecutive 12-month periods, unless the Agreement is terminated in accordance with the terms of clause 10 of this Agreement. 3. SERVICES 3.1 The Supplier agrees to provide the Services and the Deliverables in accordance with Schedule 1, subject to the terms of this Agreement. 3.2 The Supplier shall perform the Services in accordance with the provisions of Schedule 1 and any dates, schedules and/or deadlines specified for such performance therein. 3.3 Services and Deliverables will be subject to acceptance by Worldpay, in Worldpay's absolute discretion. 3.4 rhe Supplier shall comply with aft applicable Laws. 3.5 If Worldpay provides any Worldpay Equipment to the Supplier, the Supplier agrees that it has no legal or equitable claim to the Worldpay Equipment and agrees (0 to use it only for the provision of the Services, and (il) to be liable to Worldpay for any expenses, damages, claims and costs, including costs of repair, replacement and restoration arising out of or in connection with any damage (excluding fair wear and tear) or destruction of the Worldpay Equipment or facilities caused by it. 4. CHARGES AND PAYMENT 4.1 In consideration for the performance of the Services, upon acceptance by Worldpay the Supplier shall issue an invoice to Woridpay and Worldpay shall pay to the Supplier the Charges set out in Schedule 1. ,4.2 Each invoice shall quote this Agreement and Worldpay's purchase order number. Worldpay shall pay the Charges within sixty (60) days of receipt of a valid invoice. AH Charges shall be calculated and payments made in pounds sterling. 4.3 Worldpay may reasonably withhold payment of Charges it disputes in good faith. In such circumstances it will Inform the Supplier of the basis of the dispute and pay any portion of the Charges which are not in dispute. 4.4 Worldpay may set off any sums due from the Supplier to Worldpay (including any amounts that Supplier is obligated to pay to or credit to Worldpay) against any payment due from Worldpay to the Supplier. 4.5 If any payment falling due under this Agreement, that is not subject to o bona fide dispute remains unpaid for a period of sixty (60) days or more from the due dace of payment, interest will accrue on the relevant unpaid amount at a per annum rale of 2% above the base rate of the Royal Bank of Scotland PLC from time to time until payment is made in full. 4.6 The Supplier shall be solely responsible for all tax liabilities arising in respect of this Agreement (including those of all Personnel) and shall account to the appropriate authorities for all tax and national insurance or similar contributions payable in respect of the supply to Worldpay of Services. The Supplier shall indemnify Woridpay, its Group Companies, officers and/or directors against all Losses suffered or incurred by Worldpay, its Group Companies, officers and/or directors arising out of or in connection with such payments. 5. AUDIT AND PERSONNEL 5.1 On Worldpay's request, the Supplier will immediately make available to Worldpay any file, correspondence, document or Information relating to the performance of the Supplier's obligations under this Agreement or which Worldpay informs the Supplier is required. It is specifically understood that Audit will not cover Supplier's financial records. 3 5.2 The Supplier acknowledges that Worldpay and its Group Companies are subject to regulation by the FCA and other Regulatory Authorities in the countries in which the Group operates, including the FCA's guidelines on outsourcing where they apply to this Agreement. The Supplier will give the Group all assistance that it reasonably requires to comply with the requirements of its Regulatory Authorities and all legal requirements of the countries in which it operates, where applicable. 5.3 If Worldpay (acting reasonably) determines that a member of the' Personnel should be removed from the provision of the Services or denied access to any Group Company premises, systems and/or data, Worldpay will notify the Supplier in writing and the Supplier will immediately remove that person from the provision of the Services and will not permit that person to be involved subsequently in the provision of the Services or entitled to access such premises, systems and/or data. 5.4 The Supplier shall comply with Schedule 2 (Pro-Employment Screening) in relation to any of the Personnel who provide the Services from or at any of Worldpay'S offices or other facilities or who have access to Worldpay systems. 6. REPRESENTATIONS AND WARRANTIES 6.1 The Supplier represents and warrants that: (a) it has the requisite power and authority to enter into this Agreement and to carry out the obligations contemplated by this Agreement; (b) It will provide the Services at all times in an efficient, diligent and timely manner with promptness and diligence and in accordance with Good Industry Practice, and it will at all times act in good faith towards Worldpay; (c) it will comply with Worldpay's directions, codes of conduct, and/or policies, including its health and safety, Information security and data privacy policies, as notified in writing from time to time by Worldpay to the Supplier; (d) it has obtained and will during the Term obtain and comply with al! applicable licences and consents required to perform the Services; (e) the Deliverables will, where applicable, interoperate with each other and with Worldpay's IT systems, infrastructure, databases end applications as notified to the Supplier from tune to lime; ar.d (f) it will perform its responsibilities under the Agreement in a manner that does not infringe, or constitute an infringement or misappropriation of any of Worldpay’s or of third party Intellectual Property Rights. 6.2 All warranties and representations shall, unless otherwise expressly stated, continue in full force and effect during the Term and shall survive Termination. 7. INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY RIGHTS 7.1 All Intellectual Property Rights in existence before the Effective Date shall be retained by the parties (“Pre-Existing IPRs-’). 7.2 The Supplier hereby assigns to Worldpay all existing and future Intellectual Property Rights in the Works and the inventions and all Materials embodying these rights to the fullest extent permitted by law (the “New IPRs’1), The Supplier confirms that save as may be required for the purpose of providing the Services, it has no right in or entitlement to use the New IPRs. 7.3 Tne Supplier undertakes: (a) upon request by Worldpay and in any event on the termination of this Agreement, promptly to deliver to Worldpay all correspondence, documents, papers and records on all media recording or relating to any part of the Works and or the Inventions and the process of their creation which are in its possession, custody or power; (b) to deliver to Worldpay the source-codes of any software that It has created, developed or modified in the course of providing the Services within five (5) days of Worldpay's request to do so; and (c) to do all acts necessary to confirm that absolute title In all Intellectual Property Rights in the Works and or the Inventions has passed, or will pass, to Worldpay, including registration in the name of Worldpay. 7.4 The Supplier shall indemnify Worldpay, its Group Companies, officers and/or directors against all Losses suffered or incurred by Worldpay, its Group Companies, officers and/or directors arising out of or in connection with any claim that the New IPRs, and/or the Works and/or the Inventions infringe the Intellectual Property Rights of a 4 third party. 7.5 The Supplier waives, and shall procure that all Personnel shall waive, any moral rights in the Nev, IPRs and/or the Works and/or the Inventions, to which it and/or the Personnel is now or may at any future time be entitled under Chapter IV of the Copyright Designs and Patents Act 1988 or any similar provisions of law in any jurisdiction. 7.6 The Supplier hereby grants to Worldpay and its Group Companies a perpetual, irrevocable, worldwide, royalty-free, sub¬ licensable licence to access, use, modify and copy the Supplier's Pre-Existing IPRs solely for the purposes of receiving the Services, and/or using the Works, Inventions and/or Matenals. 7.7 Worldpay hereby grants to the Supplier, for the term of this Agreement, a limited, non- 8.4 exclus ve, revocable, non-sublicensable licence to use Worldpay’s Pre-Existing IPRs solely for the purposes of providing the Services. 7.8 To the extent that any of the Works and or the Inventions contain Third Party Materials the Supplier shall: (a) disclose the existence of such Third Party Materials to Worldpay; and (b) obtain such licences or other consents as are required to permit the use of such Third Party Materials by Worldpay in order for Worldpay to enjoy the full benefit of its rights under this Agreement. 8. CONFIDENTIALITY 8.5 8.1 Each Party will, and each will procure that its personnel will keep confidential all Confidential Information of, or concerning, the other's Confidential Information received 8.6 by it. 8.2 Clause 8.1 does not apply to information: (a) that is published or otherwise generally becomes available to the public, except as a result of a breach of this Agreement; g (b) to the extent made available to a Party other than under any obligation of 9.1 confidentiality in respect of that information; (c) to the extent required to be disclosed by any Law making body, provided that the disclosing Party notifies the other, to the extent legally permissible, of the information to be disclosed as early as reasonably practicable before the disclosure and takes ail reasonable action to avoid or limit the disclosure; or (d) that 'S already known by the receiving Party without any obligation of confidence. Clause 8.1 will not restrict the sharing of any Confidential Information by the receiving Party to its directors, employees, professional advisors or sub-contractors who need to know it to provide the Services and/or to manage the relationship between the Parties, provided that such persons use it solely for such purpose and are under an obligation to the receiving Party to keep such information confidential. Other than as expressly permitted under this Agreement, un termination of this Agreement for whatever reason, each Party will immediately cease to use any Confidential Information of the other and will return on written demand or, at its election, destroy or, so far as is reasonably practicable, permanently erase ail copies of that Confidential Information in its possession or control, save that a Party will be permitted to retain such part of that Confidential information only for the purposes of, and for so long as required by, any Law or its legitimate internal compliance requirements. Any obligation to destroy or permanently erase Confidential Information shall not be applicable to Confidential Information that forms part of an electronic back-up system which is not immediately retrievable as part of day-to-day business. The Suppjier shall ensure that all Personnel comply With this clause 8 and confirms that it is responsible and liable for any breach of this clause 8 by any Personnel. The Supplier shall indemnify Worldpay, its Group Companies, officers and/or directors against all Losses suffered or incurred by Worldpay, its Group Companies, officers and/or directors arising out of or in connection with the Supplier's breach of this clause 8. BRIBERY ACT The Supplier warrants and represents that It and its Personnel shall comply with any applicable Law in force from time to time regarding bribery, fraudulent acts and/or any other corrupt practice including without limitation: 5 (a) the Bribery Act 2010; and (b) the Anti-Terrorism, Crime and Security Act 2001 together, the "Anti-Bribery Law". 9.2 The Supplier shall indemnify Worldpay, its Group Companies, officers and/or directors against all Losses suffered or incurred by Wortdpay, its Group Companies, officers and/or directors arising out of or in connection the Supplier’s breach of this clause 9. 10. TERMINATION 10.1 Worldpay may (without prejudice to its other rights or remedies) terminate this Agreement with immediate effect by written notice to the Supplier: (a) if the Supplier commits a material breach of this Agreement; or (b) if an Insolvency Event occurs in relation to the Supplier; or (c) at any time in the Initial Term. 10.2 Woridpay may terminate this Agreement for convenience at any time by giving two (2) weeks' prior notice In writing, and this Agreement shall terminate at the expiry of such notice. 10.3 Upon termination or expiry of this Agreement the Supplier shall transfer all data, works-in-progress and Deliverables to Worldpay or its designated third party. 10.4 Upon termination of this Agreement all rights and obligations of any Party will cease to have effect Immediately, save that the clauses and paragraphs and Schedules which expressly or by implication have effect after termination will continue to be enforceable notwithstanding such termination (including Clauses 4, 6 to 8, 10, 11, 13 and 14); and termination will not affect accrued rights, obligations and liabilities of any Party under this Agreement as at the date of termination. 11. LIMITATIONS OF LIABILITY 11.1 Nothing in this Agreement shall operate so as to exclude or limit the liability of either Party to the other for: (a) death or personal injury arising out of negligence or fraud; (b) any liability arising in connection with Clauses 7.4 (1PR Indemnity), 8.6 (Confidentiality Indemnity), and 9.3 (Bribery Act Indemnity); or (c) any other liability which cannot be excluded or limited by law. 11.2 Subject to Clause 11.1 and 11.4. the total aggregate liability of Worldpav to the Supplier under o' in connection with this Agreement indud ng liability for breach of contract, misrepresentation (whether tortious or statutory), tort (including, but not limited to, negligence), breach of statutory duty or otherwise, shall not exceed the total Charges paid to the Supplier under this Agreement 11.3 Subject to Clauses 11.1 and 11.4, the Supplier’s total aggregate liability to Worldpay under or in connection with tins Agreement including liability for breach of contract, misrepresentation (whether tortious or statutory), tort (including, but not limited to, negligence), breach of statutory duty or otherwise, shall not exceed the total Charges paid o' payable under this Agreement. 11.4 Save where specifically set out otherwise in this Agreement, neither Party shall be liable, whether in tort (including for negligence or breach of statutory duty), contract, misrepresentation or otherwise for any special, indirect or consequential losses or damage (whether such losses or damage are foreseen, foreseeable, known or otherwise). 12. ANTI-VIRUS 12.1 The Supplier shall ensure that no Virus or other disabling code is introduced into the Services, the Deliverables or Worldpay's information technology environment. 12.2 The Supplier shall immediately notify Worldpay upon the discovery of any such introduction" of the Virus and take all necessary remedial action to eliminate the Virus from the affected item and mitigate any loss of operational efficiency or data. 13. MISCELLANEOUS 13.1 No Partnership of Agency - Nothing in this Agreement shall be deemed to constitute a partnership, or create a relationship of principal and agent for any purpose between the Parties. 13.2 Variation - No variation of this Agreement will be effective unless made in writing, signed by or on behalf of the duly authorised signatories and expressed to be such a variation In accordance with this clause 13.2. 13.3 Group Company Loss - In the event of any breach of this Agreement by the Supplier 6 which results in any loss, damage, costs o' expense ("Loss") being suffered by a member of the Group (other than Worldpay) that Loss wdl be treated as if it had been suffered by Worldpay, shall be deemed to be the Loss of Worldpay, and Worldpav will be able to recover such Loss from the Supplier despite the fact that it was not suffered by Worldpay directly. Any member of the Group may enforce the terms of this Agreement under the Contracts (Rights of Third Parties) Act 1999 but no other person who is not a Party to this Agreement may enforce any of its provisions under the Contracts (Rights of Third Parties) Act 1999. 13.4 Severance - If any provision of this Agreement is held by any court or administrative body of competent jurisdiction to be illegal, invalid or unenforceable the legality, validity and enforceability of the remainder of this Agreement will not be affected. 13.5 Notices - Any notice required under this Agreement will be in writing, to the parties' respective addresses appearing at the head of this Agreement, or Such other address as the parties may advise at a later date. A notice will be deemed received if: (a) delivered personally, at the time of delivery to the receiving Party; (b) delivered by post within the united Kingdom, two (2) Business Days after posting (c) delivered by post by air mail to a destination outside of the United Kingdom, seven (7) Business Days after posting; or (d) (subject to clause 13.6) sent by email, on the day on which the notice is sent, provided no repoit of non-delivery is received by the sender. If any notice would, when made in accordance with the above, be deemed to be given or made either on a non-Business Day or after 17:00 on a Business Day, such Notice will be deemed to be given or made at 09:00 on the next Business Day. 13.6 No Notice of claim or termination by email - Neither Party may give notice to another Party to terminate this Agreement or to bring a claim in respect of this Agreement by email. 13.7 Waiver - No failure or delay on the part of either Party in enforcing against the other Party any term or condition of this Agreement will be construed as a waiver or release of that right or any other right or remedy, nor will any single or partial exercise of such rights preclude or restrict the further exercise of such rights. 13.8 Counterparts - This Agreement may be executed and delivered in any number of counterparts, each of which Is an original and which, together, have the same effect as if each Party nad signed the same document. 13.9 Assignment - The Supplier shall not assign or sub-contract its obligations under this Agreement to any third party without the prior written consent of Worldpay. Worldpay may at any time assign, transfer, novate or subcontract any or all of its rights and obligations under this Agreement to any Group company or any third party. 13.10 Continuing obligations - Where the Supplier has sub-contracted any of the Services, the Supplier will remain liable to Worldpay for the acts or omissions of its subcontractors. 13.11 Entire Agreement - This Agreement constitutes the whole agreement between the parties, and replaces and extinguishes all previous agreements, undertakings, or collateral contracts of any nature made by the parties, whether oral or written, m relation to its subject matter. Each Party acknowledges that, in entering into this Agreement, it has not relied on, and shall have no right or remedy in respect of, any statement, representation, assurance or warranty (whether made negligently or Innocently) (together, “Pre-Contractual Statements"), other than as expressly set out in this Agreement and hereby waives all rights and remedies which might otherwise be available to it in relation to Such Pre- Contractual Statements. Nothing m this Clause shall limit or exclude any liability for fraud. 13.12 Publicity - The Supplier shall not make any announcement regarding the existence of this agreerrent, or the fact that it is working with Worldpay, to any third party without the prior written consent of Worldpay. The Supplier shall have no right to use the Worldpay name or any of its brand names, logos or trademarks without the prior written consent of Woridpay. 13.13 Force Majeure - Neither party shall be liable to the other for any delay or non¬ performance of Its obligations under this Agreement arising from events or circumstances beyond Its reasonable control Including, without limitation, any of the "Acts of God" i.e. natural calamities, governmental act, war, fire, flood, explosion, civil commotions or insurrections or terrorist activities, and Worldpay agrees to extend the timing for provision of the Services in such circumstances, always provided that 7 the Supplier has used reasonable endeavours to mitigate the effect of such events and to carry out Its obligations under this Agreement in any other way that is reasonably practicable. 14. GOVERNING LAW AND JURISDICTION 14.1 This Agreement and any disputes or claims arising out of or m connection with it or its interpretation shall be governed by the laws of England and Wales. 1-4.2 The parties irrevocably agree that the courts of England and Wales have exclusive jurisdiction to settle any dispute or claim that arises out of or in connection with this Agreement, its subject matter or formation (including non-contractual disputes or claims). AS WITNESS whereof the parties hereto have caused this Agreement to be signed by their duly authorised representatives as of the day and year first written above Signature: For and on behalf of Datamatics Financial Services Limited: Mv^LX.C-'vY-'U Name/Tilie: Haren Jawahram, Chief Executive Officer Date: 19 Dec 2014 8 SCHEDULE 1 PART A - DESCRIPTION SERVICES/DELIVERABLES Scope & Terms of Agreement 1. Project Scope: The Supplier will provide secondary and primary research services to Worldpay as per Worldpay's specifications or instructions from t.me to time. The data requested shall be obtained, assimilated, validated and updated via intensive secondary or primary research, web validation or using Worldpay’s internal databases/resources as directed by Worldpay. 2. Input Data: The scope of work outlined in this Schedule is only Indicative and the Supplier acknowledges the scope of the projects will vary depending on the research requirements of Worldpay. The Supplier with provide FTE (Full Time Researchers) to work on a variety of projects as per the research requirements of Worldpay. To ensure ease of co-ordination for Worldpay, the Supplier will allocate a single point of contact to Worldpay. The FTE will be managed by the Supplier's senior research manager and the Supplier will ensure that the FTE's work will also be monitored by the Supplier's quality auditor co ensure the deliverables are as per Worldpay's expectations. The mam point of contact al Worldpay will be the Market Intelligence Manager. The FTE wiif need to conduct secondary research, data collation et ai with a focus on uncovering contacts, company information, industry data, ready data, report, intelligence sources, etc. For the purposes of this Agreement, it is specifically understood that the data provided Dy the Supplier will depend on information available in public domain and applicable usage policy applicable thereto. In addition to dally coordination, the Supplier will have a weekly teleconference with the Market Intelligence Manager at Worldpay to ensure that the research expectations are being met and to ensure a smooth flow of feedback to the Supplier and subsequent implementation in the provision of Services. The research methodology employed will be secondary research, web validation, quality review, email deliverability checking Worldpay's internal databases/resources. Telephone research can be used as directed by Worldpay. Project Planning & Specifications 1. Project Planning: On receipt of Worldpay's instructions , the Supplier shall initiate the project Within 24 hours of receipt of the project instructions. This timeframe will allow the Supplier to: • Identify and allocate suitable resources for Worldpay's project. • Provide project specific training to member of the Supplier's team which will be specific to Worldpay's requirement, and also for setting up the entire process. 2. Conversion Rate: The Supplier shall put all efforts to procure the specified data requested by Worldpay. However, the production output depends on the availability and existence of the contacts' information. The deliverables is of Business to Business nature and the parties hereto acknowledge that the quality of the deliverables is defined on the basis of Its existing status at the time when data was processed or information extracted and Is susceptible to Internal changes taking place at the end of data subject e.g. transfers, promotions, attritions, resignations etc.. Turn Around Time The parties mutually agree on the turnaround time for each project. 9 PART B - SERVICES/DELIVERABLES CHARGES The FTE will be required to work on varied projects including Business to Business prospect database building, updating, enriching, appending, augmenting, online data collation as requested, data entry, mining the members (and their contact details) of trade groups on business social networking sites and should have the relevant skills to carry out these tasks to the required standard, FTE charges are: FTE Resource Cost Per FTE in GBP Per Month if Total no. of FTE are 1-5 Cost Per FTE in GBP Per Month if Total no. of FTE are more than 5
Secondary Researcher 780 750
FTE Resource Cost Per FTE in GBP Per Month

*The above Phone researcher rates are valid for ail English Speaking and English prevalent countries and non-MENA (Middle East North Africa) countries. Note: An FTE Is defined as a Full Time Employee working 8 hours daily, 5 days a week barring the federal and employee holidays. The above cost is all inclusive and covers the following: • All manpower salaries and associated costs • Technology infrastructure costs ■ Datamatics management time cost ■ Use of proprietary CRM software to improve productivity • Single point of contact for project coordination and communication ■ Telecom cost wherever applicable ■ Reporting: clients receive a dally, weekly , monthly report 10 SCHEDULE 2 PRE-EMPLOYMENT SCREENING The Supplier must ensure that it has carried out the following checks in relation to the Personnel described m clause 5.4 to the standards shown below: • Proof of Right to Work • Proof of Residence • Financial Screening Check • Basic Disclosure in progress and the most recent employment references received and satisfactory. • Passport from EEA/EU countries or Switzerland , or

data.text: evaluate LICENSE AGREEMENT This evaluate® License Agreement (the “License Agreement”) is executed on August 3, 2010 (“Execution Date”) between Credit Management Solutions, Inc., a Delaware corporation with its principal place of business at 8671 Robert Fulton Drive, Suite B, Columbia, Maryland 21046 (“CMSI”), and DealerTrack, Inc. a Delaware corporation, with its principal place of business at 1111 Marcus Avenue, Lake Success, NY 11042 (“Licensee”). CMSI and Licensee are each, a “Party” and together “Parties” to this License Agreement. Background Licensee wishes to license from CMS! its proprietary evaluate ® software (the “Program”) for Verification, Pre-screening and Analytics (as defined below) purposes, and the Parties agree to such license subject to the terms and conditions of this License Agreement. In connection with the execution of this License Agreement, CMSI and Licensee have also agreed to tire execution of a mutual release waiving any and all rights each party may have against the other under the Non-Competition Agreement dated March 19, 2003 between DealerTrack Holdings, Inc., Credit Online, Inc., First American Credit Management Solutions, Inc., and The First American Corporation (the “Non-Compete Agreement”). THEREFORE, in consideration of the Terms and Conditions below and other valuable consideration, the sufficiency of which is acknowledged by the Parties, the Parties enter into this License Agreement as follows. Terms and Conditions 1- Definitions. In addition to the capitalized terms defined elsewhere in this License Agreement, the following definitions apply to these capitalized terms: 1.1 “Affiliate” of a Party, means another entity that controls, is controlled by, or is under common control of the Party. For purposes of this License Agreement, control of an entity means ownership, whether directly or indirectly through the control of one or more intervening entities of more than 50% o f the entire ownership interest in the entity, control of the entity’s voting stock, or the right and power to direct the entity’s affairs. 1.2 “Analytics” means use of the Program to provide to any DealerTrack Dealer real-time results, incorporating internal and external data relating to Verification and/or Pre-screening along with DealerTrack Lender Criterion, with respect to various key metrics that such DealerTrack Dealer measures as a means to assist such DealerTrack Dealer in deciding where to route Credit Applications, Loan contracts, and/or Contract Data, and to improve the management of its business, 1.3 “Annual Period” means the period of time beginning with the day after the Acceptance Date and ending on the yearly anniversary of the Acceptance Date. 1.4 “Billing Month” means the period of time between the twenty-fifth (25th) day of one month through the twenty-fourth (24th) day of the immediately successive month. 1.5 “Configuration Specifications Document” means the document, prepared by CMSI and signed by Licensee in accordance with Section 3.2 of this License Agreement, plus the Configuration Specifications Document relating to Verification, accepted and first placed into production by Licensee CMSI (7/2/2010) Confidential 1 in November, 2006, as modified by any Verification related configuration Task Orders that have been executed since by the Parties. 1.6 “Consumer Initiated Credit Approval Request” means a credit application initiated by a consumer through a consumer oriented web based portal that is routed through the DealerTrack System to a DealerTrack Lender(s) for a Credit Decision rendered by means of the loan origination system(s) of such DealerTrack Lenderfs), which if approved can be routed by DealerTrack to a DealerTrack Dealer(s) as a lead. 1.7 “Contract Data” means information submitted to the Program, and any information generated by the Program, necessary for (a) performing Analytics or (b) the completion of a retail installment sales contract or a lease instrument including but not limited to all Federal and state law disclosures. 1.8 “Credit Application” means (a) information submitted to the Program in connection with a DealerTrack Dealer’s request for a Credit Decision from a DealerTrack Lender or (b) a Consumer Initiated Credit Approval Request, in each case including but not limited to the Credit Application document and the information contained therein. 1.9 “Credit Decision” means a preliminary or final assessment, analysis or determination and information relating to a DealerTrack Dealer customer or prospective customer with respect to: (a) whether to make, purchase or sell a Loan, (b) whether the making, purchasing or selling of a Loan satisfies certain criteria, a policy or rule, or (c) the credit-worthiness of an applicant for a Loan. 1.10 “Data” means information transmitted in electronic form by Licensee, a DealerTrack Dealer, a consumer or a DealerTrack Lender through the Program, including, without limitation, any credit applications, credit reports, electronic contracts or information whether provided directly or indirectly. Licensee and CMSI may from time to time, with written consent from the other, add additional data fields to, or delete certain data fields from the Data accessed through the Program. These fields will be included in the term “Data.” 1.11 “Data Center” means the area of the building or buildings or at a designated annex, where a production or backup version of the Program, installed for operation on a computers), is physically located. 1.12 “DealerTrack” means the Licensee and its Affiliates. 1.13 “DealerTrack Dealer” means any dealer or dealer group that is authorized by DealerTrack to use the DealerTrack System. 1.14 “DealerTrack Lender” means any lender that is under contract with Licensee to use the DealerTrack System, including without limitation Pre-screening and/or Verification subject to the terms of this License Agreement. 1.15 “DealerTrack Lender Criterion” means the characteristics selected by a DealerTrack Lender to be used in Pre-screening and/or Verification. 1.16 “DealerTrack Rules Expressions” means any rule or calculation newly created in the Program specifically for a DealerTrack Lender as part of the DealerTrack Lender Criterion. 1.17 “DealerTrack System” means DealerTrack’s web-based, multi-financing source system that facilitates the transfer of Data from DealerTrack Dealers to DealerTrack Lenders and the transfer of Data back to such DealerTrack Dealers. 1.18 “Electronic Contract” means Contract Data electronically submitted by a DealerTrack Dealer to a DealerTrack Lender. CMSI (7/2/2010) Confidential 2 1.19 “Equipment” means any hardware, router, mechanism, device, or software used in connection with the Program, excluding the Program itself. 1.20 “External Site” means Equipment sites or web sites used by or on behalf of a Third Party to transmit data to, or receive data from, the Program. 1.21 “Licensee Enhancements” means, subject to Section 2.3 below, any modifications, enhancements or alterations to the Licensed Products made by Licensee independently of CMSI. Licensee Enhancements do not include any software code (or related documentation) that Licensee may develop in order to create an interface or other means of retrieving data from the Program and compiling reports or transmitting the data to other systems that Licensee utilizes to operate its business, provided such software code does not modify or alter the functionality of the Program and does not modify or alter or become part of the Program’s object code or Source Code (such software code and related documentation, “Licensee Interfaces”). 1.22 “Licensed Products” means the Program and the Program Documentation, as hereinafter defined. 1.23 “Loan” means a lease, loan, installment contract or other extension of credit to a person or entity. 1.24 “Maintenance Agreement” means the written agreement between CMSI and Licensee, dated concurrently with this License Agreement, entitled “evaluate Software Maintenance Agreement.” 1.25 “Personnel” of a Party means such Party’s employees, consultants and independent contractors, provided such individuals are subject to confidentiality and intellectual property right restrictions regarding the other Party’s confidential and/or proprietary information and intellectual property rights which are at least materially as stringent as those established for the respective Party under this Agreement. 1.26 “Pre-screening” means use of the Program to assist in determining whether a Credit Application to be transmitted to a DealerTrack Lender through the DealerTrack System satisfies certain preliminary DealerTrack Lender Criterion such that the Credit Application should be forwarded to such DealerTrack Lender for decisioning. Pre-screening expressly excludes use of the Program, either alone or in combination with any other software based system or program operated by, and/or under the control or direction of, either Licensee (or any of its Affiliates) or any DealerTrack Lender (or any of its Affiliates): (a) to process a Credit Application in any manner that would require under applicable law, in the event of a denial, the generation of a turndown letter, and/or (b) to render a Credit Decision that would require under applicable law, in the event of a denial, the generation of a turndown letter. For purposes of the preceding sentence use of the Program in combination with another software based system or program shall not be deemed to occur when a DealerTrack Lender processes a Credit Application and renders a Credit Decision regarding such Credit Application without utilizing the results or information generated by the Program to make the Pre-screening Decision, whether or not the Program had been used to Pre-screen such Credit Application. 1.27 “Pre-screening Decision” means a response that results from “Pre-screening”. 1.28 “Program” means, in object code form only, the Program components, modules and interfaces identified in Exhibit A. 1.29 “Program Documentation” means the Configuration Specifications Document and any other written or electronic documentation provided by CMSI to Licensee or its Affiliate for use in connection with the Program. CMSI (7/2/2010) Confidential 3 1.30 “Program Error” means a material failure of the Program to perform in accordance with the Program Documentation, but does not include a failure caused by any condition set forth in Section 4.1 of the Maintenance Agreement. 1.31 “Source Code” means the computer code for the Program in a form that is human readable and maintainable. 1.32 “System” means all software, and all hardware, equipment, and computers provided or used by a particular Party. 1.33 “Task Order” means a written request by Licensee or its Affiliate for service, work, maintenance or other assistance from CMSI on a form prescribed by CMSI and executed by an authorized representative of each Party. A Task Order may include requested services which will be billed to Licensee at the professional services rates indicated in Exhibit C for the type of service requested. Task Orders may cover services not anticipated on the Execution Date and may not be included in the pricing for this License Agreement in Exhibit C. 1.34 “Term” has the meaning provided in Section 9 of this License Agreement. 1.35 “Third Party” means a person or entity other than (a) CMSI, (b) Licensee, (c) an Affiliate of CMSI, (d) an Affiliate of Licensee, or (e) or an employee of (a) through (d). 1.36 “Verification” means the process by which the Program analyzes and compares Credit Application, Pre-screening Decision, Credit Decision and Contract Data with each DealerTrack Lender’s Criterion for the purpose of determining, within that DealerTrack Lender’s pre-selected tolerance levels, the conformity of the Credit Application, Pre-screening Decision, Credit Decision and Contract Data to that DealerTrack Lender’s Criterion. For the purposes of clarity, the analysis and comparison of Credit Application, Credit Decision and Contract Data for spot delivery is considered part of Verification. 2. License. Subject to all of the terms and conditions of this License Agreement, CMSI grants Licensee and its Affiliates, and Licensee accepts, anon-exclusive, non-transferable, perpetual, irrevocable license to use the Licensed Products during the Tenn. Each of the following subsections is a condition of this license: 2.1 Scope of Use. Licensee and its Affiliates and its and their Personnel will solely use the Program in connection with the business functionality identified in Exhibit A, Section 3. In addition, Licensee and its Affiliates will not: (a) Provide any Third Party access to or use of the Program other than for Pre-screening, Verification, Analytics or otherwise operate the Program in a service bureau environment; provided, however, that subcontractors and consultants of Licensee or its Affiliates may access and use the Program for or on behalf of Licensee or its Affiliates to the same extent as employees of Licensee or its Affiliates; or (b) Use the Program for Pre-screening, Verification or similar analysis of any Credit Application, Consumer Initiated Credit Approval Request, any Credit Decision or any Contract Data, which is not submitted, or is not being considered for submission, by a DealerTrack Dealer or consumer to a DealerTrack Lender (c) Use the Program: (i) outside of the United States of America or Canada or to process Credit Applications for a financial institution outside of the United States of America or Canada. 2.2 Program Database. Licensee may not modify the Program’s database, or add to, modify or delete any data in the Program’s database, except through use of the Program in accordance with the Program Documentation and Configurations Specifications Document, Licensee will not authorize its CMSI (7/2/2010) Confidential 4 Affiliates to modify the Program’s database, or add to, modify or delete any data in the Program’s database, except through use of the Program in accordance with CMSI’s written permission, directions, specifications and requirements. However, Licensee may execute independent routines or software such as report generating software) that access and/or extract data from the Program’s database provided that such routines are restricted to read-only access to the Program’s database. 2.3 Ownership. Licensee acknowledges and agrees CMSI is the sole owner of any and all right, title or interest of any kind, anywhere in the world, whether now existing or created in the future, of any or all of the Licensed Products, including without limitation any copyright, patent or trade secret rights, Licensee, on its behalf and on behalf of its Affiliates, irrevocably assigns to CMSI, now and in the future, and without need for further consideration or action, any and all right, title or interest, including without limitation any copyright, patent or trade secret rights, that may be conferred on or obtained by Licensee or its Affiliate in any of the Licensed Products, except for the license granted under this License Agreement provided however that this assignment expressly excludes all Licensee Enhancements and Licensee Interfaces which the Parties acknowledge are the sole and exclusive property of Licensee or its vendors as their interests may appear. Upon CMSI’s request and at CMSI’s expense, Licensee and its Affiliates will promptly execute, obtain all necessary documents and signatures, and take all other actions necessary to effect or confirm this assignment. Licensee will cause its Personnel, its Affiliates, and its Affiliates’ Personnel, to comply with this Section 2.3. CMSI will have no right, title, or interest in any Data, which is Confidential Information of Licensee, its Affiliates, any DealerTrack Lender or any DealerTrack Dealer, as their interests may appear. CMSI will not retain Data for any purpose other than to perform its obligations pursuant to this License Agreement. The Parties further agree that Dealer Track Rule Expressions will be deemed Confidential Information of DealerTrack and the DealerTrack Lender unless: (1) the DealerTrack Rule Expression was already in CMSI’s library when submitted to CMSI by DealerTrack for configuration or development; (2) a Third Party asks CMSI to develop a rule expression that is similar to, or contains similar components as may be found in the DealerTrack Rule Expression, in which event the rule expression as developed by CMSI for the Third Party will not be restricted as to disclosure or use by reason of the confidentiality of the DealerTrack Rule Expression; or (3) if at Licensee’s request, CMSI develops a rule expression for Licensee that is used by Licensee for general use and circulation among DealerTrack Lenders. 2.4 Proprietary Protections. Licensee will not, and will not permit its employees, Affiliates or any Third Party to: (a) Use or copy al l or part of any of the Licensed Products except in accordance with this License Agreement; (b) Decompile, disassemble or reverse engineer all or part of the Licensed Products, or create, access or use all or part of the source code for the Program; (c) Except as otherwise permitted by this License Agreement, create any derivative work from all or part of any of the Licensed Products, or use all or part of the Licensed Products to create computer software with functionality similar to any functionality of the Program; or (d) Modify or delete any copyright, trademark or other rights notice embedded in or affixed to any of the Licensed Products. 2.5 Reservation of Rights; Affiliate Compliance. Licensee shall pay to CMSI the license fees (“Program License Fees”) in connection with its access to and use of the Program determined in accordance with this Section 2, The Program License Fee will be $500,000 and will include 2,250,000 evaluate Pre-screening, Verification and Analytics transactions per Annual Period (during the initial Annual Period Verification transactions will only be counted for purposes of this Section 2 if they are processed on the Program hosted by Licensee, and not on the Program hosted at CMSI’s Data Center prior to migration of Verification processing from Licensee’s Data Center). These 2,250,000 transactions can be any combination of Pre  screening and/or Verification transactions. If Licensee exceeds or believes it will exceed the 2,250,000 transactions in an Annual Period, Licensee can either (a) increase the number of transactions by increasing the annual volume by paying a one-time payment of $75,000 for an additional 500,000 annual transactions or (b) pay $0.10 for each evaluate transaction over the number of annual transactions that Licensee has licensed. As an example, if, in a given Annual Period, Licensee exceeds the 2,250,000 transactions by 40,000 transactions, Licensee could just pay CMSI an additional $4,000 within thirty (30) days of the end of such Annual Period. This would allow Licensee the option to determine if the overage is a temporary increase based upon a short term market condition (e.g. Cash for Clunkers) that is not sustainable. For the purposes of this Section 2, one transaction shall be deemed to have occurred if a Credit Application is processed for Pre-Screening, a second transaction shall be deemed to have occurred if that same Credit Application is processed for Analytics to determine to which DealerTrack Lender the Loan should be forwarded for funding and booking, and a third transaction shall be deemed to have occurred if that same Credit Application and the associated Contract Data is processed for Verification. There can be no more than three transactions in connection with a single Credit Application for purposes of counting Licensee’s annual transaction volume. 3. Program License Fee Payments. Until the thirtieth (30th) calendar day after the later of the Acceptance Date and the date upon which the migration has been successfully completed, Licensee is entitled to an unlimited number of hours of that support without additional charge. After that period, Licensee is entitled to ten (10) hours of support per month (“Base Support”) and will pay for support for any support hours in excess of the Base Support each month. 2.2 Maintenance Releases. CMSI will promptly make available for license and use by Licensee at no extra charge all updates, upgrades and further releases of or for the Program CMSI (7/2/2010) Confidential 27 made available by CMSI at no extra charge to any other licensee of comparable versions of the Program, regardless of whether marketed by CMSI under the same name(s) or under new name(s). CMSI will provide installation and training on all updates, upgrades and further releases at no cost to Licensee. Such installation and training will not count against Licensee’s Base Support time. 2.3 Program Error Correction. At no cost to Licensee, CMSI will take the steps reasonably necessary to promptly correct each material failure of the Program to perform as set forth in the Program Documentation (a “Program Error”) until such error is corrected. Such correction and attendant work will be at CMSI’s sole cost and expense and not count against Licensee’s Base Support time. 2.4. Availability. Service levels shall be at the same levels as provided in the Service Level Policies and Procedures. 3. Licensee Responsibilities. As a condition of CMSI’s services under this Maintenance Agreement, Licensee agrees to the following: 3.1 Notice of Program Errors. Licensee must notify CMSI of the Program Error in accordance with the procedures supplied by CMSI to Licensee in writing or e-mail. 3.2 Support Requests. Licensee must request help desk support in accordance with CMSI’s then current published Service Level Policies and Procedures. 3.3 Dial-In Access. Licensee will provide CMSI dial-up access to all of the production copies of the Program and their databases through an “800” telephone number, over the Internet through a Virtual Private Network or other reasonable means that Licensee may prescribe and to which CMSI agrees. If CMSI incurs incremental, direct telecommunication charges because such access is unavailable, Licensee will reimburse CMSI for those charges at CMSI’s cost without surcharge or markup. CMSI’s obligations under this Maintenance Agreement shall be waived to the extent that CMSI requires access to production copies of the Program as set forth in this Section 3.3 and Licensee does not allow or make available such access by CMSI. The service level response times set forth in Exhibit A to this Maintenance Agreement shall commence as of the time CMSI gains appropriate access to production copies of the Program. 3.4 Licensee Representative. Licensee will identify to CMSI in writing 1 person and 1 alternate to serve as Licensee’s primary support contacts. Only those persons (or in their absence, their designated alternates) are authorized to request CMSI’s services under this Maintenance Agreement. Licensee may change its primary support contacts by prior written notice to CMSI. Licensee hereby designates Christopher DeMeo as its primary support contact. 3.5 Problem Determination and Remediation Procedures. Prior to requesting that CM SI correct any condition, Licensee will perform reasonable problem determination procedures to determine whether the condition is a result of a Program Error for which CMSI is responsible under this Maintenance Agreement, and will perform other problem determination or remediation procedures as directed by CMSI. 3.6 Access and Information. Licensee will provide CMSI: (a) The reasonable information and attention of its employees reasonably requested by CMSI; (b) Access to the production copy of the Program and its database, production hardware, network, equipment, telecommunications system, device, software or other product or system reasonably required by CMSI to cany out its responsibilities; and CMSI (7/2/2010) Confidential 28 (c) If CMSI reasonably determines that it is appropriate to perform services at Licensee’s facility, reasonable access to that facility. 3.7 Suspension. If Licensee materially fails to fulfill its responsibilities set forth in this Section 3, or pay undisputed fees or expenses owed under this Maintenance Agreement, CMSI may suspend any or all services under this Maintenance Agreement until Licensee corrects that failure. 4. Exclusions. 4.1 Exclusions. CMSI is not obligated to correct any Program Error or provide any Support for any condition to the extent arising out of: (a) Use of the Licensed Products not authorized under the License Agreement; (b) Use of the Licensed Products outside of their specifications; (c) Failure to use a correction or reasonable work-around supplied by CMSI to Licensee, or a version of the Program more than two releases prior to a release supplied by CMSI to Licensee; (d) Bug, defect, failure or other problem with any hardware, network, equipment, telecommunications system, device, other software, process, method, work, invention or information provided by Licensee or a Third Party; or (e) Negligence of Licensee or any third party acting on behalf of, or otherwise authorized to use the Licensed Products by, Licensee or its Affiliate. 4.2 Services for Excluded Conditions. CMSI will reasonably assist Licensee in determining whether a Program Error arises out of a condition described in Section 4.1. CMSI may but is not required to assist Licensee in correcting such condition, and may require Licensee to execute a written agreement regarding such services (a “Task Order”). Licensee will pay CMSI as set forth in that Task Order, for any services performed by CMSI to diagnose, correct or otherwise assist with respect to such a condition. 5. Fees and Expenses. In exchange for the services provided by CMSI under this Maintenance Agreement, Licensee will pay all fees and expenses in accordance with each of the following subsections: 5.1 Maintenance Fee. Licensee’s annual Maintenance Fee is Fifteen Percent (15%) of the Program Licensee Fee as provided in Exhibit B of the License Agreement, and is due and payable at the beginning of each Annual Period. If Licensee migrates the Accepted Verification Configuration before the Acceptance Date, the Maintenance Fee shall be correspondingly prorated until the occurrence of the Acceptance Date. 5.2 Expenses. Licensee will reimburse CMSI for reasonable shipping, travel and similar out-of- pocket expenses, incurred by CMSI in connection with this Maintenance Agreement. Prior written approval is required for travel that is not normal and customary. Air travel must be coach or similar status and lodging must be in commercially reasonable accommodations. 5.3 Taxes. Licensee is responsible for all taxes or duties based upon amounts payable under this License Agreement or upon Licensee’s license, use or possession of the Licensed Products (exclusive of taxes based upon the net income of CMSI). CMSI will report and remit any taxes due under this Maintenance Agreement. CMSI (7/2/2010) Confidential 29 5.4 CPI Adjustment. After the second Annual Period, rates specified may be adjusted annually in accordance with the consumer price index. For purposes of this Maintenance Agreement, “CPI” means the “Consumer Price Index for - Urban Wage and Clerical Workers (Current Series), as published by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, United States Department of Labor. 6. Payment Terms. Unless otherwise stated in this Maintenance Agreement, all amounts payable by Licensee under this Maintenance Agreement are due and payable sixty (60) calendar days after the date of invoice. Payments that are more than sixty (60) calendar days late bear interest at the lesser rate of: (a) 1’4% per month on the unpaid amount for each month (or fraction thereof) that the amount remains unpaid; or (b) the maximum rate permitted by law. 7. Term; Termination. 7.1 Term. This Maintenance Agreement is effective on the Maintenance Commencement Date and will continue for one (1) year and will automatically renew on the annual anniversary of the Maintenance Commencement Date without further action by either Party. 7.2 Termination for Breach. A Party may terminate this Maintenance Agreement based on a material breach by the other Party, upon prior written notice to such other Party reasonably describing the breach, and the breach remains uncured for ninety (90) calendar days from the receipt of such notice. This Section 7.2 does not limit any Party’s right to file a lawsuit seeking preliminary or permanent injunctive relief against unauthorized use or disclosure of a Licensed Product or Confidential Information. 7.3 Discretionary Termination by Licensee. Licensee may terminate this Maintenance Agreement by providing CMS1 written notice ninety (90) or more calendar days prior to termination, but only if Licensee simultaneously terminates the License Agreement in accordance with its terms. 7.4 Automatic Termination. This Maintenance Agreement terminates immediately, without need for further action, if the License Agreement terminates. 7.5 Survival of Provisions. The following provisions or obligations survive termination of this Maintenance Agreement: Sections 8.3, 8.4 and 9, and any payment obligations incurred prior to the effective date of termination. 8. Warranties and Limitations. 8.1 Good and Professional Manner. CMSI warrants the services specified in this Maintenance Agreement to be provided in a good, professional and timely maimer in accordance with the Service Level Policies and Procedures. 8.2 LIMITATION. THE WARRANTY SET FORTH IN SECTION 8.1 IS IN LIEU OF, AND CMSI DISCLAIMS, ANY AND ALL OTHER WARRANTIES, EXPRESS, IMPLIED, OR ARISING FROM ANY COURSE OF DEALING OR USAGE OF TRADE, RELATING TO THE SUBJECT MATTER OF THIS MAINTENANCE AGREEMENT, INCLUDING WITHOUT LIMITATION ANY IMPLIED WARRANTY OF MERCHANTABILITY OR FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE. 8.3 LIMIT OF LIABILITY. IN NO EVENT MAY EITHER PARTY OR ANY OF ITS AFFILIATES BE LIABLE, UNDER THIS MAINTENANCE AGREEMENT OR RELATED TO ITS SUBJECT MATTER, FOR LOST PROFITS, LOST SAVINGS, LOSS OF USE, LOSS OF DATA, OR FOR INCIDENTAL, CONSEQUENTIAL, SPECIAL, EXEMPLARY, PUNITIVE OR SIMILAR DAMAGES, EVEN IF ADVISED OF THE POSSIBILITY OF SUCH DAMAGES, OR FOR ANY THIRD PARTY CLAIM. CMSI (7/2/2010) Confidential 30 EITHER PARTY’S ENTIRE LIABILITY TO THE OTHER PARTY CONCERNING PERFORMANCE OR NONPERFORMANCE BY EITHER PARTY OR IN ANY WAY RELATED TO THE SUBJECT MATTER OF THIS MAINTENANCE AGREEMENT, AND REGARDLESS OF WHETHER A CLAIM IS BASED IN CONTRACT, NEGLIGENCE OR IN TORT, SHALL NOT EXCEED SEVENTY-FIVE THOUSAND DOLLARS ($75,000) 8.4 TIME LIMITATION. NO ACTION, REGARDLESS OF FORM, ARISING UNDER THIS MAINTENANCE AGREEMENT OR RELATED TO ITS SUBJECT MATTER, MAY BE BROUGHT BY A PARTY MORE THAN 2 YEARS AFTER IT KNEW OR SHOULD HAVE KNOWN THE TRANSACTIONS OR CIRCUMSTANCES GIVING RISE TO THE ACTION. 9. Miscellaneous. 9.1 Incorporation of License Agreement Provisions. The following provisions of the License Agreement Are incorporated by reference into and made fully applicable to this Maintenance Agreement, except that, as applied to this Maintenance Agreement, the term “License Agreement” is deleted and replaced by the term “Maintenance Agreement”: Sections 10.1 (Independent Contractors), 10.4 (Force Majeure), 10.5 (Section Headings and Subheadings), 10.6 (Severability), 10.7 (Implied Waiver), 10.8 (Notices), 10.9 (Enforcement), 10.10 (Governing Law) ,10.11 (Exhibits and Addenda) and 10.15 (Consents and Approval). 9.2 Assignment. This Maintenance Agreement is binding on any and all successors or permitted assigns. This Maintenance Agreement may be assigned only together with and to the same assignee as the License Agreement, and must be so assigned if the License Agreement is assigned. Any attempted assignment in violation of this Maintenance Agreement is void. 9.3 Entire Agreement: Waiver, Modifications and Amendments. This Maintenance Agreement is the entire agreement between the Parties with respect to its subject matter, and there are no other terms or conditions, expressed or implied, written or oral, with respect to that subject matter. This Maintenance Agreement supersedes all prior oral or written representations, agreements, promises, or other communications, concerning or relating to the subject matter of this Maintenance Agreement. This Maintenance Agreement may not be amended or modified except by a written agreement signed by an Authorized Representative of each Party, No term, condition or provision of any Licensee purchase order or other form will be effective as a modification of this Maintenance Agreement. Confidential and Proprietary 1 SETTING THE STANDARD IN CREDIT AUTOMATION Service Level Policies and Procedures from Credit Management Solutions, Inc. This document and the information contained herein is confidential and proprietary to Credit Management Solutions, Inc. (CMSI). This document or any information contained in it may not be used, reproduced, or distributed, in whole or in part, except with the express written consent of CMSI. CMSI reserves the right to modify this document in whole or in part. Service Level Agreement Revised September 10, 2007 Credit Management Solutions, Inc. Confidential and Proprietary 2 5 CHING THE STANDARD IN CREDIT AUTOMATION Table of Contents SERVICES POLICIES AND PROCEDURES  4 Problem Resolution 4 Customer Support 4 Escalation Policy 4 Software Development Issues 6 Upgrade Policies and Procedures 7 Policy  7 Procedure(New Builds within a release) 7 Procedure New Releases 7 Service Level Agreement Revised September 10, 2007 Credit Management Solutions, Inc. Confidential and Proprietary 3 Services Policies and Procedures Problem Resolution Customer Support All calls are answered directly by a Customer Support Analyst during the Principle Support Hours (displayed in table below). Calls are logged into an issue tracking system, and each issue is assigned a priority and a tracking number. During business hours, customers should dial the appropriate CMSI support number as shown in the table below. The first available Customer Support Representative (CSR) will answer the call. If a CSR is not available then please leave a voice mail in the support voice mailbox. A CSR will return your call shortly. In an emergency, press 0 and ask the CMS! operator to page Customer Support. If you are having a production emergency and are unable to get in contact with CMSI’s customer support team, please contact the Customer Support Manager or Manager of Client Services. After-hours, weekend, and holiday support calls are processed by CMSI’s answering service. The answering service escalates all issues to the after-hours support team in accordance with procedures established by CMSI. The goal of CMSI’s customer support operation is to resolve all issues promptly, issues that cannot be resolved during the Client’s initial phone call are escalated in accordance with the "Escalation Policies and Procedures’’ described in the section following the Support Hours and Contact Numbers tables. Principle Support Hours 8:30 a.m. - 8:00 p.m. EST Monday thru Friday coverage is 8:30 am - 8:00 pm EST. 9:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m. EST Saturday coverage is 9:00 am - 5:00 pm EST. After Hours Available on a time and materials basis. Customer Support Contact Numbers evaluate Support 800-472-0780 After-hours Support, all products 800-927-2674 If unable to reach a representative at the After-hours Support number, direct-dial 301-961-7762 Escalation Policy CMSI has established detailed escalation procedures that are followed by our customer support team for problem resolution. Each problem is assigned a priority that is mutually agreed between the client and the CMSI team. Priority A issues are addressed immediately. Priority B and C issues are addressed during normal business hours. Service Level Agreement Revised June 29, 2010 Credit Management Solutions, Inc. Confidential and Proprietary 4 Priority A A support request is classified as a Priority A if the problem has interrupted or impaired the operation of the customer's system. The following criteria should be used as a guideline in determining a Priority A condition: • evaluate not processing any tranactions • evaluate shuts down unexpectedly • evaluate will not start Because of the serious impact problems of this nature have on the customer's operation, they must be handled immediately. The goal for Priority A problems is to either provide a resolution or a mutually agreed-upon workaround as soon as possible after receiving the client’s call. Furthermore, to ensure that Priority A problems are resolved as quickly as possible, the following escalation process will be followed. Escalation Procedures for Priority A Within 15 minutes of the reported problem: The Customer Support Analyst: • Notifies CMSI Management with a brief description of the problem • Logs the problem into the tracking system. • Discusses with the Customer Support Manager the current status of the research and any actions taken or actions planned The Customer Support Manager: • Assigns internal resources as needed. • When 1 hour has elapsed: • The Customer Support Manager: • Updates CMSI Management on the status of the problem. • Modifies plan of action as needed and assigns additional resources if necessary. • Contacts management of the vendors involved in the plan of action, if applicable. • Contacts management within the customer organization to let them know the problem has been escalated, provides updates and explains the plan of action. Until the problem is resolved, phone or email updates will be provided every 4 hours. It is CMSI’s target to resolve Priority A problems within 24 hours or less. CMSI will use commercially reasonable efforts to meet this target. Priority B A support request is classified as Priority B if the problem has impaired the operation of the customer's system and the customer's business is being moderately affected. If one or more of the following criteria are applicable to the customer’s problem, it should be classified as a Priority B condition: • Turnaround time on evaluate request is too long • Rules are causing failure to process Service Level Agreement Credit Management Solutions, inc. 5 Revised June 29, 2010 Confidential and Proprietary Priority C A support request is classified as Priority C if the problem has a minor impact on the functionality of the operation of the customer's system and the customer's business is being slightly affected. • Rules returned incorrect results. Escalation Procedures for Priority B & C Once a problem or issue has been assigned a Priority B or C status, it is handled to completion in essentially the same manner as a Priority A issue, but within a more extended time frame that is mutually agreed between the customer and CMSI. Because of this longer time frame, weekly status reports are required as described below. Customer Support Analyst investigates and resolves the issue within a mutually agreed upon time frame. While the issue remains unresolved, Customer Support Analyst Continues to work on the solution and keeps the Customer Support Manager informed. Escalates to a Business Analyst if it appears to be a coding problem or a configuration problem that cannot be diagnosed. Customer Support Analyst maintains contact with the client at least weekly. While working on the solution to be completed by the agreed-upon due date, Customer Support Analyst updates the issue in the system CMSI uses for issue tracking. At the start of each business week after the initial report is received, Customer Support Analyst prepares a status report that satisfies the following requirements: Provides a brief description of the problem Identifies the report date Describes the resolution plan Provides a status of all resolution activities and tasks Indicates the next planned activity Customer Support Analyst forwards the status report to Customer Support Manager for review. After approval, Customer Support Analyst forwards the status report to the client. Software Development Issues Potential software development issues identified during problem resolution are assigned to Product Management. Product Management is responsible for reviewing the issues, categorizing them as issues or enhancements, and assigning a priority for resolution. Those issues identified as Business Critical, which do not have an agreeable work around, will be assigned for immediate resolution. Other non  Business Critical issues and enhancements will be resolved as part of a normal product release. Weekly meeting are held by management to review the open production issues. Issues are designed to be either patched to the existing system or assigned to a release. Issues identified as ‘patch’ candidates are assigned to available development staff and scheduled for delivery. Service Level Agreement Revised June 29, 2010 Credit Management Solutions, Inc. Confidential and Proprietary 6 Upgrade Policies and Procedures Policy In order to continually improve the Evaluate software, new enhancements and fixes will be released for reported issues and for requested enhancements. Regularly, these changes are released in new builds (one single deployment package) under the current version. When these builds are released, clients will be notified and expected to test and schedule installation into their production system. Builds are cumulative, meaning each new build’s module contains all the fixes that are included with previous builds. This procedure means you do not have to install an earlier version of the build before you install the latest version. The rollout of each build’s module provides a cumulative rollup of the changes. CMSI will also be creating new releases. At minimum, two releases will be created per year. CMSI will support the current version plus minus two. When a new release is announced, CMSI will provide 12 months support for the previous releases. Support may be extended, if approved by CMSI, to 24 months for those releases if the client feels additional time is needed for testing and deployment. CMSI will notify the customer and outline the support timelines for a previous release. CMSI strongly recommends that customers evaluate and install the current builds and releases in a timely manner to make sure the evaluate systems are up to date with the most recent software changes. ProcedurefNew Builds within a release) • When a build is released, an email will go out to all customers notifying them that the new build has been placed in a test environment and is ready for testing by the client. • During testing any issues found should be reported to the CMSI support center. Issues will be fixed and a new build will be created and released when available. • After certification of the build, the customer can notify support and schedule the production installation Procedure New Releases • When a new release is announced, a new bulletin will be sent outlining all the new features and fixes that are included. • All releases will not be immediately available to all clients. All features may not be available immediately as it may require configuration. • Any configuration that is needed in order to take advantage of the new functionality will be billed on a time and materials basis. • Client may notify CMSI to request an upgrade so it may be schedule accordingly. • Clients will be notified when a release is ready for testing in their environment. • During testing any issues found should be reported to the Release Upgrade Project team . • After certification of the release, the customer will work with the Upgrade project team to schedule the production installation. • Full upgrades are scheduled over a weekend period. Service Level Agreement Revised June 29, 2010 Credit Management Solutions, Inc. Confidential and Proprietary 7
