STATEMENT OF WORK ONE (Travel) This Statement of Work Number One (“SOW”) is effective as of October 6, 2017 (“SOW Effective Date”) and is between CONNEXIONS LOYALTY, INC. (“Connexions”) and FIDELITY INFORMATION SERVICES, LLC (“FIS”). This SOW is issued under the Master Services Agreement between Connexions and FIS effective as of October 6, 2017 (the “Agreement”). The terms and conditions of the Agreement are incorporated by this reference. Each capitalized term used herein but not defined herein shall have the meaning ascribed to such term in the Agreement. In the event of conflict among any of the provisions set forth in the Agreement and this SOW, the terms in the Agreement shall prevail except as to provisions specifically set forth in writing in this SOW. Any such modifications or amendments in this SOW shall control for purposes of this SOW only. In consideration of the mutual covenants and promises contained herein, and for other good and valuable consideration, the receipt and sufficiency of which is hereby acknowledged by each party, each party agrees as follows: 1. General Services, (a) Connexions will provide travel redemption/purchase services for all of FIS’ loyalty reward programs for which FIS is the system of record and/or the fulfillment provider (collectively, the “Programs”). Travel redemption/purchase services excludes the provision of travel vouchers/discounts/gift cards (such as a paper voucher for $100 off a car rental and a $50 gift card for an airline) or any other travel service requested by FIS that Connexions is unable or unwilling to provide or support. Connexions shall fulfill travel redemptions/purchases for eligible end users of the Programs (“Customers”). Connexions will not market any products and services other than the Program products to Customers without FIS’ written consent. For clarity, marketing by Connexions to a Customer who is also a member of a third party rewards program serviced by Connexions as part of the third party’s rewards program does not violate this provision. Connexions will ensure that its Services comply with all applicable laws and regulations, including, without limitation, U.S. Department of Transportation (“DOT’) requirements. (b) Unless delayed by circumstances other than its failure to meet its obligations under the Agreement and/or this SOW, FIS shall migrate approximately 20% of the total travel redemption/purchase portion of FIS Programs volume on or before March 18, 2018 and FIS shall migrate the remainder of FIS’ existing Programs to Connexions on or before December 31, 2018 (the “Exclusivity Date”). Both parties will make reasonable commercial efforts to expedite the migration schedule. At the time of migration, FIS will provide Connexions the FIS Rewards parameter file that lists all reward programs that include travel offering support at the time and listing of programs that are pointing the travel page offering to Connexions as objective demonstration of meeting the migration commitment. FIS and Connexions shall work together to determine an orderly migration schedule for 2018. 2. Program Websites, (a) Connexions will develop, host and maintain the online experience (the “Travel Website”), for the Programs in English and United States Dollars, for the redemption/purchase process, in accordance with the mutually agreed upon FIS Travel Launch Business Requirements Document, version 2.3, dated April 25, 2017 (the “BRD”), Connexions shall create a master Travel Website that will be replicated for each Program requiring a custom branded website, using the logo, colors and headers applicable to each Program. At FIS’ request, Connexions can provide additional customization or functionality and modify the Program rules at the fees specified in the attached Exhibit A. At FIS’ request, Connexions currently can configure a website in the language and currencies indicated on Exhibit B. Connexions and FIS will agree in advance to the effort required and estimated cost for any customization or functionality prior to Connexions making any changes. 1 (b) At a minimum, the travel Website will (i) be mobile responsive and ADA compliant, (ii) be integrated with FIS’ proprietary rewards platform, (iii) retrieve Customer points balances and display relevant Customer details, (iv) support all Payment Types, (v) support presentation of the purchase price on the Travel Website for split pay, which is configurable at the Program level, with a slider bar format or an input box, (iv) be configurable on the Program ID/client (BIN) level, (vii) support multiple redemption reward structures, including dynamic pricing models (where prices are converted into points), fixed ticket models (where travel items within a specified range cost a fixed amount of points) and dollars off awards (where a specified amount of points equates to a fixed dollar amount off the price), (viii) round point redemptions to the nearest 2500 points, (ix) be accessed via single sign on (SSO) technology from FIS’ website, and (x) will include the fraud monitoring tools described in Exhibit A. As used herein, “Payment Types” means the three ways a Customer can purchase their travel: (i) Redemption: All points are used to redeem the booking; (ii) Full Purchase: A payment card is used to purchase the entire booking; and (iii) Split Tender: A combination of points and a payment card is used to complete the booking. (c) Connexions will add the enhancements listed on the attached Exhibit C to the Travel Website at no cost to FIS. Connexions is committed to ensuring the Customer experience on the Travel Website is not stagnant and continues to evolve. Connexions will host a two day “innovation summit” for FIS during each year of the Term during which the parties will review innovations in the marketplace. The summit will focus on increasing Customer retention, increasing net margins, increasing transactional engagement and reducing transactional friction in the customer’s online experience. (d) (i) FIS will, through Connexions escalation contacts, advise Connexions of all scheduled maintenance and/or unplanned outages on FIS’s telecommunications network that are reasonably likely to adversely affect in any manner the ability for customers to reach the Travel websites and potentially drive additional calls into the call centers. (ii) Connexions will occasionally need to take the Travel Websites out of operation for Regular Maintenance and Emergency Maintenance. (x) “Regular Maintenance” means any planned maintenance on the Travel Website to implement platform upgrades, patches and/or fixes and other modifications, which may include new features to Connexions’ existing booking tool or modifications custom to the Travel Website for up to a 6 hour window which is currently between the hours 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Eastern Time, commencing on Saturday night and concluding by Sunday morning at 7:00 a.m. Connexions will publish the calendar for Regular Maintenance at the beginning of each calendar year during the Term and the Regular Maintenance windows will be based on the published monthly release schedule. Connexions will notify FIS in writing (which may be by email) at least 48 hours prior to any Regular Maintenance indicating the planned time and duration of planned activities that pertain to FIS and Regular Maintenance will be followed by a post-maintenance report within 2 business days detailing the results where relevant to FIS. (y) “Emergency Maintenance” means any maintenance for the Travel Website that must be performed promptly, outside of the Regular Maintenance window due to potential impacts to servicing, although Connexions will use commercially reasonable business efforts to conduct emergency maintenance between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. Eastern Time. Written notice (including via email) of Emergency Maintenance shall be given to FIS as soon as reasonably possible upon the need being identified. Emergency Maintenance activity will be followed by a post-outage report within 1 business day after the release detailing the accomplishments. 3. Rewards Options and Display on Travel Website. 2 (a) Customers will be able to book air, hotel, car, activities, cruise, tour and insurance through Connexions (“Travel Components”). Additional Travel Components may be added or removed as agreed to by Connexions and FIS from time to time. FIS acknowledges that some Travel Components may be bookable only on the Travel Website, other reward options may be bookable only in the call center, and some reward options may be bookable on the Travel Website and in the call center. Additionally, FIS acknowledges that insurance is only bookable for the Full Purchase Payment Type, and not for Redemptions or Split Tender. (b) Connexions will source and manage the Travel Components provided for redemption/purchase through each Program, including informing Customers of terms and conditions related to the selected items. Sourcing and managing the Travel Components includes, without limitation, the following: (i) If an airline offers multiple fare options for seats on the same flight, (examples of fare options include Basic Economy, Coach, Business Class and First Class) Connexions will offer Customers the fare options that Connexions receives from the global distribution system (“GPS”) that it uses for the FIS Travel Components. For airline travel, the Customer (or agent) will be able to view live seat maps in the booking process for over 70 airlines. If those airlines allow for it through the GDS used by Connexions, for the class of service selected by the Customer, Connexions will allow the Customer to select their seat when booking a flight. Where unavailable, the Customer will need to go to the airline’s website to select seats after checkout, if permitted by the class of service selected by the Customer. (ii) Southwest Airlines currently permits Connexions agents to book flights offline only. So long as Southwest Airlines continues to permit Connexions to book flights offline, Connexions will make Southwest Airlines tickets available to Customers for offline booking. (iii) Connexions receives hotel content from multiple providers. Connexions’ technology reviews the hotel content at the property and hotel room level and provided the information is recognized by the technology, the lowest price received by Connexions from its providers will be shown in the booking tool and the higher prices will be suppressed. From time to time Connexions may suppress hotels, whether by individual property, chain or supplier based on its due diligence which may include industry press reports, lack of cooperation to resolve concerns or negative Customer experiences. Connexions will give FIS prompt notice, but in no event greater than twenty- four (24) hours, of any property suppressions across all sourced hotel vendors. (iv) Connexions will include Trip Advisor ratings for hotels on the Travel Website so long as Trip Advisor has reviews for the hotel and Connexions continues to obtain ratings from Trip Advisor. The current functionality displays the 5 most recent reviews. If Connexions no longer obtains ratings from Trip Advisor, Connexions will use commercially reasonable efforts to include traveler ratings from another reputable company within a reasonable time after loss of Trip Advisor. (v) Connexions will offer Customers the ability to display hotels and car results within a map in the Travel Website user interface and to switch back and forth between the map view and the list review of results. Connexions currently uses Google Maps technology to show the results on a map and will offer this functionality so long as Connexions continues to obtain the information from Google Maps. If Connexions no longer obtains maps from Google Maps, Connexions will use commercially reasonable efforts to provide maps from another reputable company within a reasonable time after loss of Google Maps. (vi) Connexions will make one-way car rentals available to Customers, meaning a Customer can pick up the car at one location and return it to another location (one-way rentals). 3 (vii) Connexions will proactively solicit promotions from travel suppliers on a monthly basis for FIS to include in its Customer communications to drive travel volume. 4. Travel Component Cost to Customers. Connexions will utilize a combination of in-house and third party due diligence and proprietary tools to dynamically adjust the cost of travel items to Customers in accordance with the market rate as available on a publicly available online travel agency (“OTA”) website as well as FIS’ requests for additional markup (“FIS Initiated Markup”), Prior to the launch of the Program, Connexions and FIS will set the initial FIS Initiated Markups. Connexions will monitor performance against forecasts during the first 30 days and will make adjustments as needed so long as FIS is in agreement. Connexions and FIS will establish a mutually agreeable cadence to review the pricing and booking results during the first 30-60-90 days of this SOW and Connexions will make agreed upon adjustments to the pricing. Thereafter, FIS and Connexions will have discussions at a minimum of once a month to review booking and markup performance to determine whether the pricing strategy needs to be adjusted. The final FIS Initiated Markup for each Travel Component (as percentage (%) or dollar amount ($)) will be dictated by FIS based on best practices and collaboration between FIS and Connexions. The FIS Initiated Markup will be added to the cost of the Travel Component prior to the price being displayed to the Customer, so that the price displayed to the Customer is inclusive of the FIS Initiated Markup. Connexions shall report the FIS Initiated Markup on Customer bookings on a weekly basis, and shall issue FIS a credit for the FIS Initiated Markup on billing invoices for the Travel Components. 5. Call Center, (a) Connexions shall provide offline customer support, in English, for rewards related requests involving booking a travel item and post-booking servicing accessible by toll-free telephone lines. For the initial migration of 20% of the redemption/purchase volume of the Programs, the support will be provided from an onshore location using a shared call center environment. When the remaining 80% of the redemption/purchase volume from the Programs migrates to Connexions, the support will be provided from either an offshore location using dedicated call center agents or from an onshore location using a shared call center environment. Once the migration schedule is established the parties will use commercially reasonable efforts to agree upon an appropriate notice period for the election of the call center environment. FIS may change its selection during the Term, provided that (i) FIS uses its initially selected location for twelve months from the time of 100% migration, (ii) FIS gives Connexions at least 150 days' notice, and (iii) FIS pays the costs to move the call center which costs include items such as severance payments for agents that cannot be reassigned, and the hiring and training costs of new agents. Connexions shall provide FIS with an estimate of the costs prior to incurring the same. If FIS requests that Connexions utilize onshore call center agents in a dedicated environment, the parties will agree in good faith on the incremental costs to FIS to provide a dedicated environment. Call Center Support (frontline and helpdesk) shall be provided from 8:00 AM to Midnight Monday through Friday and 9:00 AM to 9 PM Saturday and Sunday, eastern time, Cruise and Tour hours are Monday - Friday 9:00 AM to 9:00 PM, Saturday 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM, eastern time, except for stated holidays (New Year’s Day, U.S. Independence Day, U.S. Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day). After hours Emergency Service is available post-booking. Connexions shall provide dedicated reporting for call center Service Level Agreements identified in Exhibit D, Section C and the reports identified in Exhibit D, Section E if FIS selects the dedicated environment; otherwise Service Level Agreements, and the call center reports are reported based on the shared call center. (b) Connexions will deliver its standard four week classroom training program for all new call center agents and will provide two weeks of nesting at the conclusion of the classroom training. Connexions will work with FIS to incorporate FIS program specific information as warranted into the training program. 4 (c) Connexions shall record all travel calls received and shall retain the recordings in the call recording system for 180 days. Recorded calls shall be archived after 180 days and maintained for an additional 180 days. Currently, after 1 year from the recording calls are deleted. Connexions will provide FIS with remote monitoring access/capability to both live and pre-recorded call center agent calls with Customers. It takes Connexions up to 2 business days to access recorded calls when they are within the call recording system and up to 7 business days to access recorded calls after they are archived and before they are deleted. Additionally, Connexions and FIS will conduct at least monthly or an otherwise agreed upon schedule between two teams joint call review sessions. Joint sessions can be facilitated between Connexions and FIS and/or between Connexions and FIS/FIS’ client at the same time. (d) Connexions prepares rolling call center volume forecasts. FIS shall meet with Connexions (which may be by phone and email) to review the call volume forecast in a 30-60-90 day forward looking manner and provide input based on marketing plans and Program changes. Forecasts will be locked three calendar months in advance of the service month (i.e. the forecast for April will be locked on January 1) for call center staffing and Service Level compliance purposes. (e) If FIS requires copies of or destruction of call recordings and/or email confirmations upon the termination or expiration of this SOW, FIS shall be responsible for the costs incurred by Connexions to comply with FIS’ request. Such costs include any out of pocket costs to retrieve records from storage systems and/or to search for and destroy information in a storage system as well as an hourly rate for Connexions in-house resources. 6. Voice Response Unit. In accordance with Connexions’ security standards, Connexions shall program its Voice Response Unite (“VRU”) to request Customers to enter their 16 digit account number (which will appear to the call center agent as a unique ID) or other agreed upon customer identifier into the VRU, enabling the call center agents to access relevant Customer information. 7. Customer Surveys. Connexions will administer a customer service survey for use in connection with online bookings. Customers will receive an online survey via email within an agreed upon number of days of booking. FIS shall have the right to approve the survey in advance of its use and will work collaboratively with Connexions on any updates to the survey content and timeframe it will be used, if at all, and for which FIS clients. Connexions may not publish, except for internal report purposes the results of any customer service survey, which shall be FIS’s Confidential Information. 8. Points Bank Access. Connexions will have access to FIS’s proprietary rewards platform system so that Connexions can access FIS’ points bank for relevant Customer information as needed. 9. Ticket Delivery. All airline tickets are issued as e-tickets. Connexions will send Customers booking confirmations, itineraries and receipts by e-mail if Customer provides an email address. Connexions will also send by U.S. regular mail or facsimile if the Customer docs not have an email address. 10. Travel Itineraries (Confirmation Emails). Each FIS client will be able to customize the verbiage and some of the other elements of the email itineraries sent by Connexions to the Customer after each booking. The itineraries (confirmation emails) can be customized by program ID in order to display details that are relevant to the client’s program. 11. Fraud Monitoring. Connexions will utilize proprietary in-house technology and processes to review each transaction, using the data elements provided, and will evaluate the fraud risk based on a robust and evolving dynamic ruleset and set of processes. The solution utilizes a customizable fraud risk model, confirmed fraudulent blacklist data, evaluation of multiple data components leveraging rules and Artificial Intelligence predictive functionality to proactively identify fraud. Connexions will manually 5 review and investigate transactions that meet certain criteria prior to completion of booking. Based on the review, Connexions will either release the quarantined order for completion or will cancel the order if it is deemed to be fraudulent. Connexions will bear the liability for all fraudulent transactions that are processed. Connexions will monitor fraud trends within FIS Customer bookings and will make modifications to the rules engine as needed. Connexions will provide fraud trend reporting and analysis on a quarterly basis. In addition, FIS will cooperate with Connexions in its efforts to prevent fraud and FIS, to the extent it is permitted to do so, will share information regarding fraudulent activities seen in the other services it provides for the Programs on a regular basis. FIS and Connexions will each notify the other party promptly if it sees an unusual increase in fraudulent activity (the criteria for which shall be agreed to from time to time by the parties) and will share information regarding such activity. Connexions reserves the right, upon notice to FIS, to temporarily stop bookings while it investigates unusual events or increased fraud activities and will work with FIS to identify the cause of the activity and resolve as soon as possible. 12. Personnel. (a) Steering Committee/Lnitiatives. Each party will assign representatives to an executive steering committee which will meet regularly to set priorities, ensure commitments and timelines are met, and provide governance on direction where needed. The steering committee may meet in person or by phone. In addition, each party will assign resources to execute upon agreed initiatives. (b) Quarterly Business Reviews and Conference Attendance. Connexions commits to four in-person onsite visits with the FIS team during each year of the Term. These visits may take place at FIS locations or Connexions will fund the flight and hotel costs for two FIS resources to travel in person to an agreed upon Connexions office location. Additionally, Connexions is committed to attending one conference jointly with FIS during each year of the Term whereby Connexions will fund the conference registration fee, hotel and air cost for one FIS representative. FIS would be responsible for all other expenses to attend the conference. (c) Designated personnel. Connexions agrees that personnel filling the roles listed below will support the Programs. These personnel are not dedicated resources. i. Account SVP and Account Director will collaborate with FIS and each other, and be accountable to advance Program strategy and performance; ii. Account Manager will be FIS’ primary point of contact and serve to direct teams, oversee requests, provide insights and recommendations regarding Program performance, as well as ensure that SLAs are met, if not exceeded. Initially the Account Manager shall reside in either Connexions’ Minnesota or Virginia office to optimize proximity to functional teams (or in any other location where Connexions may relocate its functional teams during the Term). If Connexions desires to assign an Account Manager who works from a location where the Connexions functional teams are not located (whether another office of Connexions’ or its affiliates, or a remote office), Connexions shall obtain approval from FIS first, such approval not to be unreasonably withheld. If FIS wants the Account Manager to reside in a FIS location, the parties will work together in good faith to accomplish this, including agreement on relocation, housing, travel and related expenses if a current Connexions employee relocates to accommodate this request; 6 iii. Revenue Optimization Manager will be responsible for the revenue optimization described in Section 4 above, which includes looking at pricing trends on at least a weekly basis and overseeing and implementing the pricing strategies for all bookings in conjunction with FIS to ensure strategy is aligned with FIS’ specific goals; iv. Business Systems Analyst will serve as SME for configuration of the multiple FIS Programs and assist with on boarding, ongoing configuration, and management of all elements within the Travel Website; and v. Client Services Team advocate will be responsible for day to day troubleshooting, ad hoc reporting and any evolution of ongoing support. (d) Background Checks. Connexions shall conduct background checks of all call center agents servicing the Programs as described in the Agreement. 13. Service Level Standards. Connexions will comply with the Service Level Standards set forth in the attached Exhibit D. 14. Fees and Costs. The fees and costs payable by FIS are set forth in the attached Exhibit A. 15. The revenue share will be remitted to FIS within ninety days after the end of the month via ACH, provided there is no past due balance. If there is a past due balance, payment will be made (up to the amount of the past due balance) as an invoice credit. Reimbursement: Connexions shall reimburse FIS as follows: i. $600,000 for expenses for the migration of the Programs incurred in 2018 and payable on or before February 28, 2019; and ii. $500,000 for marketing expenses incurred in 2018 payable on or before February 28, 2019. 7 b. Rebates: Connexions shall pay FIS the following rebates: i. Two Million Seven Hundred Thousand Dollars ($2,700,000), payable sixty days after the migration of 100% of FIS Programs to Connexions; ii. aggregate additional rebate of One Million Dollars, payable in annual installments in the amount of Two Hundred Thousand Dollars each as follows i. $200,000, due on December 31, 2019 ii. $200,000, due on December 31,2020 iii. $200,000, due on December 31,2021 iv. $200,000, due on December 31, 2022 v. $200,000, due on December 31, 2023 The payments shall be made via ACH on or before the due date, provided there is no money due to Connexions. IT Development Fund. Connexions will provide FIS with 1,000 hours per contract year (the first contract year to commence on January 1, 2019) during the Initial Term to enhance and drive product development needs as FIS requests. Prior to using any of the hours in the Development Fund, Connexions and FIS would agree in advance to the effort required and estimated hours to accomplish such request. Connexions is committed to work with the FIS team to enhance and evolve the travel program during the Term. The allocated hours shall not roll over from contract year to contract year; however, Connexions acting in good faith may make an exception, upon request of FIS, in situations driven by FIS clients outside of FIS’ normal control or an ongoing project. 18. Reporting, (a) Connexions will provide FIS with its standard monthly executive summary report by the 17th day of each month, which includes details on monthly bookings (sales and cancellations) by product, channel and Payment Type and the items set forth in Exhibit D. (b) FIS will provide Connexions with reports by the 17th day of each month which details 1) active client programs participating in FIS’ loyalty rewards programs at the end of the prior month, 2) a list of client programs that were added to the Connexions platform during the prior month and 3) a list of client programs that were removed from the Connexions platform during that month. 19. Exclusivity. As of the Exclusivity Date, FIS is appointing Connexions as its exclusive provider of travel redemption/purchase services for all FIS’ Programs. It shall not be deemed a breach of this provision with respect to any current Program that is not converted on or before the Exclusivity Date due to acts of the client that are outside of FIS’ control provided that FIS uses reasonable business efforts to assist such client with the conversion in an expeditious manner and FIS notifies Connexions of any clients who are not able to convert by the Exclusivity Date and keeps Connexions informed on the progress of the conversion timeline. It shall be deemed a violation of this provision if any Program leaves FIS and is converted to a program that is owned or managed by an FIS Affiliate. It shall not be a violation of this provision if FIS or an affiliate acquires a company that has a rewards program that FIS would manage (an “Acquired Program”) and such Acquired Program does not convert to Connexions as the travel provider, however, in the case of an Acquired Program FIS shall use its reasonable business efforts to convert such 8 Acquired Program to the Service. 20. Liquidated Damages. a. As of 60 days after the Exclusivity Date should 100% of the travel redemption/purchase services provided by Connexions for FIS Programs not be redeemed or purchased through Connexions, FIS shall pay to Connexions a single payment of Two Million Nine Hundred Thousand dollars ($2,900,000) within sixty (60) days of receipt of written notice from Connexions (the “Liquidated Damages I”). provided however, if as of 60 days after the Exclusivity Date, Connexions has not paid the sums due under Section 16 (a)(i) or (ii), such amounts not paid by Connexions up to total of $1,100,000 may be deducted from the Liquidated Damages I payable under this subsection by FIS. b. Once FIS migrates 100% of its existing Programs to Connexions, if at a point in time before the third anniversary of the Exclusivity Date FIS violates the exclusivity provision of Section 19, FIS shall pay to Connexions a single payment of Five Million Six Hundred Thousand dollars ($5,600,000) within sixty (60) days of receipt of written notice from Connexions or if at a point in time after the third anniversary, but before the fifth anniversary of the Exclusivity Date FIS violates the exclusivity provision of Section 19, FIS shall pay to Connexions a single payment of Three Million dollars ($3,000,000) (the “Liquidated Damages II”), provided however, if Connexions has not paid the sums due under Section 16 (a)(1) or (ii), 16(b)(i) or (ii) or any other amount due on or before April 1, 2018, such amounts not paid by Connexions may be deducted from the Liquidated Damages II payable under this subsection by FIS. The parties agree that such Liquidated Damages I or II payment shall be Connexions’ exclusive remedy for breach of the exclusivity provision of Section 19. 21. Term. Unless earlier terminated pursuant to the terms of the Agreement, the term of this SOW shall extend until the last day of the month in which five (5) years from date upon which FIS provides objective demonstration of meeting the migration commitment of one hundred percent (100%) of the Programs, as described in Section 1(b) to Connexions occurs (“Initial Term”). Thereafter, unless earlier terminated pursuant to the terms of the Agreement, the term of the SOW shall renew automatically for additional successive one (l)-year periods (each, a “Renewal Term” and, together with the Initial Term, the “Term”), unless either party provides the other party with written notice of non-renewal at least one hundred twenty (120) days prior to the end of the Initial Term or any Renewal Term. 9 Each of the parties has caused this SOW to be executed on its behalf by its duly authorized officers as of the SOW Effective Date. Each SL is measured monthly for all Programs in the aggregate. If the call center is in a dedicated environment, SLs are measured on a dedicated basis. If the call center is in a shared environment, SLs are measured on a shared basis. Failure to perform in accordance with the SLs may result in the service credits described in this Exhibit to be provided by Connexions to FIS. The service credits are FIS’ exclusive remedy for Connexions failure to meet a SL. Service credits shall be paid to FIS as an invoice credit. Connexions shall have 120 days from launch of each Program to “ramp up”. SL measurement, and any related service credits, shall not commence until 120 days after the last Program is launched. Root-Cause Analysis - Failure to comply with Service Levels In any month in which Connexions’ fails to meet a SL specified herein (other than incident responses and unless otherwise mutually agreed upon by the parties), Connexions shall have ten (10) business days to: (1) perform a root-cause analysis to identify the cause of such failure; (2) provide FIS with a report detailing the cause of, and procedure for correcting, such failure; and (3) provide an implementation procedure to be performed to cure such service level failure. Although Connexions has ten (10) business days to provide these items, Connexions shall use reasonable business efforts to provide the same within five (5) business days. Compliance Reporting Connexions shall report monthly (by the 17th day of each month) on its level(s) of compliance with each SL during the prior month. Any related service credits due to FIS for SL failures shall be provided by Connexions in the month following the report indicating the SL failure. Service Levels and Service Credits A. Travel Website and Program Availability Program Availability: The percentage of time the Travel Websites and the Programs are available, calculated as follows: the percentage of time equal to (Y-(X-Z))/Y, where X equals the number of minutes the Travel Websites and the Programs were not available during the month, Y is the total minutes in the month, and Z is the actual minutes during the month that the Travel Websites and the Programs were not available as result of Scheduled Downtime or downtime resulting from a force majeure event. Scheduled Downtime: The actual minutes that the Travel Website is not available in a month due to Emergency Maintenance that is approved by FIS and Regular Maintenance. Travel Website Availability: The percentage of time the Travel Websites are available, calculated as follows: the percentage equal to (Y-(X-Z))/Y, where X equals the actual minutes the Travel Websites are not available during the month, Y is the total minutes in the month, and Z is the actual minutes of the month that the Travel Websites were not available as result of Scheduled Downtime or downtime resulting from a force majeure event. 18 ♦Travel Website and Program Availability are measured separately and separate service credits apply for any failures. Commitment Service Level
Travel Website Availability The Travel Websites shall be available to users 99.5% of the time, although Connexions will strive for Availability of 100%.
Program Availability The Programs shall be available to users 99.5% of the time, although Connexions will strive for Availability of 100%.
Travel Website Response Time Home page for the travel site shall load within 8 seconds after single sign-on is completed with the FIS servers 97% of the time. Single sign-on process is inclusive of the authentication and account lookup with the point bank. Home page load time is exclusive of the iframe which loads content from the Program websites.
CDS Response Time Connexions agrees to put an action plan into place such that if the average GDS response time exceeds 25 seconds for a consecutive three month period, Connexions will identify this as requiring critical action, and provide options to address, including changing search vehicles if warranted.
Data File Processing Connexions shall support daily data files (e.g. fulfillment files, status files, etc.). Connexions agrees that it will process 95% of data files within one business day, provided the format of the files and the associated processing timeframes are provided and processed in the already agreed upon format and as long as the file isn't 20% larger than the average file size for the prior month. If FIS notifies Connexions via email of activity that could result in file sizes that exceed 120% of the average file size for the prior month at least 45 days in advance, Connexions agrees that it will also process the larger files within one business day provided that the format of the files and the associated processing timeframes are provided and processed in the already agreed upon format.
Travel Website and Program Percentage Availability* Service Credits Per Month
Less than 99.5%, but greater than or equal to 99.0% $2,500
Less than 99.0%, but greater than or equal to 98% $5,000
Less than 98.0%, but greater than or equal to 97.0% $7,500
Less than 97.0% $10,000
Travel Website Response Time Service Credits Per Month
Level 1 - Less than 9.5 seconds but greater than or equal to 8.1 seconds $5,000
Level 2 - Less than 10.5 Seconds but greater than or equal to 9.6 seconds $7,500
Level 3 - Greater than or equal to 10.6 Seconds $10,000
In addition to the Service Credits Set forth above, if the Travel Website and /or Program Availability service levels are missed in any three months during a rolling twelve month period, the service credits set forth in the Service Credit Schedule shall also apply. 19 B. Incident Response and Resolution All identified issues are classified in one of the following categories and are subject to the affiliated response and resolution timeframes: riVl : Sill1 -,, • • • \ :
1 - Critical • Defined as an egregious breakdown in service offering to Customers that creates a direct or indirect impact to the performance of the Programs. This includes significant client issues, risk to "client satisfaction and performance of program etc. 60 Minutes Connexions will work around the clock 7x24 until resolved. Connexionswill make commercially reasonable efforts to resolve within 12 hours if it is determined that resolution is in Connexions’ sole control and is not dependent on third party vendors for response. Resolution may include a work-around that resolves the issue or reduces the severity. Connexions will provide a root cause analysis within 7 business days after the issue is resolved.
2-High •Defined as an unplanned incident causing the Services to be materially different from those described in the product definition for essential features of the Program. 2 Hours Connexions will work around the clock 7x24 until resolved. Connexionswill make commercially reasonable efforts to resolve within 16 hours if it is determined that resolution is within Connexions’ sole control and is not dependent on third party vendors for response. Resolution may include a work-around that resolves the issue or reduces the severity. Connexions will provide a root cause analysis within 7 business days after the issue is resolved.
3- Medium • An unplanned incident that causes Services to operate in a way that is materially different from those described in the product definition for non-essential features. 4 Business Hours Connexions will use commercially reasonable efforts to resolve /find a work around within 1 Business Day. If the fix requires a code release, the
20 fix would be included in the next feasible production release.
4 - Low • Service-related issues that do not affect the operation of the Program, and/or issues that prevent a minor portion of work-related tasks from being performed; the majority of other tasks may be completed. One business day Connexions will use commercially reasonable efforts to resolve/find a work around within 30 Calendar Days If the fix requires a code release, the fix would be included in the next feasible production release.
Severity Level Initial Response Time Service Credits
Severity Level 1 Critical More than 60 Minutes $10,000
Severity Level 2 High More than 2 Hours $5,000
In addition to the Service Credits Set forth above, if the Severity Level 1 and/or Severity Level 2 Initial Response Time service levels are missed in any three months during a rolling twelve month period, the service credits set forth in the Service Credit Schedule shall also apply. C. Call Center Performance Standards The following categories are defined below and are subject to the affiliated performance standards: ♦If call volumes exceed the locked forecast by 7.5% or more, service credits for the call center performance standards will be waived for that reporting period. i 80% .jSfcJ
Speed of Answer Percent of calls answered by a live voice within thirty (30) seconds after the VRU recording is complete and the caller has entered the queue. See Service Credit Schedule
Abandon Rate Calls abandoned more than 30 seconds after caller has entered the queue. Less than 5% See Service Credit Schedule
Quality Assurance Connexions shall achieve an Overall Quality Percentage of 90% as scored from the Connexions’ Quality Assurance Observation and Feedback form. The current Connexions scoring form will be used. 90% See Service Credit Schedule
Overall Accuracy Connexions shall achieve an Overall Accuracy Percentage of 90% as scored from the Connexions’ Quality Assurance Observation and Feedback form. The current Connexions scoring form will be used. 90% See Service Credit Schedule
-VRU Availability Connexions VRU (voice response system) shall be available 99.5% of the time twenty-four (24) hours per day, three hundred sixty-five (365) days per year with exception of Scheduled Downtime. 99.5% See Service Credit Schedule
21 D. Travel Redemption and Fulfillment The following categories are defined below and are subject to the affiliated performance standards: Escalation Rate J.^tlyrFT.V  Connexions shall achieve an Escalation Rate of less than or equal to 1% based on Level I and Level II escalations. Percent shall be defined by the number of unique Level I and Level II escalation/complaint calls handled for the month divided by the number of calls during that same period. Level I - Escalations received by Connexions that fall into one of the following categories: Itinerary Errors made by Connexions; Schedule Change Errors made by Connexions; Point Redemption Errors. Level II - Valid escalations that fall into one of the above categories received by FIS and sent to Connexions for resolution. " r.'V.rff; See Service Credit Schedule E. Reports Connexions shall provide, on a monthly basis, no later than the seventeenth (17th) of the month following the month being measured, the following detail: Required Monthly Reports Description Service Level Requirement Service Credit
Aggregated reporting across all Programs • Total calls offered • Total calls answered • Total calls forecasted • Average call handle time • Average speed of answer • Abandon rate / percentage • Service Level (percentage of calls answered within 30 seconds) • Average hold time • Total call center and online sales • Conversion Rate • Total tickets • Quality Assurance and Overall Accuracy Report (Call Monitoring Report) • Cardholder survey results ■ Escalation log • Other reporting as required by the SOW 100% See Service Credit Schedule
22 Reporting at Program level (Scorecard = 1 Program, Bank of the West = 1 Program) If FIS has a dedicated call center environment, then Connexions will also provide the following reports by Program: • Total calls offered • Total calls answered • Average call handle time • Abandon rate / percentage F. Operations Inquiry Response and Complaint Resolution - FIS must send all complaints received about Connexions servicing of Customers via email to Connexions’ Customer Care Unit at stl.fisescalations@contactscfs.com. Connexions agrees that upon receipt, an automated response will be generated acknowledging successful receipt of the request. Connexions shall provide an update on the inquiry within 48 hours of receipt. For any Complaint requiring more than 48 hours to resolve, Connexions will notify FIS of the nature of the Complaint and the reasons for the extension of time to resolve the Complaint. With the exception of requests that are dependent on a third party travel provider Connexions will provide daily updates for issues requiring longer than 48 hours to resolve. Connexions will provide regular updates for issues requiring a third party travel provider to resolve. For any Complaint that alleges a violation of law, Connexions shall notify FIS via email within 24 hours of the violation in addition to notification via phone or mail of the allegation^) and organize a conference call with FIS to discuss the appropriate approach to resolve the problem. See Service Credit Schedule for service credits. 23 Service Credit Schedule to Exhibit D Service Level Requirements (for Chronic Service Level Failures) Metrics by Category Defined Defined Penalty Levels - Applicable to Call Center Performance, Travel Redemption and Fulfillment, Issue Response Penalty Per Month Example
Measured Monthly; Penalized for missing any three months In rolling twelve months Calf Center Performance Metrics Level 1: Miss any one metric 3 times in a rolling 12 month period $5,000 Speed of answer, Abandoned rate and QA Assurance each missed for any three months within a rolling twelve month period = Level 3 violation; penalty = $15,000
Speed of Answer 80% / 30seconds Level 2: Miss any two metrics 3 times each in a rolling 12 month period $10,000
Abandon Rate 5% or less Level 3: Miss any three metrics 3 times each in a rolling 12 month period $15,000
Quality Assurance 90% Level 4: Miss any four metrics 3 times each in a rolling 12 month period $20,000
Overall Accuracy 90% Level 5: Miss any five metrics 3 times each in a rolling 12 month period. $25,000 Speed of Answer, System Uptime, and Abandon Rate each missed 3 times in a rolling 12 month period. Quality Assurance missed 4 times in a rolling 12 month period and Escalation rate missed 5 times in a rolling 12 month period = Level 5 violation; Penalty = $25,000
VRU Availability 99.5%
Monthly Reports 100% by the 17th
Travel Redemption and Fulfillment Metrics
Escalation Rate Less than 1%
Operations Inquiry Response and Resolution Update within two business days of receipt
Issue Response
Notification of Critical system issues Respond within 60 minutes or less with reasonable efforts to resolve within 12 hours; Level 6: Miss any six metrics 3 times each in a roiling 12 month period. $50,000 OR FIS may terminate the Agreement, without penalty (other than payment to Supplier for Services performed by Supplier up to and including the effective date of such termination), with 90 days Speed of Answer, System Uptime, and Abandon Rate each missed 3 times, Quality Assurance missed 4 times, Escalation rate missed 3 times and Notification of System issues 4 times in a rolling 12 month period and = Level 6 violation ; Penalty = $50,000 AND Connexions will call an Urgent Remediation Conference (URC) OR FIS gives notice of termination
Notification of High system Issues Respond within two hours or less with reasonable efforts to resolve within 16 hours
24 notification which notice must be given with 15 days of receipt of the report that indicates the occurrence ofthe SL miss that enables FIS to terminate Note: In any month the service credit due to FIS shall be based on the highest Level indicated in the chart above. Urgent Remediation Conference. In addition to providing FIS with the Level 6 service credits, if a Level 6 violation occurs in any month, if requested by FIS, Connexions will convene an Urgent Remediation Conference (“URC”). The Account SVP together with Connexions’ executive owner(s) of the missed SL (such as the call center leader) will participate in the URC with appropriate representatives from FIS. The parties shall work in good faith to convene the URC within 5 business days of FIS’ request and will hold the URC in person if feasible. The URC shall be scheduled to last for 2 business days and the participants in the URC will work in good faith to agree promptly to a remediation plan at the URC. The Connexions URC team members and their designees will work diligently to bring service levels to an acceptable level within a reasonable period of time in accordance with the agreed upon remediation plan. Connexions will keep FIS informed of its progress towards achieving any milestones in the remediation plan as appropriate. 25

data.text:
MASTER PROGRAM PROVIDER AGREEMENT This MASTER PROGRAM PROVIDER AGREEMENT (this “Agreement”), effective as of October 6, 2017 (the “Effective Date”), is by and between CONNEXIONS LOYALTY, INC. a Delaware limited liability company, having its principal place of business at 4951 Lake Brook Drive, Suite 400, Glen Allen, Virginia 23060 (“Connexions”) and FIDELITY INFORMATION SERVICES, LLC an Arkansas limited liability company with principal offices at 601 Riverside Avenue, Jacksonville, Florida 32204 (“FIS”). WHEREAS, Connexions is engaged in the business of providing products and services to companies in connection with their loyalty and/or rewards programs; and WHEREAS, FIS operates one or more loyalty programs (each a “Program”) and wishes to make Connexions’ services available to members of the Programs (“Customers”); and WHEREAS, Connexions agrees to provide the Services as set forth in this Agreement, and the parties agree to work together as set forth in this Agreement. ARTICLE I - DEFINITIONS The capitalized terms used in this Agreement shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this Agreement, in the SOWs (as defined below) or as set forth below: (a) Affiliate: As defined in Rule 12b-2 promulgated by the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended. (b) FIS Marks: FIS’s name (or any derivative thereof), URLs, domain names, trademarks, trade names, logos, service marks, photographs, menus, slogans, trade styles, trade dress, trade secrets, copyrights, patents, graphics and other proprietary intellectual property rights whether or not registered or otherwise legally determined to be owned by FIS. (c) Losses: All out-of-pocket costs, fees, losses, damages, claims and expenses, including reasonable outside and in-house attorneys’ fees, disbursements and court costs, incurred by a party. (d) Person: Any individual, corporation, limited liability company, partnership, joint venture, association joint stock company, trust, unincorporated organization, government or any group or political subdivision thereof or other entity. ARTICLE II - SERVICES AND DUTIES Section 2.1. Services. Connexions shall provide the services described in statement(s) of work (the “Services”) entered into between Connexions and FIS (collectively the “SOW”) in accordance with the terms and conditions of this Agreement and the applicable SOW (including any service level standards contained in a SOW, if any). SOWs shall be sequentially numbered for identification. Each approved SOW is hereby incorporated by reference and made a part of this Agreement. Section 2.2. Duties of FIS, (i) General. FIS shall: Page 1 of25 (a) Forward promptly to Connexions all notices of claims, complaints or Customer correspondence arising pursuant to any element of the Services to which this Agreement applies and which are received by FIS. (b) Be responsible for notifying the Customers in the event that (i) FIS terminates a Program for any such Customers or (ii) this Agreement has expired or is terminated for any reason. (c) FIS may select Connexions to coordinate and print all marketing materials used to announce a Program to the Customers, the terms to be defined in a mutually agreed upon SOW or purchase order. (ii) FIS Marketing. (a) FIS can promote redemption travel generically in its marketing. FIS may use the names and logos of the merchants whose permission Connexions has obtained to identify the services being provided within their website, but FIS must obtain prior written approval from Connexions for the use of any merchant names/logos that relate to the Services provided by Connexions in marketing materials. FIS acknowledges that Connexions works with the merchants to obtain such approvals on FIS’s behalf. FIS acknowledges that it takes between ten (10) and thirty (30) business days to obtain merchant approvals. (b) FIS shall provide Connexions with an outline of marketing and promotion initiatives related to each Program for which Connexions is providing Services on an annual basis when the calendar is available. The parties will have ongoing marketing meetings to discuss changes or enhancements to the annual plan to assist Connexions with call center forecasting. FIS will provide notice at least sixty (60) days prior to using Connexions’ toll-free number in marketing materials and thirty (30) days prior for other marketing materials, and FIS will provide drafts of the related written communications using the toll-free number at least twenty (20) days prior to printing and the related written communications that do not use the toll-free number at least 48 hours prior to release. Connexions shall notify FIS promptly if it recommends any changes to the communications using the toll-free number and FIS will incorporate all reasonable requests. (c) Failure of FIS to comply with its obligations under Section 2.2(ii)(b) may result in, at a minimum, failure of Connexions to meet call center service level requirements specified in a Statement of Work and, at most, reasonable incremental costs to Connexions directly related to overtime costs in a dedicated or shared call center environment in a shared call center environment. FIS acknowledges and agrees that if Connexions fails to meet specified call center service level requirements due to FIS’ failure to comply with this obligation, such failure(s) shall not be considered a failure for the applicable call center service level requirements for the applicable month(s). To the extent feasible, Connexions will consult with FIS regarding management of any incremental costs and FIS shall reimburse Connexions for such incremental costs. Connexions must receive at least one (1) electronic copy or ten (10) hard copies of any Customer communication involving any element of a Program serviced by Connexions at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to communication to Customers. Section 2.3. Duties of Connexions. Connexions shall: (a) Render customer service and general administration for complaints, notifications, updates and other customer inquiries regarding the Services. (b) Render all Services and performances specified in this Agreement and all SOWs regardless of whether the individual elements contained in the Services are supplied by Connexions, an Affiliate of Connexions or any other third-party service providers. Page 2 of25 ARTICLE III - FEES AND COMPENSATION; REPORTS Section 3.1. Fees and Compensation. (a) Connexions shall submit all invoices in electronic format through Transcepta (or such other tool as may be identified by FIS from time to time). (b) Unless otherwise specified in a SOW, Connexions shall invoice FIS in US dollars for (i) the administrative and such other fees for the Services as set forth in the SOWs (except for reward costs and fulfillment fees) on a monthly basis and Client shall pay Connexions the invoiced fees that are not Disputed Amounts within thirty (30) days of the date that FIS receives the invoice, and (ii) the rewards costs and related fulfillment fees for the Services as set forth in the SOWs on a weekly basis and Client shall pay Connexions the invoiced fees that are not Disputed Amounts within seven (7) days of the date that FIS receives the invoice. Payments shall be made by check or ACH. (c) Any past due balance, except for Disputed Amounts, shall be subject to a late fee of the lesser of (i) one percent (1%) per month (twelve percent (12%) per annum) and (ii) the maximum amount permitted by law. (d) FIS may withhold payment of any amount disputed in good faith pending resolution of such dispute provided that FIS has given Connexions prompt written notice of the amounts disputed and the reason for the dispute and cooperates with Connexions in providing commercially reasonable responses to Connexions’ requests to resolve the outstanding charges (‘‘Disputed Amounts”). (e) Billing Records. Connexions will create and maintain accurate records and supporting documentation for all invoices under the Agreement for at least three (3) years following the date of payment of each invoice. No more than once per contract year, and once within one year of the expiration or termination of this Agreement, upon at least ten (10) business days’ prior written notice, FIS may verify Connexions’ invoices for the prior 12 months. Such verification will be conducted in a manner that minimizes disruption to Connexions’ business, and if in person, shall be conducted at the location where the records are kept. FIS may use an independent auditor to assist with such verification, provided that FIS has a written confidentiality agreement in place with such independent auditor. Connexions will provide to FIS and its auditors accurate electronic and written records, system tool outputs, and other requested system infonnation sufficient to provide verification that Connexions’ billing invoices are accurate and in compliance with the Agreement. FIS will provide Connexions notice in writing of any such verification that indicates that Connexions is not in compliance with the Agreement. Provided Connexions does not dispute the audit results, FIS will be entitled to (i) offset any overpayment amount against any currently due or future payment due under this Agreement or (ii) demand reimbursement to FIS of any overpayment amount made, which reimbursement Connexions will make within thirty (30) days after receipt of written demand from FIS. If the overpayment amount exceeds ten percent (10%) of the valid amount, then FIS will also have the right to demand payment for all reasonable out of pocket costs associated with the audit and examination, including, but not limited to reasonable travel, legal and accounting fees, up to $5,000. (f) Connexions shall have no right to increase any fee set forth in a SOW at any time during the initial Tenn of an SOW without the prior written consent of FIS; except that unless otherwise specified in a SOW, any fee increase required by regulatory changes shall automatically be accepted by FIS in an amount equal to the increased cost to Connexions, subject to Connexions providing FIS with reasonable supporting documentation of such cost. In the event of (i) material change(s) in travel industry commercial structures, or (ii) other additional fees assessed to Connexions which cannot be passed on to the customer, which events are beyond Connexions’ control, the parties shall negotiate in good faith appropriate changes Page 3 of25 to the Agreement after FIS’s receipt of written notification from Connexions with commercially reasonable documentation. If the parties do not agree upon changes within 60 days after FIS’s receipt of written notification from Connexions, or such later date as may be agreed to by Connexions, Connexions, in its sole discretion may terminate the SOW affected by the changes by giving FIS 30 days written notice of termination. The notice period can be extended by FIS up to a total of 180 days provided FIS agrees to pay the cost of such applicable travel industry commercial structures and/or other additional fees during the extended notice period. Section 3.2. Reports and Invoices. (a) Each party shall prepare and deliver report(s) to the other party in accordance with the terms of the applicable SOW. (b) Connexions shall send FIS invoices setting forth the total dollar amount, per Program and/or per fee, owed to Connexions in respect of the Services, in accordance with the terms of the applicable SOW. ARTICLE IV - RECORDS AND AUDITS Section 4.1. Records and Audits. Each party shall keep and maintain appropriate books and records relating to its activities and obligations under the Agreement for a minimum of three (3) years after their creation unless a longer period is required by applicable law, rule or regulation. Subject to reasonable security requirements, during the Term, each party shall make available to the other party and its designated representatives and primary regulatory agencies, if any, upon not less than ten (10) business days’ prior written notice, during normal business hours, at such party’s principal place of business, only the portion of such party’s books and records (including, without limitation, originals or copies of documents that support entries in such books and records) covering the Services described in the SOW, all transactions arising out of or relating thereto, and such party’s performance of its obligations under this Agreement for the purpose of inspection, audits and reproduction to ensure compliance with such parly’s performance of its obligations hereunder, subject to the confidentiality provisions of Article VIII hereof. Except as otherwise provided herein, each party will be solely responsible for its own costs and expenses in connection with such audits and inspections. ARTICLE V - INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY Section 5.1. License of FIS Marks. FIS hereby grants to Connexions a revocable, non-exclusive, non-transferable, royalty-free, worldwide license to use the FIS Marks during the Term solely to perform Connexions’ obligations under this Agreement. Connexions recognizes and acknowledges that it acquires no right, title or interest in or to any of the FIS Marks by virtue of this Agreement. Section 5.2. Work Product. (a) ■ All documents, reports, analyses, test results, marketing research data, computer programs, promotional materials and any other materials prepared by Connexions for FIS in connection with the performance of its obligations under this Agreement (’’Work Product”) shall belong to Connexions, and FIS grants to Connexions all right, title and interest in and to any such Work Product. Solely to the extent necessary or appropriate to perform its obligations hereunder, Connexions hereby grants to FIS a revocable, worldwide, royalty-free license to reproduce or use the Work Product. Page 4 of 25 (b) Unless otherwise mutually agreed to in a SOW, if Connexions solely develops a program, product or service hereunder without any funding or development by FIS (each, an “Connexions Service”), the parties agree that Connexions will own all right, title and interest in and to each such Connexions Service and, to the extent that there are any protectable intellectual property interests arising out of the development of any such Connexions Service, Connexions shall own all such interests. In such event, the parties agree to negotiate in good faith to arrive at a mutually agreeable licensing and cost arrangement. Section 5.3, FIS’s Proprietary Rights. FIS is and shall remain the sole owner of all right, title and interest in and to its name (or any derivative thereof), trade names, copyrights, patents, URLs, logos, trademarks and other marks, photographs, menus, slogan, trade dress and other proprietary descriptions and intellectual property of FIS, whether registered or unregistered, and all other materials furnished by FIS in connection with its performance of its obligations hereunder, as the same now exist or as they may hereafter be modified, including all rights in and to any copyright, trademark, trade name, service mark, patent, trade secret or other similar rights inherent therein or appurtenant thereto. Section 5.4. Connexions’ Proprietary Rights. Connexions is and shall remain the sole owner of all right, title and interest in and to its name (or any derivative thereof), trade names, copyrights, patents, URLs, logos, trademarks and other marks, photographs, menus, slogan, trade dress and other proprietary descriptions and intellectual property of Connexions, whether registered or unregistered, and all other materials furnished by Connexions in connection with its performance of its obligations hereunder, as the same now exist or as they may hereafter be modified, including all rights in and to any copyright, trademark, trade name, service mark, patent, trade secret or other similar rights inherent therein or appurtenant thereto (collectively, “Connexions Intellectual Property”). Section 5.5. Intellectual Property Representations and Warranties. Connexions hereby represents and warrants to FIS that, at all times during the Term, it owns and will own, or has the right and will have the right to use or license (and sublicense where applicable) under valid and enforceable agreements, the Connexions Intellectual Property. Connexions further represents and warrants to FIS that the current or future provision of the Services does not and will not infringe or violate any intellectual property rights of any other person, and Connexions has not received any charge, complaint, claim, demand or notice alleging any such infringement or violation. If it is determined that Connexions is infringing on any such third-party intellectual property rights, Connexions shall, at its sole and complete expense and as soon as possible: (i) obtain for FIS the right to continue using the infringing item free of any liability for infringement or violation; or (ii) replace or modify the infringing item with substantially similar and non-infringing systems, services or products. ARTICLE VI - TERM AND TERMINATION Section 6.1. Term. This Agreement shall start on the Effective Date and shall continue in full force and effect until the last day of the month in which the following occurs: the sooner of (i) five (5) years from the date upon which FIS provides objective demonstration of meeting the migration commitment of one hundred percent (100%) of the Programs under Statement of Work One to Connexions (as Programs is defined in such Statement of Work, as described in Section 1(b) of Statement of Work One) occurs, or (ii) when Connexions is no longer obligated to provide any Services under an SOW, (the “Initial Term”), unless terminated sooner in Page 5 of 25 accordance with the terms of Section 6.2. If not sooner terminated, this Agreement shall renew automatically for additional successive one (l)-year periods (each, a “Renewal Term” and, together with the Initial Tenn, the “Term”), unless either party provides the other party with written notice of non-renewal at least one hundred twenty (120) days prior to the end of the Initial Term or any Renewal Term. In addition, if the term of any SOW extends beyond the termination of this Agreement, this Agreement shall extend automatically, solely with respect to the SOW(s) then in effect. Section 6.2. Early Termination. (a) Immediate Termination. ARTICLE VIII - CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION Section 8.1. Confidential Information. (a) Scope of Confidential Information. In connection with its performance under this Agreement, each party (a ‘Receiving Party") may be supplied with materials and information concerning the other party by or on behalf of such other party and/or its Affiliates (the “Disclosing Party”) which is non-public, confidential or proprietary in nature (the “Confidential Information") and which may include, but is not limited to, information about or concerning the Disclosing Party’s and/or its Affiliates’: (i) financial condition and projections; (ii) business ventures and strategic plans; (iii) marketing strategies and programs; (iv) customers and prospective customers and information related to both; (v) strategic insights or statistical models about such customers or prospective customers and their behavior; and (vi) business partners. The Receiving Party agrees to be responsible for any breach of this Agreement by its Advisor, and the Receiving Party agrees that its Advisors will be advised by the Receiving Party of the confidential nature of such information. (c) Ownership of Information. The Receiving Party acknowledges and agrees that any Confidential Information of the Disclosing Party, in whatever form, is the sole property of the Disclosing Party. The Receiving Party agrees that upon the request of, and as directed by, the Disclosing Party, it shall either return such Confidential Information to the Disclosing Party or shall destroy such Confidential Information, except as may be necessary for the Receiving Party to perform its obligations hereunder.
