(b) "Order of Precedence. In the event of any conflict between the terms and conditions of this Agreement and any Appendices, SOWs, or other attachments the following order of precedence shall apply: (1) this Agreement; (2) Appendices; (3) SOWs, and (4) other attachments incorporated by reference. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the parties may modify a provision or render a provision inapplicable in a document that would take precedence by (i) referencing the specific provision that should take precedence and then deleting such provision or modifying such provision in an Appendix, SOW, attachment or amendment, (ii) having both parties sign the document containing the deletion or the modification." Section 10.15. Nonexclusive Agreement. FIS understands and agrees that nothing in this Agreement shall be interpreted to require Connexions to provide Services to FIS or the Customers on an exclusive basis and that Connexions may, in its sole discretion, provide other products and services similar to the ones provided by Connexions hereunder to third parties. Section 10.16. Inurement; No Third Party Beneficiaries. This Agreement shall inure to the benefit of and shall bind the parties and their successors, permitted assigns and legal representatives. Subject to the preceding sentence and as otherwise specified herein, nothing in this Agreement is intended to confer any rights or remedies on any person or entity which is not a party to this Agreement. Section 10.17. Counterparts; Facsimile Execution. This Agreement may be executed (by original copied, facsimile, scanned or electronic signature) in counterparts, each of which shall be deemed an original and all of which, when taken together, shall constitute one original document. Section 10.18. Procurement Contract Supplement. Page 16 of 25 Connexions shall comply with the terms set forth in the Procurement Contract Supplement, which is attached as Appendix A. Section 10.19. Disaster Recovery. In the event of a disaster, Connexions will resume operations via the procedures described within Connexions’ disaster recovery plan. Section 10.20. Mutual Negotiation. The parties hereto acknowledge that this Agreement was the product of mutual negotiations and accordingly should not be construed against either party hereto. [SIGNATURE PAGE FOLLOWS] Page 17 of 25 IN WITNESS WHEREOF, each of the parties has caused this Agreement to be executed on its behalf by its duly authorized officers as of the Effective Date. FIDELITY INFORMATION SERVICES, LLC Name: Wayne Ezell Title: VP, Global Procurement Date: 10-30-17 Page 18 of 25 APPENDIX A PROCUREMENT CONTRACT SUPPLEMENT PART I. DEFINITIONS. a. DEFINITIONS (1) A ‘‘Product” is any item of goods or services of any kind and in any form provided under the Agreement, including Services, equipment, supplies, data and software. (2) The phrase “under the Agreement” means under the Agreement directly or indirectly, such as through a statement of work or other contract made under the Agreement for the purchase of one or more Services or other Products, and the phrase “with the Agreement” refers to the Agreement and any such other contract. PART 2. SAFETY AND SECURITY a. SAFETY AND SECURITY ON PREMISES. Connexions Personnel must comply with all FIS postings and notices regarding safety and security when on the premises of FIS, and with the postings and notices of Clients or their customers when on their premises. Connexions Personnel must not carry weapons or ammunition onto the premises of FIS, Clients or their customers and must not use or carry weapons or ammunition while attending FIS-sponsored events. b. ACCESS PRIVILEGES AND RESTRICTIONS. In the event Connexions Personnel will receive access credentials for FIS’s facilities, applications, systems or servers, those of its Affiliates orthose of any Clients or any of their customers, the following provisions will also apply: (1) Connexions will require all Connexions Personnel that will be issued access credentials to submit to FIS’s then current access credentialing process. (2) Connexions will promptly, but in any event within twenty-four (24) hours, (i) confiscate each such access credential from Connexions Personnel when the Connexions Personnel’s need to have such access in order for the Services to be performed is discontinued and (ii) notify FIS of any change in the status (including any such suspension, termination or discontinuation) of Connexions Personnel for whom such a device or access credential has been requested or to whom such a device or access credential has been provided. (3) Connexions will not request that such a access credential be provided, or provide such a access credential, to any individual who will not be directly engaged by or at the request of FIS to provide Services. (4) FIS reserves the right to deny any access credential request or terminate any access credential that has been provided. Connexions will notify FIS within twenty-four (24) hours of any changes to the Connexions Personnel for whom such an access credential has been requested or to whom such an access credential has been provided. (5) Connexions will not permit any such access credential to be used by more than one individual. c. INFORMATION SECURITY AND INTERNAL CONTROLS. In the event Connexions (i) stores any data of FIS, its Clients or their customers, otherwise has any such data in its possession or control, (ii) has access to any such data from outside the premises of FIS, its Clients or their customers, or (iii) has access to any networks of FIS, its Clients or their customers, the following provisions will apply to Connexions. In the event a Connexions Affiliate or Contractor to Connexions does so, Page 19 of 25 Connexions will ensure by contract and otherwise that the following provisions apply correspondingly to the Connexions Affiliate or Contractor for the benefit of FIS. (1) Connexions will be responsible for establishing and maintaining an information security program to (i) ensure the security and confidentiality of such data, (ii) protect against any anticipated threats or hazards to the security or integrity of such data, and (iii) protect against unauthorized access to or use of such data that could result in substantial harm or inconvenience to FIS, its Clients or their customers. (2) Connexions will maintain security for its own systems, servers, and communications links as necessary to protect such data and networks. Connexions' security controls must include (i) anti- virus/malware devices, (ii) DMZ subnet and firewall controls, (iii) IDS/IPS controls, (iv) patch management controls, (v) physical security controls, and (v) change management controls. (3) Connexions will contract with an appropriately qualified third party information security assurance vendor to perform, on an annual basis, an information security assessment that includes intrusion testing. Connexions will forward a summary of the results of these tests to FIS within ten (10) business days following the Connexions’ receipt from the security assurance vendor. If, after reviewing such test results, FIS believes that additional testing is warranted, Connexions will discuss such additional testing with FIS in good faith. (4) Connexions will notify FIS of any and all breaches to Connexions’ information security system that impacts FIS Confidential Information, will identify the root cause of the incident, and will work with FIS management to identify the potential impact to FIS, its Clients or their customers, as reasonably requested by FIS. (5) Not more frequently than once each quarter during the Term, Connexions will conduct, or have a third party conduct, vulnerability scans of those components of Connexions’ environment required to support the Service and will promptly, and in any event not less than ten (10) business days following receipt from such third party, provide to FIS a summary of the results of any such scans if applicable to FIS. Not more frequently than once each year during the Term, Connexions will conduct, or have a third party conduct, penetration tests of those components of Connexions’ environment required to support the Service and will promptly, and in any event not less than ten (10) business days following receipt from such third party, provide to FIS a summary of the results of any such tests if applicable to FIS. In addition, Connexions will allow FIS or one of FIS’s approved third-party security assurance vendors to perform periodic vulnerability scans and penetration tests of those components of Connexions’ environment, if any, required to support any Product. FIS agrees to share the results of any scan or test it performs in Connexions’ environment to assist Connexions in correcting any agreed upon information security vulnerabilities identified. Connexions will correct any agreed upon information security vulnerability identified in FIS’s or Connexions’ own scans and penetration tests within agreed upon time periods, based on the severity level of the vulnerability, and provide FIS a new scan report upon remediation. Connexions will be considered to have access to such data in the event that a communications link (defined as a pre-established communications path from the customer premises, through a carrier network, to a network of FIS, its Clients or their customers) exists between any of Connexions’ systems or servers and any systems or servers on which such data is stored. (6) PCI DATA SECURITY STANDARD. If and to the extent Connexions or any Product is subject to the Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard requirements (as amended from time to time) (“PCI DSS”\ Connexions will comply with said requirements. In addition, if and to the extent Connexions or any Product is subject to PCI DSS requirements: Page 20 of 25 (a) Connexions will submit their Report of Compliance (“ROC”) within ten (10) days of the execution of this Supplement and will have a ROC prepared, and provide to FIS such updated ROC, annually thereafter upon request. d. BACKGROUND CHECKS. Connexions will ensure that a background check, as described herein, has been completed for each individual who is performing any Services under the Agreement and has access to the facilities, records or data of FIS, any Affiliate, any Client or any customer of a Client. Where permitted by applicable Law, the background check will consist of, at a minimum, verification of the highest level of education completed, verification of employment for the past five (5) years, social security number trace and validation, and a check of U.S. Government Specially Designated National (OFAC) lists. In addition, to the extent permitted by Law, the background check will include a 9-panel drug test and criminal record search. For the drug test, all specimens will be tested at a Department of Health and Human Services/Substance Abuse Mental Health Services Administration certified lab, and the screening service will include confirmation of all positive test results. The criminal record search will include, to the maximum extent permitted by Law, a federal, state and county check, and a National Criminal File check, for felony and misdemeanor convictions for the last seven (7) years in all locations where the individual has resided for the last seven (7) years. Connexions will comply with all applicable Laws related to the background check, including required notices and applicable consents. In addition, Connexions will require the individual to report any criminal convictions. Connexions will not assign anyone to perform Services for FIS who has tested positive for drugs or whose background check findings do not meet the standards established by Connexions in accordance with all applicable Laws, including if there is a conviction or referral to a pretrial diversion program for a crime that is related to his or her duties. Connexions acknowledges that under the banking Laws, an individual may not participate, directly or indirectly, in any manner in the conduct of the affairs of any insured depository institution without regulatory consent if he or she has a conviction, or has agreed to enter into a pretrial diversion or similar program in connection with a prosecution, of a crime involving dishonesty, breach of trust or money laundering, including any crime concerning the illegal manufacture, sale, distribution of or trafficking in controlled substances, unless the crime meets certain criteria for treating the crime as de minimis. The background check must be completed before assignment of an individual. (1) A “Client” is any current or prospective client or other customer of FIS or an FIS Affiliate. (2) A “Contractor” to a party is any individual (other than the party or an employee of the party), corporation or other entity providing services to or on behalf of the party, including any direct or indirect independent contractor to the party. (3) “Connexions Personnel” are individuals who are assigned to perform a Service, including employees of Connexions or its Affiliates, employees of any Contractor to Connexions, and if an individual, Connexions or any Contractor to Connexions. PART 3. SAFEGUARDING OF INFORMATION a. PROTECTION OF FIS CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION. Connexions must protect all FIS Confidential Information with at least the same degree of care it uses to protect its own confidential information, but in no event will Connexions use less than a reasonable standard of care to protect any FIS Confidential Information. (1) Connexions will (i) restrict the use and disclosure of FIS Confidential Information to Connexions Personnel and do so solely on a “need to know” basis in connection with Connexions’ obligations to perform Services, (ii) ensure Connexions Personnel who receive or have access to FIS Confidential Information are bound by confidentiality obligations at least as restrictive and as protective of the FIS Confidential Information as the provisions of this PART 3, (iii) establish Page 21 of 25 procedural, physical and electronic safeguards, designed to prevent the compromise or unauthorized disclosure of FIS Confidential Information and to achieve the objectives of the Guidelines (if applicable), (iv) not use or disclose any FIS Confidential Information except in accordance with the Agreement, (v) promptly investigate any security breach to determine whether such incident has resulted or is likely to result in misuse or unauthorized possession or disclosure of FIS Confidential Information; and (vi) promptly notify FIS of any Breach discovered by Connexions. (2) In providing any notice of a Breach, Connexions will use commercially reasonable efforts to (i) provide notice to one or more FIS managers generally responsible for security matters relating to the FIS Confidential Information affected by the Breach, within twenty-four (24) hours of discovering the Breach, and (ii) keep FIS informed as to the actual and anticipated effects of the Breach and the corrective actions taken or to be taken in response to the Breach. In addition, if the Breach results or is likely to result in misuse of NPI, PHI or payment card data, Connexions will (A) notify FIS as soon as possible and reasonably cooperate with FIS in its efforts to notify affected Clients and their customers and to mitigate the actual or potential harm resulting from the Breach and (B) reimburse FIS for its reasonable costs in notifying Clients or their customers of the Breach and if required by applicable law, making available to them any credit monitoring services, and for any other costs FIS reasonably incurs with respect to the Breach that are agreed to by Connexions. (3) FIS Confidential Information will remain the property of FIS, its Affiliate or other party from or through whom it was provided. (4) Except for NPI, PHI, other information protected by the Privacy Regulations, or any payment card data, (a) the parties’ respective confidentiality obligations under the Agreement do not apply to any information that: (i) was previously known by the party; (ii) is a matter of public knowledge; (iii) was or is independently developed by the party; (iv) is released for disclosure with written consent of the party; or (v) is received from a third party to whom it was disclosed without restriction. (b) each party may disclose information notwithstanding its confidentiality obligations under the Agreement to the extent required (i) by Law, (ii) in connection with the tax treatment or tax structure of the Agreement; or (iii) in response to a valid order of a U.S. court or other governmental body, provided that the party provides the other party with written notice and the other party is afforded a reasonable opportunity to obtain a protective order with respect to the disclosure. (5) At the end of the Term, or upon the prior termination of the Agreement, Connexions will destroy all FIS Confidential Information in a manner designed to preserve its confidentiality, or, at FIS’s written request and expense, return it to FIS, except that Connexions shall not be required to return or destroy any FIS Confidential Information stored on backup data and the confidentiality obligations contained herein shall continue to apply to such backups. (6) FIS will have and retain all right, title and interest in all FIS Confidential Information, whether possessed by FIS prior to, or acquired or refined by FIS (either independently or in concert with Connexions) during the Term of the Agreement. (7) Connexions will not, without the prior written consent of FIS, (i) provide the Services or access, store or process any FIS Confidential Information outside the United States or any approved call center location, or (ii) export any FIS Confidential Information to anywhere outside the United States or any approved call center location. 1 he provisions of the Agreement (as modified by this Supplement) apply without regard to where the Services are provided or FIS Confidential Information is accessed, stored or processed. Page 22 of 25 b. CONSUMER INFORMATION AND PRIVACY. If, in connection with the Agreement, Connexions receives, stores or accesses any NPI, PHI or other information or materials that are subject to the Privacy Regulations and Guidelines, Connexions will comply with the applicable requirements of the Privacy Regulations and Guidelines. Connexions acknowledges that the Guidelines include provisions regarding the safeguarding of consumer information, response programs and notice in the event of unauthorized access to consumer information, that FIS provides information processing services to Clients subject to the Guidelines, and that FIS may be required to notify Clients, their customers or other third parties of security incidents that result, or are likely to result, in misuse or unauthorized possession or disclosure of NPI, PHI, payment card data or other Confidential Information. Without limiting the foregoing, and in addition to its confidentiality and security obligations as otherwise set forth in the Agreement, Connexions will have systems and procedures in place designed to (i) ensure the security and confidentiality of such information or materials, (ii) protect against any anticipated threats or hazards to the security or integrity of such records, (iii) detect unauthorized access to or use of such records or information, and (iv) protect against unauthorized access to or use of such records or information that would result in harm or inconvenience to any Client or any customer of a Client. c. SPECIFIC PRECAUTIONS. Connexions represents and warrants that it has and will maintain in place commercially reasonable precautions to safeguard the confidentiality, security and integrity of FIS Confidential Information in a manner designed to meet the requirements of this PART 3. These precautions will include but will not be limited to (i) contractual restrictions on access to the information by Contractors and Connexions’ other vendors, (ii) intrusion detection systems on all information systems of FIS maintained or controlled by Connexions, and (iii) notification procedures for notifying FIS promptly in the event a security Breach is detected, as well as other response programs when there is a suspected or detected Breach involving NPI, PHI or payment card data. These precautions will also include, as appropriate, (A) access controls to FIS information systems, including controls to identify and permit access only to authorized individuals and controls to prevent access to FIS Confidential Information through improper means, (B) Connexions Personnel controls and training, (C) physical access restrictions at locations where FIS Confidential Information is located, (D) encryption of electronic FIS Confidential Information when appropriate or legally required, and (E) a disaster recovery plan as appropriate to protect against loss or damage to FIS Confidential Information due to potential hazards such as fire or water damage or technological failures. Connexions will (1) monitor the foregoing measures with periodic audits or testing and (2) provide copies of the same sufficient to assure FIS or its regulatory authorities that Connexions is implementing these precautions, and (3) notify FIS immediately in the event there is any Breach. Connexions will indemnify FIS from, defend FIS against, and pay any final judgments awarded against FIS, resulting from any claim brought by a third party, including but not limited to a customer of FIS, against FIS based on any breach of such applicable privacy Laws and the related rules or regulations by Connexions, including Connexions Personnel. d. DEFINITIONS (1) A “Breach” is an actual unauthorized (i) access to or (ii) use, possession or release of FIS Confidential Information. (2) “FIS Confidential Information” is information disclosed in any form in connection with the Agreement to Connexions, or to a Connexions Affiliate, any Connexions Personnel, or a Contractor to Connexions, by FIS, an FIS Affiliate or a Client, or by a customer of a Client, regardless of the manner of disclosure (including disclosure by giving access), that either: (a) constitutes or contains NPI, PHI, or payment card data, or FIS’s employee records (including any FIS employee’s name, address, phone number, salary, taxpayer or government Page 23 of 25 identification number, date of birth, health records, bank account information or labor party), or (b) constitutes or contains (i) FIS’s business strategy and direction, (ii) FIS’s operating or marketing plans, (iii) memos or other documents or communications pertaining to pending FIS litigation or contracts (including the Agreement), (iv) any information disclosed by FIS that is designated as “confidential” at or prior to disclosure, (v) other FIS data or information which is not generally known, including business information, specifications, research, software, trade secrets, discoveries, ideas, know-how, designs, drawings, flow charts, data, computer programs, marketing plans, budget figures, and other financial and business information, or (vi) information of the kind described by any of the foregoing categories that is of or disclosed by a Client, an FIS Affiliate, or a customer of a Client. (3) The “Guidelines” are the standards and guidelines established pursuant to (i) the Gramm-Leach- Bliley Act of 1999 or a state law equivalent, relating to the protection of nonpublic personal information provided to financial institutions (“NPI”), (ii) the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 or a state law equivalent, relating to the protection of protected health information (“PHI”), (iii) other relevant privacy Laws, or (iv) PCI DSS, relating to cardholder data (“payment card data”). (4) “Law” means applicable laws collectively, including statutes, codes, rules, regulations, ordinances and orders of governmental authorities. (5) The “Privacy Regulations” are the standards, guidelines and other regulations established by various federal or state regulatory agencies to protect the privacy and security of customer or patient information held by financial institutions, medical service providers and other entities. PART 4. ADDITIONAL CONEXIONS OBLIGATIONS. a. ONGOING QUALIFICATION OF CONNEXIONS (a) Connexions is and will maintain Enterprise certified for ISO 27001 Security frame during the Term. b. COMPLIANCE WITH LAW. (1) In all circumstances, Connexions will comply with, and will ensure that all Products comply with all applicable Law, including Law relating to export and import, privacy, use, disclosure or transfer of personal information, or security, and Law relating to the employment, health, safety and payment of Connexions Personnel. Connexions will perform an on-going review of Law applicable to Connexions’ performance under the Agreement and will maintain the features and functions for all standard Products in accordance with all Law applicable to such features and functions, including Law enacted or amended after the effective date of the Agreement. Connexions will identify and procure all permits, certificates, approvals, licenses, and inspections necessary for Connexions’ performance under the Agreement other than such permits, certificates, approvals, licenses and inspections that FIS is directly responsible for obtaining under the Agreement. Without limiting any other obligation of Connexions under the Agreement, Connexions will at all times comply with all Law relating to trade sanctions, export controls, the U.S. Foreign Assets Control Regulations, the U.S. Export Administration Regulations, and the U.S. International Traffic in Arms Regulations. c. BUSINESS CONTINUITY PLAN AND DISASTER RECOVERY. Connexions will establish and maintain disaster recovery and business continuity plans designed to minimize the risks associated with a disaster affecting Connexions’ ability to provide the Services, which includes off-site data storage and recovery infrastructure. Connexions’ recovery time objective for the Services C‘RTO”) under such plan is 24 hours. Connexions will maintain adequate backup procedures in order to Page 24 of 25 recover FIS’s or if applicable any Client’s data to the point of the last available good backup, with a recovery point objective (“RPO”) of 24 hours. Connexions will test its disaster recovery and business continuity plans, including call trees, not less frequently than annually, will annually provide to FIS disaster recovery and business continuity plans test results. If Connexions fails to meet the RTO and RPO in any annual test, Connexions shall perform a root cause analysis of the cause of the failure to meet the RTO or RPO and will remediate the cause of such failure and retest within a mutually agreed upon time period after the failed test. If Connexions fails to meet the RTO or RPO in the retest, Connexions will have a mutually agreed upon period to remediate and retest Connexions will provide its disaster recovery plan summary and test results to FIS and FIS may share such disaster recovery plan summary and test results with Clients who have contracted for the Services, if any, FIS’s auditors, and FIS’s regulators. Connexions will implement the applicable disaster recovery or business continuity plan upon the occurrence of a disaster, and shall notify FIS promptly following such event. Connexions will notify of, and invite FIS to participate in (at no additional charge to FIS), Connexions’ disaster recovery and business continuity plan test as it pertains to the Services provided to them. MASTER SERVICE AND SOFTWARE END-USER LICENSE AGREEMENT This Master Service and Software End-User License Agreement (the “Agreement”) is hereby effective as of (the “Effective Date”) and is by and between Core Technologies, Inc. a Colorado corporation with a principal place of business of 1320 Pearl Street #240, Boulder, Colorado 80302 (“Licensor”) and Fifth Third Processing Solutions, LLC, a Delaware limited liability company, with a principal place of business of 38 Fountain Square Plaza, Cincinnati, Ohio 45263 (“Licensee”). WITNESSETH: WHEREAS, Licensor is the creator and owner of certain e-commerce back office database management systems known as Mailware and Mailware Home Office (collectively the “Software”); WHEREAS, Licensee desires to use such Software; and WHEREAS, Licensor desires to grant to Licensee and Licensee desires to obtain from Licensor a non¬ exclusive perpetual license to use the Software and related Documentation solely in accordance with the terms and on the conditions set forth in this Agreement. NOW, THEREFORE, in consideration of the promises and agreements set forth herein, the parties, each intending to be legally bound hereby, do promise and agree as follows. 1. DEFINITIONS A. "Required Equipment" shall mean the minimum hardware configuration required to operate the Software. The minimum equipment shall consist of the following hardware: Mailware Workstations Mailware Server Pentium IV - 2 Ghz processor Pentium IV - 2 Ghz or higher 1 GB of memory 2 GB of RAM 300 MB of disk space 10 GB hard drive Monitor with 1024 x 768 resolution or Windows 2000, 2003, NT, XP, Vista or 7 higher Backup drive Windows XP or higher CD-ROM or DVD Monitor with 1024 x 768 resolution or higher B. "Documentation" shall mean all user documentation, and other related materials pertaining to the Software which are furnished to Licensee by Licensor in connection with the Software. C. "License Fee" shall mean the fee associated with a license seat to use the Software on a concurrent user basis (individually a “User Seat”), which shall establish a maximum number of users that may run the program at any one time. For purposes of this Agreement the initial license fee for the first User Seat is $2,500.00 and $1,000.00 for each additional User Seat. Licensor shall have the ability to adjust the License Fee in its sole discretion for future User Seat license purchases or upgrade purchases. MAILWARE MASTER SERVICE AND SOFTWARE END-USER LICENSE AGREEMENT Page 1 of 12 D. "Software1' shall mean the computer programs in machine readable object code form referenced herein and any subsequent error corrections or updates supplied to Licensee by Licensor pursuant to this Agreement. E. “License Term” shall mean the duration of the license, which as long as Licensee is in compliance with these terms and conditions shall be perpetual from the Effective Date. 2. LICENSE GRANT Licensor hereby grants to Licensee a perpetual non-exclusive right to utilize the Software on a concurrent user basis. The Licensee may install the software on multiple computers or make it available on a computer network or other shared environment. The foregoing notwithstanding, Licensee in only allowed at any one time to have a maximum number of concurrent users equal to the number of User Seats purchased by Licensee. 3. DELIVERY A. Licensor shall make the Software available to Licensee via download through an internet portal. B. Licensor shall also make available to Licensee electronic copies of the applicable Documentation for the Software. The Documentation can be found at www.mailware.com/mwdocs.php. 4. IMPLEMENTATION AND MODIFICATIONS A. Installation of Software. Licensee shall be responsible for the installation and implementation of the licensed Software. B. Modifications. If Licensee is in full compliance with this Agreement, Licensee may, from time to time, request that Licensor incorporate certain features, enhancements or modifications or other custom programming elements into the Software (“Modifications”). Any such Modifications shall be made on a time and materials basis ($125.00 per hour for standard delivery and $250.00 per hour for rush requests) and be documented in a Statement of Work (“SOW”) approved and signed by the Parties. The SOW shall be incorporated into and be considered part of this Agreement. Any fees paid for custom programming services are non-refundable. Any charges in excess of any amounts estimated on a SOW will be billed on an hourly basis. C. Title to Modifications. Any Modifications made in accordance with this Section shall be the sole property of Licensor. Licensor may, in its sole discretion, incorporate such changes into the Software and distribute them to all or any of Licensor's Licensees. Subject to Licensee’s compliance with this Agreement, Licensor grants to Licensee a non-exclusive perpetual license to utilize any Modifications distributed by Licensor under this Agreement. 5. INTEGRATION WITH OTHER SOFTWARE. If the software is to be integrated with any other software program, such integration must be completed by Licensor under a SOW issued in conjunction with this Agreement. Any integration or modification of the Software not performed by Licensor shall void the warranties set forth in Section 11 (B) of this Agreement. MAILWARE MASTER SERVICE AND SOFTWARE END-USER LICENSE AGREEMENT Page 2 of 12 6. SUPPORT, TRAINING & ERROR CORRECTION A. Maintenance and Support Services. Maintenance fees shall be and shall not exceed $2000 nor increase without thirty (30) days written notice. Maintenance fees entitle Licensee to 20 hours of phone support (including remote assistance) and a version upgrade for 2 licenses when available annually. At least ninety (90) days prior to the expiration date of a term for maintenance and Support Services as referenced in Exhibit A, Licensor may send Licensee written notice of renewal pricing for the renewal of such maintenance and Support Services. The parties shall agree to the renewal of maintenance and Support Services in writing at least thirty (30) days prior to the renewal date. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this Agreement and except for Licensee’s nonpayment for Services or the applicable Software license fee, Licensor agrees to provide support and maintenance Services at Licensee’s request. B. Remote Assistance. The Software contains a feature in which Licensor through permission of Licensee can take control of Licensee’s desktop to provide technical support services. Remote assistance can be used to help show Licensee how to use certain features or to fix certain problems. The Remote Assistance feature is provided at no additional charge; however phone support charges will apply. If Licensee receives goods damaged during shipment, Licensee must exchange the product within 30 days of receipt of the damaged goods by sending the damaged goods back to Licensor at the return address listed on the shipping label of the packaging. 9. Custom Work ESTIMATE: Core Technologies will:_ 1. Create a custom interface for importing and printing print jobs from an encrypted text file. A. Requires a valid operator login to open B. Button click to show the available print job files that can be imported (located in the directory specified in options) C. Button click to select available job from list to import 1. Decrypt file using command line decryption application into plain text. This will be done directly from the utility so the file does not need to be decrypted separately. 2. Import plain text, pipe delimited file into encrypted table. There is no limit on the size of the file, but it is recommended that it be limited to the number of records to be printed per batch. 3. Delete plain text file (but not the original print job file) 4. Number of records imported will be shown on screen D. Select from available printers and click button to print 1. Display list of printers to be printed to (list is created in setup) 2. Click button to allocate records evenly between printers and begin printing a. Merge file will be created for each printer b. Word template will be merged with merge file and sent to printer 3. Printed records will be marked automatically E. Ability to reprint part or all of a printer's output 1. Requires administrator approval 2. Select printer to reprint, enter sequence number range, and click button to reprint 3. Ability for operator to see limited identifying information for first and last sequence number selected 4. Allow comment to be entered by administrator as reason for reprinting 5. Core Technologies can add a feature to allow printer selection for reprint. NOTE: The user will need to verify printer has completed previous jobs. F. Cleanup after printing is complete 1. Operator initiates with button click (must be done before utility is allowed to close) 2. Delete original print job file 3. Delete merge files 4. Delete PIN and all customer and address information (Job and sequence numbers may be retained). Note: PIN number is encrypted at all times except when briefly decrypted for import. 5. Setup screen(s) for the following: A. Operator list (including administrators) with passwords. Note: Security levels to be limited to Operators and Administrators. B. DocuSign Envelope ID: 422751A4-75CC-4F9A-8701-2E086036FAF1 CORPORATE Vision Tk<M- vjih® 3875 Hopyard Rd, Ste. 275 Pleasanton, CA 94588 925-401-7990 www.corporatevisions.com EXHIBIT A STATEMENT OF WORK NO.: 11970 This Statement of Work No. 11970 (this “SOW”) is a SOW under APPENDIX A attached hereto (the “Agreement”) between Corporate Visions, Inc. (“CVI”) and Fidelity Information Services, LLC. (“Customer”) and is effective as of the last date signed below (the “SOW Effective Date”). Capitalized terms used in this SOW but not defined herein shall have the meanings given in the Agreement. This and all SOWs shall be subject to and governed by the terms and conditions set forth under the Agreement, unless specifically set forth herein. * If PO is required, it must be received before delivery of Intellectual Property. Customer requires PO NJ No J Yes* PO #  CVI Representative: Joe Kozub Customer Representative Sona Jepsen Fidelity Information Services, LLC 340 Madison Avenue Floors 6, 7 & 8 New York, NY 10173 sona.jepsen@fisglobal.com 908-463-4328 Product One, Two-Day Create Value™ Messages Workshop Dates: To be determined Location: To be determined Pricing: $98,000 plus consultants’ travel and lodging expenses, for no more than 15 Customer designated attendees in the Workshop. Note: an attendee or “Authorized User” is a Customer employee who logs into the eLearning or attends a Workshop. Sales Presentation Pricing: $15,000 The total value of this SOW is $113,000**. All amounts are payable in US Dollars. **This value does not include travel and expenses. All POs for SOWs with Workshop deliveries should include an estimated travel and expense amount of at least $3,000 for domestic delivery and $10,000 for international delivery per consultant, per Workshop. The pricing listed in this SOW is valid until November 30, 2017. If this SOW is not signed by November 30, 2017, pricing may no longer be valid. Confirmed dates are valid only upon a signed SOW and an email confirmation as set forth below. Payment Terms M3 Corporate Visions Inc. Confidential Rev.07-2017 DocuSign Envelope ID: 422751A4-75CC-4F9A-8701-2E086036FAF1 $41,800 will be invoiced upon execution of this SOW. Licenses will be released upon execution of SOW. $29,400 will be invoiced upon completion of the Create Value™ Messages Workshop. $14,700 will be invoiced upon delivery of the draft Conversation Roadmap. $19,600 will be invoiced upon delivery of the draft Conversation Playbook. $7,500 will be invoiced upon delivery of the Presentation. All invoices will be due Net 45 days from invoice date. NOTE: Customer shall be responsible for and shall bear all applicable sales, use, excise, personal property and value added taxes, or taxes of a similar nature imposed by any federal, state, provincial, or local government, or other taxing authority on all items, goods and/or services being paid for by Customer to CVI under this SOW. Once travel is booked, Customer is responsible for all travel and expenses incurred as a direct result of cancellation by Customer. A convenience fee of 3% will be added to all Customer credit card transactions used to pay for Services. Timeline In order to complete projects by their requested due dates, a project timeline will be provided and will need to be followed as closely as possible. We understand that variations in the timeline can occur and will make best efforts to accommodate. However, rush charges of approximately 25% of the project price apply when extensive delays in client responsibilities (background information, edits and final copy and design approvals) force overtime hours to meet completion deadlines. For the Create Value Messages Workshop: CVI Will Provide • 15 non-transferrable Create Value™ Messages eLearning Licenses for participants of the Create Value™ Messages Workshop. Upon execution of this SOW, CVI shall deliver the License Key to the Customer and a link to download the SCORM-compliant eLearning files. Customer is responsible for distributing License Key to individual users. Upon enrollment, individual users will have 12-month access to the newest version of the eLearning and Reinforcement Library. Except for subscription agreements, Authorized Users are limited to the total number of licenses specified in the SOW and in no case should eLearning files be copied, displayed, distributed, resold, transferred or otherwise provided to any third parties. Only subscription Customers may host the eLearning files on their own servers. • One, two-day Create Value™ Messages Workshop for no more than 15 participants. This Workshop will focus exclusively on message development, targeting one specific buyer profile, for a single enterprise, product, service, or solution of Customer’s choosing. • One interactive Conversation Playbook, using input from the consulting event. Playbook includes: • Strategy, copy, programming and design/layout using client’s brand guidelines. • Messaging and content that supports Customer’s Why Change and Why You stories, as well as downloadable versions of Why Change Whiteboard and Why You Prompterassets. • Playbook wireframe document for copy review & approval. • CVI sales coaching content. • Two rounds of content revisions and one round of design revision, incorporating Customer feedback on Playbook draft. • Production of a Why Change Whiteboard, using input from the consulting event. Why Change Whiteboard assets are delivered via the interactive Conversation Playbook and include: • Sales Coaching Video with illustrated Whiteboard story content, including voice over narration to model the story (video hosted by CVI) • Storyboard with sales coaching script for Why Change Whiteboard message. • Customer Facing PowerPoint file, in Hand-Drawn style with Whiteboard story animations, for use in remote selling or webinars. • Production of a Why You Prompter, using input from the consulting event. The Why You Prompter is delivered via the Conversation Playbook. • One Conversation Roadmap for up to three Power Positions, which includes: • Description of Customer’s Power Positions. • 1 Why Change story. • 3 Challenge/Why You stories. • Written content for each “copy block” in the Conversation Roadmap. MZ Corporate Visions Inc. Confidential Rev.07-2017 DocuSign Envelope ID: 422751A4-75CC-4F9A-8701-2E086036FAF1 • One round of content revision of on Conversation Roadmap draft incorporating Customer’s compiled feedback. • One CVI certified consultant to facilitate each event using CVI intellectual property. (CVI consultant(s) will be assigned based upon availability and requirements at CVI’s discretion). • One content consultant per event. The CVI content consultant will be responsible for capturing all notes and consulting results, producing draft Deliverables, and working with Customer to finalize assets. • A pre-event alignment call to better determine Customer objective and discuss the agenda, and participants. • Logistics Toolkit/Coordinator’s Guide with event logistics and requirements, to assist Customer coordinator. • CVI reserves the right to have up to two (2) CVI observers at eachWorkshop. Customer Will Provide • One event champion/ point of contact to compile and deliver feedback and sign off on event Deliverables. • Customer may provide CVI one round of consolidated revisions within one week of receiving the draft Why Change Whiteboard, draft Conversation Roadmap, and draft Why You Prompter and final approval within one week of receiving revised materials. If Customer does not provide revisions or final approval to CVI within 30 days of receiving the draft, the latest draft shall be deemed final and CVI shall have no further obligations to the Deliverables. • A coordinator to plan and implement the event. CVI’s Project Manager will assist the coordinator with details. • A technical coordinator to answer computer connectivity and log-on questions for Users taking the eLearning. The coordinator is responsible to contact CVI technical support regarding unresolved log-on issues. • A training facility large enough to accommodate Customer’s entire group and CVI’s consultants and support staff. (Descriptions of the most effective room set-up and other details are included in the Logistics Toolkit/Coordinator’s Guide.) • U-shape table, LCD projector / screen and four flip charts with multi-colored markers. A detailed Audio Visual list is in the Logistics Toolkit/Coordinator’s Guide. • If Customer attendees require special equipment, e.g. slide projectors, demo equipment or internet access, Customer should also make this equipment available. • Minimum System Requirements: 1 Mbps sustained downstream bandwidth, Intel Pentium 4 2.33GHz, Athlon 64 2800; 1GB of RAM, 128MB of graphics memory, latest version of Edge, Firefox, Chrome or Safari browser, Adobe Flash Player 11+, screen resolution of 1024 x 768, and speakers or headphones for audio. Headsets are recommended. Users need to be able to access CorporateVisions.com (http://corporatevisions.com/), learning.conversation.com (http://learning.conversation.com), training.corporatevisions.com (http://training.corporatevisions.com/), Box.com, Postclickmarketing.com and FLV and SWF files from Brainshark.com (http://brainshark.com/). Users are responsible to contact an assigned technical coordinator within Customer organization if they experience difficulties logging on. The course is only supported on Windows 8, Windows 10 and macOS operating systems. For the Presentation: CVI Will Provide • One, Sales Presentation o Presentation draft with up to two rounds of text and design edits o Deliverable: Up to 15 slides with stylized graphics and fully scripted notes • Kickoff call and interviews Customer Will Provide • Access to relevant background and subject matter experts, as needed. • Consolidated, timely feedback/edits in Word for no more than one round. • Consolidated, timely feedback/edits in Design for no more than tworounds. • Approval and sign-off. Additional Costs From time to time, additional expenses may be incurred in order to complete a project or meet the Customer’s additional requirements. CVI will inform Customer of these expenses and obtain written approval of the same (which may be by email in addition to other forms of writing) prior to delivery of such Services. CVI’s policies are as follows: Corporate Visions Inc. Confidential MC- Rev.07-2017 DocuSign Envelope ID: 422751A4-75CC-4F9A-8701-2E086036FAF1 • To effectively provide these services, CVI may need to record meetings and conversations and have them transcribed by an outside service. Transcriptions are charged at $55 an hour and become the property of the client. The need for transcription services will be identified by CVI and approved by the Customer beforehand. • Printing is not included in any of the above prices. Print prices will be provided upon approval of the first pass of design of a project. Due to the complexity of the printing process and in accordance with the Graphic Artists Guild, print quantity will fall within +/-10% of the original quantity ordered. CVI makes all attempts to deliver the exact amount set forth in this SOW. • Any production/printing fees are set forth prior to initiation. • Stock photography rates for quality above that which is priced in this SOW begin at $75 and vary depending on size of photo required, as well as usage restrictions. Any stock photography fees are set forth prior to initiation. • Illustrations, charts, custom artwork, and scanning are not included and are charged at a rate of $205 per hour. Screen captures are often poor quality and have to be recreated. If that is the case, it is a separate charge and is usually $500/shot or more and depending on screen complexity. Any custom graphic fees are set forth prior to initiation. • CVI prices are based on the schedule set forth in this SOW. Additional charges may be incurred at the rate of $250 per hour if additional rounds of edits, alterations or copy changes are requested beyond those set forth under this SOW or are requested after Deliverables are accepted/approved by Customer. Cancellations and Rescheduling Terms Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in the Agreement, Customer cancellation or termination of all or any portion of this SOW for convenience shall not relieve Customer of its obligation to pay 100% of any unpaid fees and incurred expenses hereunder and Customer shall be required to pay such amounts without deduction, setoff or delay. All amounts shall be due and payable in accordance with the terms of this SOW and the Agreement. CVI reserves the right to suspend services (including but not limited to CVI Workshops) and delivery of any Deliverables in the event of Customer’s non-payment or late payment over 120 days. When Customer signs this SOW with dates to be determined, the engagement is not considered scheduled until there is email confirmation between Customer and CVI’s Project Manager confirming the dates and location of the engagement. On occasion, Customer may need to reschedule an event. In those situations, the following terms apply: Cancellation & Rescheduling Notice Cancellation & Rescheduling Terms and Fees
Customer cancels more than 30 days prior to a scheduled event/Workshop date and sends a written reschedule request within 30 days of cancellation: CVI will use reasonable efforts to reschedule the cancelled event/Workshop on or around the date proposed by Customer. Any actual, reasonable expenses incurred up to the time of cancellation by CVI as a result of such cancellation will be invoiced upon cancellation and are due and payable per the terms of the Agreement.
Customer cancels and does not send a written reschedule request within 30 days of cancellation; or Customer cancels without notice or less than 30 days prior to Workshop/event date: 100% of SOW fees for the cancelled event/Workshop and any actual, reasonable expenses incurred up to the time of cancellation by CVI as a result of the cancellation will be invoiced upon cancellation and are due and payable per the terms of the Agreement. In addition, if Customer cancels within 21 days of the event/Workshops, CVI may be invoiced up to a $2,500
Corporate Visions Inc. Confidential Rev.07-2017 DocuSign Envelope ID: 422751A4-75CC-4F9A-8701-2E086036FAF1 per day non-refundable consulting fee. If this cost is incurred by CVI, Customer will be invoiced upon delivery of the rescheduled event/Workshop.
Travel and Expenses CVI will follow Customer’s travel policy guidelines, except that the following terms will prevail over the Agreement: Travel: Coach class airfare or auto mileage for domestic travel. Business class airfare for intercontinental flights. Auto Rental: Full-size car. Meals: Up to $100 per CVI facilitator assigned, per day, in the USA. As incurred, internationally. Hotel: A quality hotel. Misc.: Tolls, porters, mileage to airports, airport parking, etc. Shipping: All course materials and seminar equipment, to and from event. Schedule changes: CVI will book travel as soon as possible after confirmation of the engagement date(s) but not within thirty (30) days of the event. Customer is responsible for paying all rescheduling fees due to date changes made after the engagement date(s) have been confirmed. Billing Contact and Instructions Invoice delivery (check one): [ ] Email Email Address:  [ ] Follow Purchase Order Billing Direction f^T Online Billing Portal URL or system name (Required if Yes): Transcepta  [ ] Postal Mail Mailing address (Required if Yes):    Corporate Visions Inc. All Services must be delivered within the SOW Term at which time, all unpaid fees and approved expenses shall be due and payable. Confidential Rev.07-2017 DocuSign Envelope ID: 422751A4-75CC-4F9A-8701-2E086036FAF1 APPENDIX A TERMS AND CONDITIONS If no other services agreement has been executed by the parties as of the Effective Date of the attached Statement of Work #11970 ("SOW”), then the following terms shall apply to this SOW: 1. Scope. CVI shall provide to Customer the Services, Licensed Products and the Deliverables (as defined below and set forth in the SOW, as applicable) in accordance with the requirements for such Services and Deliverables in the SOW which these terms and conditions govern. The SOW and this Appendix A (collectively, the "Agreement”) constitutes the entire agreement between Customer and CVI with respect to the subject matter of the SOW. 2. Term. This Agreement shall begin on the Effective Date and continue for a period concurrent with the term of the SOW, unless sooner terminated. 3. Confidentiality. "Confidential Information” means and includes any trade secrets or non-public information and any and all data, documents and materials provided or made available, whether visually or orally, to a Party, its personnel or subcontractors by the disclosing Party ("Disclosing Party”) to the receiving Party ("Receiving Party”) under or in connection with this Agreement and that is marked or indicated at the time of disclosure or observation as being "Confidential”, or which would be deemed by a reasonable person to be confidential or proprietary in nature. For purposes of this Agreement, Confidential Information of CVI is referred to as "CVI Confidential Information” and Confidential Information of Customer is referred to as "Customer Confidential Information.” 3.1 Each of the parties shall (i) keep all Confidential Information strictly confidential and shall not, without the Disclosing Party's prior written consent, use or disclose Confidential Information other than as for the purpose of the contracted engagement and as permitted by this Agreement; (ii) use the same degree of care to protect the other party's Confidential Information as it uses to safeguard its own, but not less than reasonable care; (iii) establish procedural, physical and electronic safeguards to prevent the compromise or unauthorized disclosure of Confidential Information consistent with the guidelines, standards or governing laws that may apply to the respective party. The Receiving Party may reveal Confidential Information only to employees, agents and affiliates who: (a) need to know the Confidential Information for the Purpose; and (b) have been informed of and agree to abide by the terms of this Agreement. The parties shall be free to disclose the tax treatment or tax structure of any transaction under this Agreement. Confidential Information shall remain the property of the party from or through whom it was provided. 3.2 All Confidential Information, including any materials based thereon and any copies thereof shall, upon request, be returned to the Disclosing Party or destroyed. The requirements of confidentiality set forth herein shall survive the return or destruction of such Confidential Information for a period of five (5) years. 3.3 In the event that a party to this Agreement or any third party becomes legally compelled to disclose any of the Confidential Information, Receiving party shall promptly notify the Disclosing Party to enable the Disclosing Party to seek a protective order or other appropriate remedy. In the event that such protective order or other remedy is not obtained, the Receiving Party shall furnish only that portion of the Confidential Information that is legally required and use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain assurance that confidential treatment will be accorded the Confidential Information. 4. License Grant, Ownership and Restrictions. Subject to Customer's compliance with this Agreement, 4.1 Deliverables. Customer shall own all right, title and interest in and to the Deliverables, but specifically excluding any portion of the CVI pre-owned and developed intellectual property including all intellectual property rights in and to the Customer feedback, Online Service, Materials, methodology and workshops and all derivatives of the foregoing ("CVI Property) which may be embodied or included in the Deliverables (the tangible work product identified in this SOW which CVI creates using its methodology.) 4.2 CVI Property. If any CVI Property is embodied or incorporated into a Deliverable, CVI will, subject to Customer's compliance with the terms of this SOW, grant Customer a non-exclusive, license to use and display the CVI Property solely as embodied or incorporated into the Deliverable. All rights, title and interest in and to the CVI Property are and shall remain the sole and exclusive property of CVI. CVI reserves all rights in and to the CVI Property not expressly granted to Customer and Customer employees. This agreement does not grant Customer or any of its employees or agents any rights or implied licenses other than those expressly granted herein. 4.4. Materials. CVI grants to the Customer employees a personal, limited, non-exclusive license to use the Materials in the form and format provided by CVI and solely for use by such employees during their employment with Customer. CVI shall retain any and all intellectual property rights embodied in said Materials Corporate Visions Inc. Confidential Rev.07-2017 DocuSign Envelope ID: 422751A4-75CC-4F9A-8701-2E086036FAF1 (collectively, the audio-visual and/or visual items made available to Customer employees as part of the Online Service or a workshop, which may include, audio-visual works, books, diagrams, guides, kits and other materials.) 4.5 CVI Property and Materials shall be collectively known on the SOW as the "Licensed Products.” 5. Indemnification. CVI shall defend, indemnify and hold harmless Customer and its officers, directors, employees, and shall pay, as incurred, all liabilities, damages, costs, fees and expenses (including reasonable attorney's fees) relating to any third party claim, action, suit or other proceeding: (a) alleging that Work Products paid for by Customer and used by Customer in accordance with the terms of this Agreement constitute an infringement of any U.S. patent, copyright, trademark or trade secret; (b) alleging damages as a result of the negligence, intentional acts, breach of confidentiality obligations or violations of applicable law by CVI, including, but not limited to, any contractors to CVI; or (c) relating to any claim for personal injury or damage to tangible property caused by any CVI Personnel while performing services on the premises of Customer; provided however, that CVI shall not be liable for or obligated to indemnify or defend any third party claims arising out of Customer’s, or any of Authorized Users’: (a) alteration or modification of the Materials; (b) combination of the Materials or Deliverables with any other information, materials or products; (c) use of the Materials or Deliverables in a manner not authorized under this Agreement; or export of any Materials or Deliverables in violation of applicable export control regulations.. THE FOREGOING SHALL CONSTITUTE THE CUSTOMER’S SOLE REMEDY AND CVI’S SOLE AND EXCLUSIVE LIABILITY FOR ALL INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY CLAIMS. 5.2 In the event of any alleged, actual or potential Intellectual Property Claim, CVI will be entitled (but not obligated), at its sole option, to: (a) procure for Customer the right to continue use of the applicable Work Product; (b) replace or modify the applicable Work Product to avoid the alleged infringement or misappropriation; or (c) if CVI determines, in its sole discretion, that neither of the foregoing options are commercially reasonable, then CVI may terminate the SOW and refund Customer any fees pre-paid for the infringing Work Product. 6. Force Majeure. Neither party shall be liable for failure to comply with any of the terms of this Agreement if and to the extent that such failure has been caused solely by fire, war, insurrection, epidemic, government restrictions, force majeure or other causes beyond the reasonable control, and not due to the fault, of the non-performing party. If the non-performance continues for more than thirty (30) days, the party whose ability to perform has not been so affected may, by giving written notice, terminate this Agreement. 7. Miscellaneous. This Agreement shall be governed by and construed and enforced in accordance with the laws of the United States of America and the State of Florida, without regard to conflict of laws principles. The parties will settle any dispute, difference, controversy or claim arising out of or relating to the Agreement by binding arbitration before a single arbitrator in Jacksonville, Florida in accordance with the Commercial Arbitration Rules (including Procedures for Large, Complex Commercial Disputes) of the American Arbitration Association. Judgment on any resulting award may be entered by any court having jurisdiction over the parties or their respective property. The arbitrator will decide any issues submitted in accordance with the provisions and commercial purposes of the Agreement, and will not have the power to Corporate Visions Inc. Confidential award damages in excess of the limitations set forth in, or damages excluded by, the Agreement. 8. Either party may assign its rights and obligations under this Agreement without obtaining prior written consent if said assignment is in connection with a merger, consolidation, reorganization or sale of substantially all of such party’s assets. A waiver by any Party of any breach or default will not constitute a waiver of any different or subsequent breach or default. If any part of this Agreement is invalid, illegal or unenforceable for any reason, the remainder shall remain in force and the invalid, illegal or unenforceable portion will be replaced with a valid provision appropriate to the Parties’ original intent.

(“CVI”) and Fidelity Information Services, LLC (“FIS” or “Customer”) and is effective January 31, 2019 (the “SOW Effective Date”). This and all SOWs shall be subject to and governed by the terms and conditions set forth under the Agreement, provided that in the event of a conflict, ambiguity or contradiction between this SOW and the Agreement, this SOW will take precedence. This SOW may only be modified (including extension or renewal) by a written document signed by both parties. The parties do not intend, nor shall there be, any third-party beneficiary rights.
