"SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in Best Current Practice - Key Words. 09.01 Global Travel and Entertainment Policy Purpose The purpose of this global policy is to acquaint all employees with FIS travel and entertainment policies and standards and to inform each employee of the company’s expectations while traveling on behalf of FIS. This document establishes mandatory requirements necessary to: • Ensure that all employees have a clear and consistent understanding of the FIS policies and standards for business travel • Provide business travelers with a reasonable level of service, comfort, safety and security at the optimum cost • Maximize FIS’ ability to negotiate discounted rates with contracted suppliers and reduce travel and related expenses, including the utilization of: o FIS appointed business travel management companies o Corporate credit card programs o Contracted and approved airline, hotel, car rental and rail companies • Ensure that all authorized expenditures meet and comply with country specific regulatory and/or statutory mandates Statement Travel will be authorized for the following circumstances only: • Client-only travel, which includes work billable to a client and/or work necessary to: a) fulfill implementation, migration, SLA or other obligations to clients, b) respond to client initiated needs or requests, or c) sales-related travel necessary to pursue new business opportunities • FIS-sponsored events, such as tradeshows and conferences when in alignment with participation guidelines specified by the event sponsor and enforced by the Senior Leadership Team (the “SLT”) business • Request or requirement by governmental or regulatory bodies, legal proceedings or other key external constituents (e.g., investor, industry analysts, media, etc.) If travel is required for purposes other than those listed above, approval by the SLT or a designated delegate is required prior to booking. These type of travel requests will only be approved when business activities cannot be successfully accomplished through conference calls, webinars, video conferencing or other alternatives. Business units may impose greater controls than required by this policy, but never less. An override to this policy will only exist when billable project travel is approved by and will be charged to the client in full. Certain countries may have additional policy requirements because of regulatory or statutory requirements. Booking travel through a company approved travel management company (the “TMC”) or online booking tool (the “OBT”) benefits FIS directly, as greater volumes generate larger discount rates for air, hotel and rental cars. Reservations made through a company approved TMC or OBT also provide FIS visibility to your itinerary should a travel related emergency arise. FIS Internal Use Only Page 5 of 18 Published Date August 16, 2018 DocuSign Envelope ID: 25CBC7F9-E170-42CA-B09A-E20B5FC8600D Personal travel may not be booked through the TMC or OBT. FIS assumes no obligation to reimburse employees for expenses that are not in compliance with this policy, are excessive and/or erroneous in nature. This includes corporate credit card and/or out-of-pocket purchases made for non-travel related goods and services detailed in the Corporate Credit Card Standard of this policy. Compliance with this policy will be monitored and exceptions reported to Executive Leadership Team (the “ELT”) and SLT. Repeat policy violations and/or fraudulent activity will result in loss of travel and corporate credit card privileges and/or possible termination. FIS managers and executives who have employees who travel or entertain in the normal course of company business have primary responsibility and authority for supporting and ensuring compliance with this policy. Managers are expected to educate and guide employees to ensure expenses submitted for approval are legitimate, reasonable, timely and compliant with the policy. Disciplinary action, up to and including termination, may be taken against a manager, who should have known about a violation by employees under his/her supervision or did not act promptly to report and correct a violation. The Corporate Travel department has responsibility for interpreting provisions of the policy. 09.01.01 Traveler Profile A “Traveler Profile” is required before making travel arrangements through an OBT, where applicable or a TMC. Data such as frequent traveler programs, seat preferences, corporate credit card and emergency contact information are securely stored, eliminating the need to re-enter information each time you make a reservation. 09.01.02 Travel Arrangements FIS has designated TMC’s and OBT’s that exclusively handle or allow self-service travel booking including airline, hotel and car rental. Booking reservations using the applicable and appropriate agency is mandatory. Travel booked directly with the carrier, either by direct contact or via the internet through any other suppliers such as Expedia, Orbitz, Priceline, etc. will not be reimbursed. Basic, single destination trips should be booked via the OBT where applicable. Employees should call the TMC for more complex trips with multi-destinations, mixed booking classes, etc. to ensure accuracy and cost efficiency. For employee convenience, a travel itinerary will be provided by the TMC via e-mail. If after-hour emergency travel arrangements are required, contact the phone number on your itinerary. 09.01.02.01 Non-Employee Travel A non-employee is defined as, but not limited to, interviewees, speakers or contractors. When possible, all non-employee travel paid for by FIS should be booked through an FIS TMC to ensure the lowest travel expenses. The travel agent may ask you for information including the following: reason for travel, who will be paying for the travel, traveler’s name and contact information, email address, destination of travel, air, hotel, and car details. 09.01.02.02 Travel to High Risk Areas Business travel to certain countries is comprehensively prohibited while other countries are subject to restrictions including preapprovals. See the Country Risk Policy for additional information. International SOS FIS has partnered with International SOS (the “ISOS”) to keep our global workforce healthy, safe, and secure. FIS currently captures travel data from many global TMC’s for our risk and security teams. If you are in a region that does not FIS Internal Use Only Page 6 of 18 Published Date August 16, 2018 DocuSign Envelope ID: 25CBC7F9-E170-42CA-B09A-E20B5FC8600D have a dedicated TMC, you are required to create a travel profile in ISOS and ensure trip details are recorded. Details can either be added manually or by forwarding travel itineraries to ISOS. Please visit FIS & Me for further guidance on this process and www.internationalsos.com for more details on how the ISOS program works. FIS Membership Number for ISOS: 11BYCA092933 09.01.02.03 Continuity of Operations To guard against the consequences of a common disaster and to safeguard the continuity of FIS operations, travel by employees on the same airplane, automobile, train or other common carrier is restricted to a limit of ten FIS employees from the same cost center. The FIS designated TMC will monitor this activity and offer alternative travel information, if applicable. 09.01.02.04 Travel Fees FIS incurs transaction fees for all tickets generated through the FIS designated TMC. These fees are lower if booked via an OBT; therefore, utilizing OBT’s where available for basic single destination trips is more cost effective. All elements of your trip, such as airfare, hotel and car rentals should be included within one booking transaction whenever possible to reduce additional booking fees. 09.01.03 Air Transportation FIS has leveraged its air travel spend and strategically aligned itself with airline partners offering a valuable combination of extensive air route systems and competitive pricing. The preferred air carriers must be used where available and if offering the lowest airfare. Business travel by FIS employees is restricted to corporate and commercial aircraft. The use of private aircraft for business purposes is not allowed for any travel purposes, including client; costs will not be reimbursed. FIS’ standard baggage allowance is one checked bag (if required), unless traveling more than seven days or if it is necessary to transport approved company property. 09.01.03.01 Class of Service All travel segments will be booked at the lowest fare. A segment is defined as one takeoff and one landing. FIS travelers will adhere to the following class of service requirements: • Travel segments less than or equal to 5 hours will be booked in economy class • Travel segments greater than 5 hours may be booked in premium economy/economy comfort or the equivalent if the option is available on your route • Travel segments greater than 10 hours may be booked in business class, unless your manager places further budgetary restrictions on your travel • Multiple Stop/Destination Trips: If you have a business trip which includes multiple destinations and/or flight segments each segment should be booked in the relevant booking cabin class as per the guidelines above. A combined ticket booked in the same cabin class is permitted if this does not incur any additional cost to the company. Employees should contact the Travel Management Company for more complex trips • First-class travel may not be booked and is not permitted under this policy If the travel is billable, follow the client contract/SOW regards to class of service. FIS approved travel arrangements, while on route, may not be changed for personal convenience if the result is an increase in the cost to FIS. FIS Internal Use Only Page 7 of 18 Published Date August 16, 2018 DocuSign Envelope ID: 25CBC7F9-E170-42CA-B09A-E20B5FC8600D The SLT or designated delegate can also approve the Class of Service deviations at their discretion. 09.01.03.02 Advance Purchase Fares Airline reservations and purchases must be made at least 14 days in advance, securing the best rate possible. Exceptions to the advance purchase fares will be permitted if approved by the SLT or designated delegate and must be client related, regulatory or necessary to meet with key constituents as noted in the statement of this policy. 09.01.03.03 Non-refundable Fares/Refunds Using the lowest restricted, non-refundable fare is required. Although these types of fares may incur penalties if changed or cancelled, FIS achieves substantial savings versus the purchasing of refundable tickets. The employee and his/her manager should have a clear understanding of the restrictions, penalties and financial implications prior to altering travel plans. Cancellations should be reported to the TMC or applicable booking agency to ensure all respective travel services are also cancelled and the applicable refunds are requested and processed. The employee must ensure that refunds are properly accounted for on an expense report. Company paid refunds cannot be used for personal use. 09.01.03.04 Frequent Traveler Programs Employees are entitled to keep mileage or other benefits earned under any frequent traveler program to which they belong. Participation in these programs must not influence flight, hotel, car or train/rail selections that would result in incremental cost to FIS. 09.01.03.05 Airline Related Fees Employees will not be reimbursed for the following types of airfare fees: • Seat upgrades • Purchase of additional frequent flier miles • Airport lounge access • Airline club memberships Reimbursement will be allowed for the following airfare fees: • Southwest Airlines early bird check-in fees • The cost for a standard seat allocation if no free seat assignment is included with your airline/carrier • Standard seat upgrades for travelers with medical conditions or disabilities, pursuant the People Office guidelines 09.01.04 Car Rental Employees must use a preferred car rental supplier when renting a vehicle for company business. To minimize the number of rental cars required, employees should coordinate with others traveling to the same destination whenever the opportunity arises. 09.01.04.01 Class of Rental Cars FIS authorizes the use of intermediate (mid-size) cars. Justification should be clearly indicated on the expense report, if an alternate class is required for one of the following reasons: • Full-size rentals and minivans are allowed when transporting three or more individuals FIS Internal Use Only Page 8 of 18 Published Date August 16, 2018 DocuSign Envelope ID: 25CBC7F9-E170-42CA-B09A-E20B5FC8600D • Minivans or larger vehicles are allowed for transporting equipment that would otherwise not fit into intermediate vehicles • Upgrades are allowed when the rate is the same or lower than the intermediate rate 09.01.04.02 Rental Car Procedures FIS employees should ensure liability and collision insurance is included through the rental car agency. When renting a car within the US, regardless of origin, FIS has liability and collision included with contracts with Avis, Hertz and Enterprise car rental agencies. Therefore, when utilizing Avis, Hertz and Enterprise in the U.S., employees should always decline insurance when renting a vehicle. If additional coverage is elected, it is at the employee’s expense. However, if one of those three rental agencies is not being used, the employee is required to take liability and collision insurance. When renting a car within Canada, regardless of origin, FIS has liability and collision included in contracts with Avis and Hertz. The cost of a rental car will not be reimbursed for weekend or holiday travel unless the car is required and used for company business during that time. Employees must obey all applicable state and federal laws and traffic regulations worldwide. If an employee driving a rental vehicle is involved in an accident as a result of, or is cited for, driving while legally intoxicated, under the influence of narcotics, driving recklessly, or willfully disobeying traffic laws, the employee may be subject to disciplinary action up to and including termination. Fines for parking and/or any moving violations are not reimbursable. 09.01.04.03 Business Related Auto Claims In the event of an accident, promptly take the following steps: • If possible, move the vehicle to a safe location out of the way of traffic. Call for medical attention if anyone is hurt • Secure the names and addresses of drivers and occupants of any vehicles involved, their operator's license numbers, insurance company names and policy numbers, as well as the names and addresses of injured persons and witnesses. Do not discuss who is at fault or sign anything for anyone except an authorized representative of Fidelity National Information Services, LLC, a police officer, or a representative of Sedgwick CMS (our claims adjusting company) • Immediately notify your supervisor and email Insurance@fisglobal.com • If you are in your personal vehicle on company business, follow the instructions you received for accident reporting from your personal insurance company o In the event of an accident with a personal vehicle for FIS business, the employee and employee’s insurance company are responsible for damages to the employee’s car. Please refer to the employee handbook “Use of Vehicles for Company Business” section for more information o If you are in a rental car on company business, follow the instructions included in your service contract for accident reporting o When there is theft of or damage to your vehicle only, and you did not witness the damage to the vehicle, you must notify the local police department immediately. Follow claim reporting instructions above. Please visit FIS and Me for more information. 09.01.04.04 Rental Car Fees Employees will not be reimbursed for the following types of fees: • Paid upgrades FIS Internal Use Only Page 9 of 18 Published Date August 16, 2018 DocuSign Envelope ID: 25CBC7F9-E170-42CA-B09A-E20B5FC8600D • Satellite radio 09.01.04.05 Rental Car Refueling Fuel charges are reimbursable if rental cars are returned with a full tank of gas. The traveler should not accept the fueling option provided by the rental car company. 09.01.05 Other Ground Transportation Travel by Personal Automobile Generally, a rental car must be used if traveling more than 400 miles in total. Travelers should evaluate whether a rental car is more economical than other means of transportation, such as air travel, personal vehicle/mileage reimbursement or rail options. 09.01.05.01 Rail Travel Rail travel service is permitted if it is the most economical means of travel. Where available rail travel should be booked in advance via the OBT or dedicated company rail booking URL. If not, available rail travel can be made direct with the rail carrier/station. Employees are responsible for cancelling rail reservations via the original booking source and should ensure all applicable refunds are received and processed in an expense report. All rail travel should be standard class at the lowest possible fare bar any regional approved exceptions. Upgrades will not be reimbursed. 09.01.05.02 Travel by Personal Automobile Generally, a rental car must be used if traveling more than 400 miles in total. Travelers should evaluate whether a rental car is more economical than other means of transportation, such as air travel, personal vehicle or rail options. 09.01.05.03 Transportation to/from the Airport Whenever possible, employees should utilize the lowest cost of transportation service to/from the airport. Airport and hotel shuttle bus service is usually more cost effective than a taxi and should be used whenever feasible. Taxis can be used when time constraints justify or regular airport transportation is not an option. These forms of transportation should be shared by employees whenever possible. Travel by personal car is permitted. Employees who commute to work daily using a personal car and travel to/from the airport in their personal car for business trips can be reimbursed for the difference between the mileage of a normal daily commute from home to work and the commute from home to the airport. 09.01.05.04 Airport Parking Employees must use the most economical option for airport parking. Economy or an “off-airport” lot is typically less expensive. 09.01.05.05 Toll Charges Necessary toll charges are reimbursable under this policy. 09.01.06 Lodging Employees required to stay overnight on authorized business are required to select a preferred FIS hotel within close vicinity of the business or client visited. Membership to a frequent guest program should not influence selection if the result is an increase in the cost to FIS. 09.01.06.01 Preferred Hotels FIS Internal Use Only Page 10 of 18 Published Date August 16, 2018 DocuSign Envelope ID: 25CBC7F9-E170-42CA-B09A-E20B5FC8600D FIS has negotiated preferred rates at hotels worldwide. Employees must use the FIS preferred hotels and book through an FIS designated TMC and/or OBT, whenever possible. Please visit FIS and Me for a list of preferred hotels. If there are issues finding a preferred hotel where you may be traveling, it is acceptable to: • Select a local TMC negotiated hotel or suitable hotel within the policy guidelines • Contact a designated TMC for assistance booking alternative accommodations Both methods will record your reservation and ensure your trip is tracked for compliance and safety purposes. Exceptions for booking hotel accommodations through a designated TMC or OBT include, but are not limited to: • Conferences or other events where accommodations were pre-arranged • Stay with friends or family • Client booked hotel • An approved TMC is not available in your region • Travel destination is in a remote location where no travel industry represented hotels are available • Extended stays 09.01.06.02 Extended Stay /Temporary An extended stay or temporary assignment is defined as 4 or more weeks away from the employee’s regular place of business, at the request of FIS, for purposes of carrying out company-related activities. Please contact your Human Resources representative for additional details. 09.01.06.03 Guaranteed Arrival/No-Show Fees Employees must cancel reservations by the specified cancelation policy of the hotel to avoid no-show charges. Early check-out fees may apply for departure prior to original check-out date, therefore please plan accordingly. Consideration should be made when choosing pre-paid, non-refundable hotel rates in order to avoid any financial implications if changed or cancelled. Pre-paid, non-refundable hotel rates while traveling on business are not recommended. If your current booking method allows you to choose restricted hotel rates, please seek approval from your manager (to consider cost saving versus possible financial risk should your trip be changed or cancelled), before booking. 09.01.06.04 Suite/Executive Floor Use It is FIS’ standard that no additional costs will be incurred by the company involving suite/executive floor use. 09.01.06.05 Combined Business/Personal Travel It is the employee’s responsibility to obtain rates/costs from a designated TMC when combining business and personal travel. The employee must deduct any personal charges from the total cost of the business trip. If combined with business, employees must have management approval prior to the trip. If vacation and/or personal days are included within the trip, all related costs must be at the employee’s expense. 09.01.07 Laundry/Dry Cleaning The reasonable actual costs of such services are allowable when travel exceeds seven days. In addition, only items laundered during the trip will be reimbursed. Laundry completed in anticipation of a trip or after the employee returns does not apply. FIS Internal Use Only Page 11 of 18 Published Date August 16, 2018 DocuSign Envelope ID: 25CBC7F9-E170-42CA-B09A-E20B5FC8600D 09.01.08 International Health Screenings To help ensure the well-being of FIS employees when traveling, in rare cases, a pre-travel medical health screening assessment may be helpful. The CDC website provides more information regarding medical requirements for high risk countries. If necessary, obtain applicable shots from your doctor or the local health department, and submit an expense report for reimbursement. 09.01.09 Immigration Requirements All employees who travel for FIS internationally, must ensure that they are compliant with all immigration legislation. Breaches of immigration compliance will be taken seriously and could result in disciplinary action, in accordance with FIS’ Code of Business Conduct and Ethics Program. Employees must ensure that they have a current passport and a visa/work authorization (if required) that is suitable for the activities to be performed in the overseas country. It is recommended that an employee has at least 6 months’ validity left on their passport from the date of travel. Processing times to obtain visas and passports can vary greatly based on location and time of year. Employees must obtain the necessary immigration documentation prior to travel to ensure sufficient processing time. Information on estimated processing times and fees for visas by country can be found on FIS & ME. Fees are reimbursable if you are required to obtain a passport/visa for business travel. 09.01.10 Global Travel and Entertainment Policy-Corporate Credit Card and Expense Reimbursement Standard FIS utilizes American Express© for all applicable business travel including, but not limited to: air, hotel, rental car, entertainment and meals where corporate credit card programs are offered. If you are a permanent employee and a business traveler, FIS encourages you to apply for a corporate credit card. All employees approved for the corporate credit card are required to use the corporate credit card for business travel and in accordance with this standard. 09.01.10.01 Standard Employees traveling with a corporate credit card must use that corporate credit card for all approved and allowable company-related travel and expenses. Using a personal credit card or cash is permitted when: • The FIS corporate credit card is not accepted • Locally, there is a company central billing card (or Business Travel Account/BTA) in place for specific services, such as air travel, hotel or car rental that has been pre-approved The following purchase and/or expense types are not allowed via any FIS corporate credit card, personal credit card or cash: • Capital purchases or fixed assets • Cash advances • Club memberships • Computer hardware and software FIS Internal Use Only Page 12 of 18 Published Date August 16, 2018 DocuSign Envelope ID: 25CBC7F9-E170-42CA-B09A-E20B5FC8600D • Drugs/narcotics, including over the counter medication/tobacco • Independent contractors • Donations - see the charitable contributions information located on FIS and Me • Office supplies • Furniture and fixtures including carpeting and wall coverings - should be requested through the local Facilities Coordination Center • Hotel no-show cancellation charges (unless company directed) o Exceptions may apply only if: ■ Cancellation was beyond the employee’s control to cancel within the cancellation policy ■ Company directed cancellation o Evidence or substantiation will be required for reimbursement of cancellation • Late fees, penalties • Movies (hotel or in-flight) • Newspapers and/or non-trade or job specific subscriptions • Personal entertainment • Personal expenses or purchases (including, but not limited to) o Expenses or personal debts o Clothing, food, etc. o Home internet o Home telephone or cellular bills o Personal hygiene related items o Spouse/Companion and/or family travel o Valuables misplaced or stolen while traveling • Political Contributions • Remote employee or Telecommuter Expenses o Office equipment o Furniture o Computer hardware and software • Tuition reimbursement - see tuition assistance on FIS and Me • Traffic or parking fines • Transactions made at “adult entertainment” venues o These transactions include, but are not limited to, meals/beverages at “adult entertainment” venues • Vendor invoices • Wireless devices • Wire transfers or money orders Deliberately failing to adhere to this standard may result in disciplinary action up to and including termination. 09.01.10.02 Employee-incurred Expense and Reimbursement It is the responsibility of the employee incurring business expenses to properly complete and submit an expense report in a timely manner. It is not FIS' responsibility to manage an employee's expense reports. While traveling on company business, every employee is charged with the responsibility of treating the company's funds as his/her own funds. FIS' goal is to contract expenses at a responsible level while ensuring that we received adequate value for the travel dollars expended. FIS Internal Use Only Page 13 of 18 Published Date August 16, 2018 DocuSign Envelope ID: 25CBC7F9-E170-42CA-B09A-E20B5FC8600D Expense reports must be submitted and approved by management within 30 days of the completion of a business trip or business transaction. Approving managers must log into the respective expense reporting tool or manually approve reimbursement requests after validating transactions are legitimate, reasonable and comply with policy. All late fees, delinquency charges, suspension fees, finance charges and any other fees charged by American Express are the cardholder's responsibility and should not be approved unless the fee is specifically related to a system failure. Employees will be reimbursed for any authorized, actual, and reasonable expenses incurred while conducting company business or while traveling on authorized company business. 09.01.10.03 Misconduct Negligence in reporting and properly substantiating business expenditures or failure to adhere to any other provisions of FIS standard may result in disciplinary action up to and including termination. In addition, the deliberate falsification of expense records, claims or participation in any other fraudulent or deceptive actions may result in disciplinary action up to and including termination as well as the initiation of legal action. Such misconduct is a violation of company standard on the grounds of misconduct as defined in FIS' Code of Business Conduct and Ethics. Dishonesty, misrepresentation of facts or misrepresentation of facts in obtaining employee benefits and privileges, or the falsification of any document or FIS record(s) is prohibited. This includes improper expense reporting, inappropriate use of the corporate credit card, and any other unauthorized activity that is outside of the scope of the FIS Corporate Credit Card Standard. Such actions may result in disciplinary action up to and including termination of employment. Please note that negligence or other serious misconduct on the part of those responsible for approving expense reports and other related documents may also result in disciplinary action up to and including termination of employment. Adult Entertainment Adult entertainment is not a reimbursable expense. Regardless of whether this might be an accepted business practice in some countries, FIS will not tolerate the use of Company funds at adult entertainment establishments or for adult entertainment provided at some other location. “Adult entertainment” is defined as nightclub type entertainment that includes shows or other activities with an overtly sexual content (e.g. topless bars, strip clubs, etc.). “Adult entertainment” is also defined as any entertainment which, were it reported (with pictures) in a newspaper of general circulation in the local community where any attendee at the event lives, might be seen by a substantial segment of the community to reflect badly upon the Company or the attendees at the function. Use of the FIS Corporate Credit Card or submission of cash receipts for expenditures related to “adult entertainment” (business or personal) is prohibited. 09.01.10.04 Delinquent Accounts FIS reserves the right to deny expense reimbursements that are greater than 30 days old. Timely reconciliation and submission practices are necessary to ensure company expenses are booked and client related costs are billed for the appropriate accounting periods. 09.01.10.05 Suspension Timelines American Express will suspend any credit card account that reaches 90-days past due and will not reinstate until the delinquent balance is paid in full. 09.01.11 Expense Reimbursement FIS Internal Use Only Page 14 of 18 Published Date August 16, 2018 DocuSign Envelope ID: 25CBC7F9-E170-42CA-B09A-E20B5FC8600D Approval Authority Guidelines No employee may act as an authorized approver for his/her own expense report. The approval of at least one authorized person, usually the employee’s manager, is required before reimbursements will be made against such documents. To minimize the risk of inappropriate approval, employees should avoid booking or charging any travel or non-travel related expenses for his/her direct line of management (those who would be approving their expense reports). If an employee is required to book travel for his/her manager, evidence in the form of an email approval from the manager’s manager must be provided with the expense report as evidence of pre-approval for booking on the manager’s behalf. Failure to provide such evidence will result in rejection of the expense report and further investigation of expenses. Required Receipt Documentation Itemized receipt and supporting documentation are critical for expedient audit processing, billing clients for appropriate costs and ensuring compliance. The following receipt criteria will apply: • Itemized receipts for US-based employee travel related expenses greater than or equal to $50 USD, regardless of payment method • Itemized receipts for all non-US based employee travel related expenses, regardless of payment method Documentation requirements may change at the company’s discretion. Managers and/or clients may request additional documentation outside of the FIS receipt requirements. Acceptable Receipts An acceptable receipt is a document that contains the following information: • Transaction Date • Merchant Name • Amount of item purchased (itemized receipt that provides the description and amount paid for each item(s); summary of total copy is not an acceptable receipt) • Form of Payment (cash, check or charge) • Indication that the purchase was paid Airfare: Receipt must include the traveler name, ticket number and ticket amount (An itemized Itinerary or OBT invoice is an acceptable receipt) Lodging: An itemized receipt or hotel folio that includes the room rate, tax, internet fees, food purchases, etc. Rental Car: Detailed/itemized receipt for the car rental that includes the breakdown of costs, size of the vehicle and tax. There must be justification provided for any upgrades listed on the receipt and expense report submitted (online or manual) Meals: Itemized receipt of meal charges along with the credit card or cash register receipt (meals will be reimbursed for actual cost; per diems are not permitted unless required by client SOW or specific countries mandate) FIS Internal Use Only Page 15 of 18 Published Date August 16, 2018 DocuSign Envelope ID: 25CBC7F9-E170-42CA-B09A-E20B5FC8600D Other: Cardholder copy of the record of charge or a cash register receipt; itemization required Unacceptable Receipts: Personal check copies, company statements or quotes and generic "tear tab" or hand written receipts will not be accepted Missing Receipts No exception will be granted for missing airline, hotel or lodging and/or rental car expenses. Travelers should make every attempt to locate or request duplicate receipt copies in the instance receipts for travel and entertainment purchases have been misplaced or lost. Obtaining these receipts prior to submitting the expense reimbursement request will prevent payment delay to the employee and/or the corporate credit card provider. Expense Categories Meals While Traveling on Business FIS will reimburse meals for employees who travel away from home. Actuals should be expensed unless specified by a Client’s Statement of Work (SOW) or when a country specifically mandates per diem. The daily maximum rate or the total allowance for meals (breakfast, lunch and dinner) by country are available on FIS and Me. Travelers are expected to take advantage of breakfasts included with hotel stays whenever possible. Additionally, consider a pro-rated daily maximum based on the timing of business travel. The number of attendees along with attendee first and last names, should be included within the expense report details. Per Diem travel FIS does not pay per diem for meals with the exception to the following circumstances: • Client SOW requires • Per diems are required based on country specific mandates (list available on FIS and Me) If certain meals are provided during travel, the per diem should be reduced by 25% for breakfast or lunch and 50% for dinner. Meals and Entertainment with Clients and Prospects FIS will reimburse reasonable business entertainment expenses providing the entertainment is consistent with FIS’ corporate policy. Business meals or entertainment must be appropriate to the circumstances and business purpose, reasonable in nature, and may not be lavish or extravagant. For additional information, please refer to the FIS Code of Business Conduct and Ethics policy. To be deductible for tax purposes, any business entertaining must occur in a place conducive to a business discussion, or must have been immediately preceded or followed by substantial and bona-fide business discussion. Entertainment expenses include events such as dining, theater and sporting events. Meals and Entertainment with Other Employees FIS Internal Use Only Page 16 of 18 Published Date August 16, 2018 DocuSign Envelope ID: 25CBC7F9-E170-42CA-B09A-E20B5FC8600D Entertainment expenses incurred while in the presence of only FIS employees are not reimbursable unless they are incurred for a legitimate business purpose. Team events or gatherings will be considered an exception to this policy. In many instances, a team member, executive administrator or other party will coordinate the function on behalf of a larger group of participants. Acceptable events include, but not limited to: • Working luncheon meetings • Project lunches/dinners • Team luncheons • Sourcing events • Client meetings • Suppliers meetings • Meeting with other key constituents FIS sponsored events or conferences coordinated by the Marketing and Events teams will require evidence of the advertised event, attendee list (meeting invite or attendance roster acceptable) with valid receipts supporting the costs of the event. Event expenses should be charged on a meeting card whenever possible. Gratuities Tips and gratuities should be limited to those situations and services where such payments are normal practice. The amount or percentage of any gratuity paid should not exceed that which is reasonable and customary for the type of service. Business Gifts Business gifts purchased for clients are subject to limitations and require registration in accordance with FIS Code of Business Conduct and Ethics Policy. The information below is required for expense reporting purposes: • Total gift cost • Date the gift was given • Gift description • Business relationship, client/business name, recipient name, job title • Business purpose, including the nature of the benefit The purchase of client gifts should be limited to those employees authorized to entertain clients as a part of normal business relationships. The intent of gift giving should be to affirm relationships in the most professional manner and never be personal in nature. Examples of acceptable client gifts are listed below. • Cards or calendar • FIS branded items • Gift certificates for retail or restaurants • Fruit or food baskets • Flowers or plants FIS Internal Use Only Page 17 of 18 Published Date August 16, 2018 DocuSign Envelope ID: 25CBC7F9-E170-42CA-B09A-E20B5FC8600D Expense Report Audits and Exception Reporting The ELT supports these policies and the enforcement of policy compliance. All expense reimbursement will be monitored as they relate to the policy guidelines and exceptions will be reported to both the SLT and ELT. FIS will conduct audits to ensure policy compliance, as well as confirmation that the required receipts were submitted and are legible. Any report(s) identified with errors will be rejected and the employee will be responsible for resubmission. If the rejection is related to insufficient documentation, then it can be resubmitted with the requested information. If the rejection relates to a policy violation, the audit team will communicate recommended “next steps”, which may require notifying or escalating to the appropriate SLT member for additional review. In addition, an employee will be personally responsible to pay for unapproved items (herein known as “policy violations”) if money was spent outside of the guidelines established within this policy. Additional Resources Expense Type Definitions Listed in Oracle Internet Expense (OIE) Please review allowable expense types on the Travel page on FIS and Me Employee Gifts Please review the “Taxable Prize or Award/Gift Form” on FIS and Me. Telecommuting Policy Please review the "Telecommuting Policy" on FIS and Me. Wireless Policy Please review the "Mobile Device Policy" and "Mobile Device Operations Standard" on FIS and Me. All FIS employees, contractors and applicable third parties are required to adhere to established policies and standards. Violation of FIS policies and/or standards may result in disciplinary action up to and including termination. Any suspected violation of an FIS policy or standard should be reported to either a management representative, the People Office representative or to the FIS Ethics Officer or FIS Chief Compliance Officer (CorporateCompliance@fisglobal.com). Violations may also be reported using the FIS Ethics Web site (www.fnisethics.com) or Hotline. FIS does not tolerate any retaliation against anyone who, in good faith, reports a violation of FIS policy or law or cooperates with an investigation. To report a potential security incident, you should email the FIS Security Incident Response Team (FSIRT) at FSIRT@fisglobal.com. For urgent or critical security incidents, you should call 414.357.FSIRT (3747) (U.S. and International). FIS Internal Use Only Page 18 of 18 Published Date August 16, 2018

DocuSign Envelope ID: 03DED725-953C-4FAC-8E09-B444761321F2 CORPORATE VISIONS 3875 Hopyard Rd, Ste. 275 Pleasanton, CA 94588 925-401-7990 www.corporatevisions.com EXHIBIT A STATEMENT OF WORK NO.: 10075 This Statement of Work No. 10075 (this “SOW”) is a SOW under the APPENDIX A attached hereto (the “Agreement”) between Corporate Visions, Inc. (“CVI”) and FIS (“Customer”) and is effective as of the last date signed below (the “SOW Effective Date”). Capitalized terms used in this SOW but not defined herein shall have the meanings given in the Agreement. This and all SOWs shall be subject to and governed by the terms and conditions set forth under the Agreement, unless specifically set forth herein. Customer requires PO [X] No [ ] Yes* * If PO is required, it must be received before delivery of Intellectual Property. PO #  Rep: Joe Kozub Customer Representative: Sona Jepsen FIS 340 Madison Avenue Floors 6, 7, & 8 New York, NY 10173 Product: 3 Consulting Days Dates: To be determined Location: To be determined Pricing: $10,000 per day, plus consultants’ travel and lodging expenses. The total value of this SOW is $30,000**. All amounts are payable in US Dollars. **This value does not include travel and expenses. All POs for SOWs with Workshop deliveries should include an estimated travel and expense amount of at least $3,000 for domestic delivery and $10,000 for international delivery per consultant. The pricing listed in this SOW is valid until December 30, 2016. If this SOW is not signed by December 30, 2016, pricing may no longer be valid. Confirmed dates are valid only upon a signed SOW and an email confirmation as set forth below. Payment Terms: $30,000 will be invoiced upon execution of SOW. All invoices will be due net 30 days from invoice date. NOTE: Customer shall be responsible for and shall bear all applicable sales, use, excise, personal property and value added taxes, or taxes of a similar nature imposed by any federal, state, provincial, or local government, or other taxing authority on all items, goods and/or services being paid for by Customer to CVI under this SOW. Corporate Visions, Inc., 3875 Hopyard Rd, Ste. 275, Pleasanton, CA 94588 Confidential | Page 1 Rev. 10/16 DocuSign Envelope ID: 03DED725-953C-4FAC-8E09-B444761321F2 Once travel is booked Customer is responsible for all travel costs and/or fees associated with any cancellation. A convenience fee of 3% will be added to all Customer credit card transactions used to pay for Services. CVI WILL PROVIDE • A pre-event call to better determine customer objective, appropriate process flow, discuss the tentative agenda, and participants. • Three Consulting events for one day each using Power Messaging® intellectual property. • One CVI certified consultant to facilitate the Consulting event. (CVI consultant and support staff will be assigned based upon availability and requirements, and is at CVI’s discretion.) CUSTOMER WILL PROVIDE • Access to all relevant competitive data and current messaging examples • One event champion/ point-of-contact to provide feedback and sign-off on any event deliverables in accordance with engagement project plan. • A coordinator to plan and coordinate the event. A CVI Project Manager will assist the coordinator with details. • A facility large enough to accommodate Customer’s entire group, CVI’s Consultant(s) and any support staff. • If Customer attendees use special equipment, e.g. slide projectors, demo equipment or on-line modem hookups via phone lines in their presentations, Customer should also make this equipment available. • Customer agrees to grant the rights to CVI to use its company’s name, relevant images and successful results in the normal course of promotion of sales and marketing activities. CANCELLATIONS & RESCHEDULING TERMS Notwithstanding anything contained in the Agreement to the contrary, in no event shall Customer have any right to cancel or terminate all or any portion of this SOW. Upon signature of this SOW, Customer remains fully responsible for the payment of all fees and expenses hereunder and Customer shall be required to pay such amounts without deduction, setoff or delay. All amounts shall be due and payable in accordance with the terms of this SOW and the Agreement. CVI reserves the right to suspend services (including but not limited to CVI Workshops) and delivery of any deliverables in the event of Customer’s non - payment or late payment. When Customer signs this SOW with dates to be determined, the engagement is not considered scheduled until there is email confirmation between Customer and CVI’s Project Manager confirming the dates and location of the engagement. On occasion, Customer may need to reschedule an event. In those situations, the following terms apply: Cancellation & Rescheduling Notice Cancellation & Rescheduling Terms and Fees
Customer cancels more than 30 days prior to a scheduled event/Workshop date and sends a written reschedule request within 30 days of cancellation: CVI will use reasonable efforts to reschedule the cancelled event/Workshop on or around the date proposed by Customer. Any actual, reasonable expenses incurred up to the time of cancellation by CVI as a result of such cancellation will be invoiced upon cancellation and are due and payable per the terms of the Agreement.
Corporate Visions, Inc., 3875 Hopyard Rd, Ste. 275, Pleasanton, CA 94588 Confidential | Page 2 Rev. 10/16 DocuSign Envelope ID: 03DED725-953C-4FAC-8E09-B444761321F2 Customer cancels and does not send a written reschedule request within 30 days of cancellation; or Customer cancels without notice or less than 30 days prior to Workshop/event date: 100% of SOW fees for the cancelled event/Workshop and any actual, reasonable expenses incurred up to the time of cancellation by CVI as a result of the cancellation will be invoiced upon cancellation and are due and payable per the terms of the Agreement. In addition, if Customer cancels within 21 days of the event/Workshops, CVI may be invoiced up to a $2,500 per day non-refundable consulting fee. If this cost is incurred by CVI, Customer will be invoiced upon delivery of the rescheduled event/Workshop. If Workshop is not rescheduled, no fee will be charged.
Travel and Expenses CVI will use Customer’s travel policy except that the following CVI travel policy terms will prevail over the Agreement: Travel: Coach class airfare or auto mileage for domestic travel. Business class airfare for international flights. Auto Rental: Full-size car. Meals: Up to $100 per CVI consultant assigned, per day, in the USA. As incurred, internationally. Hotel: A quality hotel. Misc.: Tolls, porters, mileage to airports, airport parking, etc. Shipping: All course materials and seminar equipment, to and from event. Schedule changes: CVI will book travel as soon as possible after confirmation of the engagement date(s) but not within thirty (30) days of the event. Customer is responsible for paying all rescheduling fees due to date changes made after the engagement date(s) have been confirmed. Corporate Visions, Inc., 3875 Hopyard Rd, Ste. 275, Pleasanton, CA 94588 Confidential | Page 3 Rev. 10/16 DocuSign Envelope ID: 03DED725-953C-4FAC-8E09-B444761321F2 Billing Contact and Instructions: Invoice delivery (check one): [ ] Email Email Address:  [ ] Follow Purchase Order Billing Direction [ ] Online Billing Portal URL or system name (Required if Yes):  [ ] Postal Mail Mailing address (Required if Yes):    The term of this SOW shall be twelve (12) months from the Effective Date. All Services must be delivered within the SOW Term at which time, all unpaid fees and approved expenses shall be due and payable. IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the Parties hereto have caused this SOW to be executed by their duly authorized representatives as of the SOW Effective Date. AGREED TO AND ACCEPTED BY: CUSTOMER Customer Signature: Customer Name: Ellyn Raftery Customer Title: Date Signed by Customer: AGREED TO AND ACCEPTED BY: CORPORATE VISIONS INC. >—DocuSigned by: CVI Signature '-FC6C233B59344DB... CVI Name: Glori a Fan CVI Title: chief Financial Officer Date Signed by CVI: 12/19/2016 Fax for returning signed SOW (please include all pages): 775-201-1789 Corporate Visions, Inc., 3875 Hopyard Rd, Ste. 275, Pleasanton, CA 94588 Confidential | Page 4 Rev. 10/16 DocuSign Envelope ID: 03DED725-953C-4FAC-8E09-B444761321F2 APPENDIX A TERMS AND CONDITIONS If no other services agreement has been executed by the parties as of the Effective Date of the attached Statement of Work #10075 (“SOW”), then the following terms shall apply to this SOW: 1. Scope. CVI shall provide to Customer the Services, Licensed Products and the Deliverables (as defined below and set forth in the SOW, as applicable) in accordance with the requirements for such Services and Deliverables in the SOW which these terms and conditions govern. The SOW and this Appendix A (collectively, the “Agreement”) constitutes the entire agreement between Customer and CVI with respect to the subject matter of the SOW. 2. Term. This Agreement shall begin on the Effective Date and continue for a period concurrent with the term of the SOW, unless sooner terminated. 3. Confidentiality. “Confidential Information” means and includes any trade secrets or non-public information and any and all data, documents and materials provided or made available, whether visually or orally, to a Party, its personnel or subcontractors by the disclosing Party (“Disclosing Party”) to the receiving Party (“Receiving Party”) under or in connection with this Agreement and that is marked or indicated at the time of disclosure or observation as being “Confidential”, or which would be deemed by a reasonable person to be confidential or proprietary in nature, or which, if disclosed verbally, is identified by the Disclosing Party in writing as being confidential or proprietary in nature within 30 days of the disclosure to the Receiving Party. For purposes of this Agreement, Confidential Information of CVI is referred to as “CVI Confidential Information” and Confidential Information of Customer is referred to as “Customer Confidential Information”. 4. License Grant, Ownership and Restrictions. Subject to Customer’s compliance with this Agreement, 4.1 Deliverables. Customer shall own all right, title and interest in and to the Deliverables, but specifically excluding any portion of the CVI pre-owned and developed intellectual property including all intellectual property rights in and to the Customer feedback, Online Service, Materials, methodology and workshops and all derivatives of the foregoing (“CVI Property) which may be embodied or included in the Deliverables (the tangible work product identified in this SOW which CVI creates using its methodology.) 4.2 CVI Property. If any CVI Property is embodied or incorporated into a Deliverable, CVI will, subject to Customer’s compliance with the terms of this SOW, grant Customer a non-exclusive, license to use and display the CVI Property solely as embodied or incorporated into the Deliverable. All rights, title and interest in and to the CVI Property are and shall remain the sole and exclusive property of CVI. CVI reserves all rights in and to the CVI Property not expressly granted to Customer and Customer employees. This agreement does not grant Customer or any of its employees or agents any rights or implied licenses other than those expressly granted herein. 4.4. Materials. CVI grants to the Customer employees a personal, limited, non-exclusive license to use the Materials in the form and format provided by CVI and solely for use by such employees during their employment with Customer. CVI shall retain any and all intellectual property rights embodied in said Materials (collectively, the audio-visual and/or visual items made available to Customer employees as part of the Online Service or a workshop, which may include, audio-visual works, books, diagrams, guides, kits and other materials.) 4.5 CVI Property and Materials shall be collectively known on the SOW as the “Licensed Products.” 5. Indemnification. 5.1. CVI shall defend, indemnify and hold harmless Customer and its officers, directors, employees, and shall pay, as incurred, all liabilities, damages, costs, fees and expenses (including reasonable attorney's fees) relating to any third party claim, action, suit or other proceeding: (a) that Work Products paid for by Customer and used by Customer in accordance with the terms of this Agreement constitute an infringement of any U.S. patent, copyright, trademark or trade secret; (b); or (c) relating to any claim for personal injury or damage to tangible property caused by any CVI Personnel while performing services on the premises of Customer; provided however, that CVI shall not be liable for or obligated to indemnify or defend any third party claims arising out of Customer’s, or any of Authorized Users’: (a) alteration or modification of the Materials; (b) combination of the Materials or Deliverables with any other information, materials or products; (c) use of the Materials or Deliverables in a manner not authorized under this Agreement; or export of any Materials or Deliverables in violation of applicable export control regulations. THE FOREGOING SHALL CONSTITUTE THE CUSTOMER’S SOLE REMEDY AND CVI’S SOLE AND EXCLUSIVE LIABILITY FOR ALL INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY CLAIMS. 5.2 In the event of any alleged, actual or potential Claim, CVI will be entitled (but not obligated), at its sole option, to: (a) procure for Customer the right to continue use of the applicable Work Product; (b) replace or modify the applicable Work Product to avoid the alleged infringement or misappropriation; or (c) if CVI determines, in its sole discretion, that neither of the foregoing options are commercially reasonable, then CVI may terminate the SOW and refund Customer any fees pre-paid for the infringing Work Product. 6. Force Majeure. Neither party shall be liable for failure to comply with any of the terms of this Agreement if and to the extent that such failure has been caused solely by fire, war, insurrection, epidemic, government restrictions, force majeure or other causes beyond the control and not due to the fault of the non-performing party. If the non-performance continues for more than thirty (30) days, the party whose ability to perform has not been so affected may, by giving written notice, terminate this Agreement. 7. Miscellaneous. This Agreement shall be governed by and construed and enforced in accordance with the laws of the United States of America and the State of California, without regard to conflict of laws principles. Either party may assign its rights and obligations under this Agreement without obtaining prior written consent if said assignment is in connection with a merger, consolidation, reorganization or sale of substantially all of such party’s assets. A waiver by any Party of any breach or default will not constitute a waiver of any different or subsequent breach or default. If any part of this Agreement is invalid, illegal or unenforceable for any reason, the remainder shall remain in force and the invalid, illegal or unenforceable portion will be replaced with a valid provision appropriate to the Parties’ original intent. Customer’s name may be used in the ordinary course of CVI’s advertising or marketing promotion of CVI. Corporate Visions, Inc., 3875 Hopyard Rd, Ste. 275, Pleasanton, CA 94588 Confidential | Page 5 Rev. 10/16

In addition, if Customer cancels within 21 days of the event/Workshops, CVI may be invoiced up to a $2,500 per day non-refundable consulting fee. If this cost is incurred by CVI, Customer will be invoiced upon delivery of the rescheduled event/Workshop. If Workshop is not rescheduled, no fee will be charged.
Travel and Expenses CVI will use Customer’s travel policy except that the following CVI travel policy terms will prevail over the Agreement: Travel: Coach class airfare or auto mileage for domestic travel. Business class airfare for international flights. Auto Rental: Full-size car. Meals: Up to $100 per CVI consultant assigned, per day, in the USA. As incurred, internationally. Hotel: A quality hotel. Misc.: Tolls, porters, mileage to airports, airport parking, etc. Shipping: All course materials and seminar equipment, to and from event. Schedule changes: CVI will book travel as soon as possible after confirmation of the engagement date(s) but not within thirty (30) days of the event. Customer is responsible for paying all rescheduling fees due to date changes made after the engagement date(s) have been confirmed. Corporate Visions, Inc., 3875 Hopyard Rd, Ste. 275, Pleasanton, CA 94588 Confidential | Page 3 Rev. 10/16 DocuSign Envelope ID: 03DED725-953C-4FAC-8E09-B444761321F2 Billing Contact and Instructions: Invoice delivery (check one): [ ] Email Email Address:  [ ] Follow Purchase Order Billing Direction [ ] Online Billing Portal URL or system name (Required if Yes):  [ ] Postal Mail Mailing address (Required if Yes):    The term of this SOW shall be twelve (12) months from the Effective Date. All Services must be delivered within the SOW Term at which time, all unpaid fees and approved expenses shall be due and payable. IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the Parties hereto have caused this SOW to be executed by their duly authorized representatives as of the SOW Effective Date. AGREED TO AND ACCEPTED BY: CUSTOMER Customer Signature: Customer Name: Ellyn Raftery Customer Title: Date Signed by Customer: AGREED TO AND ACCEPTED BY: CORPORATE VISIONS INC. >—DocuSigned by: CVI Signature '-FC6C233B59344DB... CVI Name: Glori a Fan CVI Title: chief Financial Officer Date Signed by CVI: 12/19/2016 Fax for returning signed SOW (please include all pages): 775-201-1789 Corporate Visions, Inc., 3875 Hopyard Rd, Ste. 275, Pleasanton, CA 94588 Confidential | Page 4 Rev. 10/16 DocuSign Envelope ID: 03DED725-953C-4FAC-8E09-B444761321F2 APPENDIX A TERMS AND CONDITIONS If no other services agreement has been executed by the parties as of the Effective Date of the attached Statement of Work #10075 (“SOW”), then the following terms shall apply to this SOW: 1. Scope. CVI shall provide to Customer the Services, Licensed Products and the Deliverables (as defined below and set forth in the SOW, as applicable) in accordance with the requirements for such Services and Deliverables in the SOW which these terms and conditions govern. The SOW and this Appendix A (collectively, the “Agreement”) constitutes the entire agreement between Customer and CVI with respect to the subject matter of the SOW. 2. Term. This Agreement shall begin on the Effective Date and continue for a period concurrent with the term of the SOW, unless sooner terminated. 3. Confidentiality. “Confidential Information” means and includes any trade secrets or non-public information and any and all data, documents and materials provided or made available, whether visually or orally, to a Party, its personnel or subcontractors by the disclosing Party (“Disclosing Party”) to the receiving Party (“Receiving Party”) under or in connection with this Agreement and that is marked or indicated at the time of disclosure or observation as being “Confidential”, or which would be deemed by a reasonable person to be confidential or proprietary in nature, or which, if disclosed verbally, is identified by the Disclosing Party in writing as being confidential or proprietary in nature within 30 days of the disclosure to the Receiving Party. For purposes of this Agreement, Confidential Information of CVI is referred to as “CVI Confidential Information” and Confidential Information of Customer is referred to as “Customer Confidential Information”. 4. License Grant, Ownership and Restrictions. Subject to Customer’s compliance with this Agreement, 4.1 Deliverables. Customer shall own all right, title and interest in and to the Deliverables, but specifically excluding any portion of the CVI pre-owned and developed intellectual property including all intellectual property rights in and to the Customer feedback, Online Service, Materials, methodology and workshops and all derivatives of the foregoing (“CVI Property) which may be embodied or included in the Deliverables (the tangible work product identified in this SOW which CVI creates using its methodology.) 4.2 CVI Property. If any CVI Property is embodied or incorporated into a Deliverable, CVI will, subject to Customer’s compliance with the terms of this SOW, grant Customer a non-exclusive, license to use and display the CVI Property solely as embodied or incorporated into the Deliverable. All rights, title and interest in and to the CVI Property are and shall remain the sole and exclusive property of CVI. CVI reserves all rights in and to the CVI Property not expressly granted to Customer and Customer employees. This agreement does not grant Customer or any of its employees or agents any rights or implied licenses other than those expressly granted herein. 4.4. Materials. CVI grants to the Customer employees a personal, limited, non-exclusive license to use the Materials in the form and format provided by CVI and solely for use by such employees during their employment with Customer. CVI shall retain any and all intellectual property rights embodied in said Materials (collectively, the audio-visual and/or visual items made available to Customer employees as part of the Online Service or a workshop, which may include, audio-visual works, books, diagrams, guides, kits and other materials.) 4.5 CVI Property and Materials shall be collectively known on the SOW as the “Licensed Products.” 5. Indemnification. 5.1. CVI shall defend, indemnify and hold harmless Customer and its officers, directors, employees, and shall pay, as incurred, all liabilities, damages, costs, fees and expenses (including reasonable attorney's fees) relating to any third party claim, action, suit or other proceeding: (a) that Work Products paid for by Customer and used by Customer in accordance with the terms of this Agreement constitute an infringement of any U.S. patent, copyright, trademark or trade secret; (b); or (c) relating to any claim for personal injury or damage to tangible property caused by any CVI Personnel while performing services on the premises of Customer; provided however, that CVI shall not be liable for or obligated to indemnify or defend any third party claims arising out of Customer’s, or any of Authorized Users’: (a) alteration or modification of the Materials; (b) combination of the Materials or Deliverables with any other information, materials or products; (c) use of the Materials or Deliverables in a manner not authorized under this Agreement; or export of any Materials or Deliverables in violation of applicable export control regulations. THE FOREGOING SHALL CONSTITUTE THE CUSTOMER’S SOLE REMEDY AND CVI’S SOLE AND EXCLUSIVE LIABILITY FOR ALL INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY CLAIMS. 5.2 In the event of any alleged, actual or potential Claim, CVI will be entitled (but not obligated), at its sole option, to: (a) procure for Customer the right to continue use of the applicable Work Product; (b) replace or modify the applicable Work Product to avoid the alleged infringement or misappropriation; or (c) if CVI determines, in its sole discretion, that neither of the foregoing options are commercially reasonable, then CVI may terminate the SOW and refund Customer any fees pre-paid for the infringing Work Product. 6. Force Majeure. Neither party shall be liable for failure to comply with any of the terms of this Agreement if and to the extent that such failure has been caused solely by fire, war, insurrection, epidemic, government restrictions, force majeure or other causes beyond the control and not due to the fault of the non-performing party. If the non-performance continues for more than thirty (30) days, the party whose ability to perform has not been so affected may, by giving written notice, terminate this Agreement. 7. Miscellaneous. This Agreement shall be governed by and construed and enforced in accordance with the laws of the United States of America and the State of California, without regard to conflict of laws principles. Either party may assign its rights and obligations under this Agreement without obtaining prior written consent if said assignment is in connection with a merger, consolidation, reorganization or sale of substantially all of such party’s assets. A waiver by any Party of any breach or default will not constitute a waiver of any different or subsequent breach or default. If any part of this Agreement is invalid, illegal or unenforceable for any reason, the remainder shall remain in force and the invalid, illegal or unenforceable portion will be replaced with a valid provision appropriate to the Parties’ original intent. Customer’s name may be used in the ordinary course of CVI’s advertising or marketing promotion of CVI. Corporate Visions, Inc., 3875 Hopyard Rd, Ste. 275, Pleasanton, CA 94588 Confidential | Page 5 Rev. 10/16
