Vendor shall notify Fidelity and any Work Order Manager of any material claim or demand which is communicated to Vendor from any Governmental Agency, regarding Vendor's activities (provided such claim or demand is related to this Agreement) or any action pertaining to the foregoing which is commenced against Vendor by any person or Governmental Agency and shall keep Fidelity apprised of the status and/or disposition of all such claims, demands and litigation. 21.13 Force Majeure. To the extent that either Party's performance of any of its obligations pursuant to this Agreement is prevented, hindered or delayed, directly or indirectly, by a Force Majeure Event, and such non-performance could not have been prevented by reasonable precautions, then the non-performing Party shall be excused from any further performance of those obligations. The non-performing Party shall only be excused for so long as such Force Majeure Event continues and such Party continues to use its best efforts (or cause its subcontractor to use best efforts) to recommence performance whenever and to whatever extent possible without delay, including through the use of alternate sources, work around plans or other means. The Party whose performance is prevented, hindered or delayed by a Force Majeure Event shall immediately notify the other Party by telephone of the occurrence of the Force Majeure Event and describe the Force Majeure Event in reasonable detail (to be confirmed in writing within two days of the inception of such delay). If any Force Majeure Event prevents or 63 restricts Vendor's performance of any of the Services and Vendor does not within three (3) consecutive days recommence provision of those Services, Fidelity may, upon notice to Vendor, terminate this Agreement. The occurrence of a Force Majeure Event does not limit or otherwise affect Vendor's obligation to provide either normal recovery procedures or any other disaster recovery services required pursuant to Fidelity Information/Technology Control Policies or Master Agreement Exhibit D hereto. Whenever a Force Majeure Event causes Vendor to allocate limited resources between or among Vendor’s customers, Fidelity shall receive no less than second priority in respect of such allocation. If Vendor is unable to perform, in whole or in part, due to a Force Majeure Event, Fidelity shall use commercially reasonable efforts to assist Vendor to restore Vendor’s performance under this Agreement, and in that event all of Fidelity’s additional costs and expenses related to Fidelity’s efforts shall be reimbursed by Vendor. Notwithstanding the foregoing, Vendor will not be excused from performance under this provision to the extent that compliance with Vendor’s plan would reasonably be expected to avoid any such nonperformance. Vendor shall not have the right to any additional payments from Fidelity for any Services during the period when such Services were discontinued or delayed as a result of an Force Majeure Event, other than payments accrued prior to such Event and payments otherwise due for Services actually provided pursuant to the terms herein. 21.14 Dispute Resolution. (a) Work Order Managers. All disputes arising under or relating to this Agreement shall be referred to a representative of each party designated by the respective parties prior to the escalation of such dispute. If the dispute is not resolved within 3 days after such referral, the Parties shall immediately escalate the dispute pursuant to Paragraph (b) below. (b) Senior Executive. Immediately upon receipt of the notice of the dispute, the Vendor Senior Executive and a representative of Fidelity designated by Fidelity shall work to resolve the dispute. If the dispute is not resolved within 5 days after such referral, the Parties shall immediately escalate the dispute to the President of Vendor and a senior executive of Fidelity. If the dispute is not resolved within 3 days after such referral, the Parties shall immediately submit the dispute for negotiation pursuant to Paragraph (c) below. (c) Negotiation. Immediately upon receipt of the notice of the dispute, the Parties’ designated representatives shall meet (including by teleconference) for the purpose of resolving the dispute by negotiation in good faith. Upon the conclusion of the negotiation, the Parties’ designated representatives will produce a joint written recommendation, including actions to be taken with respect to any issues not agreed upon or remaining unresolved. The Parties agree to be bound by any such joint written recommendation. (d) Continuity of Services. Vendor acknowledges that the performance of its obligations pursuant to this Agreement is critical to the business and operations of Fidelity. Accordingly, in the event of a dispute between Fidelity and Vendor, Vendor shall continue to perform its obligations under this Agreement in good faith during the resolution of such dispute unless and until this Agreement is terminated in accordance with the provisions hereof. 64 (e) Right to Terminate and/or Litigate. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this Section, this Section shall not be construed to prevent either Party from (i) terminating this Agreement pursuant to Section 17 of this Agreement provided disputes have first been presented through the Dispute Resolution process described in Section 21.14 (a) and (b) up to the completion of the meeting between the President of Vendor and a senior officer of Fidelity; or (ii) instituting litigation to (A) avoid, based on a well-founded belief, the expiration of any limitations period applicable to a particular claim, (B) preserve a superior position with respect to creditors, (C) seek a temporary restraining order or other immediate injunctive relief or (D) if the Party who wishes to institute the litigation has in good faith attempted the negotiation described in Paragraph (b) above and objectively believes in good faith that it has and will continue to fail to resolve the Parties dispute or disputes. (f) Steering Committee. Fidelity and Vendor will each appoint two (2) high- level employees to a Steering Committee that will monitor the performance of the Services. Without limiting either Party’s rights or obligations under this Agreement, the Steering Committee shall monitor Vendor’s performance hereunder, and shall promptly report, but in no event later than thirty (30) days from the time the Steering Committee has knowledge, to the Vendor Client Partner and Fidelity project manager, circumstances which indicate the Vendor has failed to perform, breached a representation, warranty or covenant, or is likely to fail to perform the Services hereunder, or breach a representation, warranty or covenant, which may cause material harm or delay to Fidelity. Upon receipt of such notice, Fidelity shall fully cooperate with Vendor to remedy or prevent such failure in an effort to mitigate any damages Fidelity may suffer. The Fidelity and Vendor Steering Committee members shall schedule and attend monthly calls to review and monitor current status, concerns and any other issues that may arise under this Agreement. 21.15 Governing Law; Venue. MASTER AGREEMENT EXHIBIT E Statement Of Fidelity Domestic Fingerprinting Policy For Contingent Worker Providers/Servicing Agencies Vendor's Personnel assigned to work on Fidelity premises must be fingerprinted no later than the first day of their assignment, and such results must be in compliance with the Financial Institutions Reform Recovery and Enforcement Act (“FIRREA”) and the Fidelity Requirements in order to remain on assignment at Fidelity. If more than six (6) months have elapsed since the completion of a prior assignment, then Vendor's Personnel must be re-fingerprinted when the next assignment begins. It is Vendor's responsibility to notify the applicable Fidelity business areas when any of Vendor's Personnel are assigned to Fidelity premises and must do so on or before the first date of assignment. Vendor's Personnel assigned to work off Fidelity premises, but who have access to Fidelity's systems, data or certain intellectual property/confidential material, shall be subject to fingerprinting at the discretion of the applicable Fidelity business areas. Vendor must notify the applicable Fidelity business areas when any of Vendor's Personnel have such access, and must do so upon the date of such access. Fingerprinting shall be conducted by Fidelity or a Fidelity designee and the results shall be returned to Fidelity. Information from fingerprinting results shall not be disclosed to Vendor. In evaluating results (or background reports, as appropriate), Fidelity may require access to the portion of the Pre-Fidelity Assignment Statement which contains inquiries concerning unresolved arrests and conviction records, and Vendor shall make this limited information available to Fidelity. It is the responsibility of Vendor to warrant that each person who is subject to fingerprinting under this policy timely submit to fingerprinting at a Fidelity facility or such other facility designated by Fidelity, all in accordance with Fidelity policies (where permitted by applicable laws and regulations). Compliance with the procedures set forth above shall not relieve Vendor of its obligation to review its personnel or subcontractors' personnel applications and Pre-Fidelity Assignment Statements, or of its obligation regarding the selection, placement and supervision of Vendor's Personnel. 92  MASTER AGREEMENT EXHIBIT F Statement of Fidelity Domestic Drug Testing Policy For Contingent Worker Providers/Servicing Agencies In general, Vendor's Personnel assigned to work on Fidelity premises are required to take a drug screening test no later than the first day of their assignment and must pass in order to remain on assignment at Fidelity. However, Vendor must warrant that no IT member of Vendor's Personnel shall be assigned to Fidelity that have not successfully passed a drug test within thirty (30) days prior to their start date. If more than six (6) months have elapsed since the completion of a prior assignment, then Vendor's Personnel must be re-drug tested when the next assignment begins. It is Vendor's responsibility to notify the applicable Fidelity business areas when any of Vendor's Personnel are assigned to Fidelity premises and must do so on or before the first date of assignment. Vendor's Personnel assigned to work off Fidelity premises, but who have access to Fidelity's systems, data or certain intellectual property/confidential material, shall be subject to drug testing at the discretion of the applicable Fidelity business areas. Vendor must notify the applicable Fidelity business areas when any of Vendor's Personnel have such access and must do so upon the date of such access. Drug testing shall be conducted by Vendor at Vendor's expense. Fidelity, at its discretion, has the right to audit Vendor's drug test records and procedures pertaining to those members of Vendor's Personnel assigned to Fidelity. It is the responsibility of Vendor to warrant that it shall use a drug test laboratory that is Substance Abuse Mental Health Service Administration (“SAMHSA”) certified and shall conform to the minimum Fidelity Health Services Drug Testing Standards, a current copy of which is attached to hereto as Appendix 1. During Vendor's Personnel's assignment with Fidelity, if there is reason to believe that their work is being impaired by a substance abuse problem, then Vendor may be required to have such member of Vendor's Personnel undergo a drug screening test in order to remain on such assignment. Under certain circumstances, Vendor's Personnel may also be asked to take a random test for drugs or alcohol if they perform a job that could affect the safety of themselves or others. If Vendor's Personnel refuse to cooperate in a drug-screening test, then they may be subject to immediate removal from their assignment. Vendor must notify Vendor's Personnel that in the event they are convicted of any drug- related crime, they must immediately notify their provider, who in turn must immediately notify Fidelity, and such member of Vendor's Personnel shall no longer be eligible for such assignment. If such member of Vendor's Personnel fails to so notify their provider, corrective action may include immediate removal from their assignment. 93 Compliance with the procedures set forth above shall not relieve Vendor of its obligation to review its personnel or subcontractors' personnel applications and Pre-Fidelity Assignment Statements, or of its obligation regarding the selection, placement and supervision of Vendor's Personnel. 94 APPENDIX 1 Fidelity Health Services Drug Testing Standards .[Un[Testing must be performed at a Substance Abuse Mental Health Service Administration (SAMHSA) certified laboratory. The urine specimen must be collected via the Chain of Custody (COC) Protocol. The urine test must be tested for the following 5 substances: Amphetamines Cannabinoid Cocaine Opiates Phencyclidine (PCP) If the preliminary screening is a positive result, then a confirmation test (Gas Chromatography/Mass Spectroscopy (GC/MS)) must be performed. All positive results must be reviewed by a Medical Review Officer (MRO). For each Amount Range, the total discount shall be the incremental portion of the Amount that falls within the Amount Range times the Discount Percentage applicable to that Amount Range. (C) Other Definitions. 102 (i) The term “Off-Shore Resources” shall mean personnel resources originating from a primary workplace within India. If the resources originate from other than India (and they are not On-Shore Resources), then the Parties shall mutually agree upon the fees for the Services provided from such resources. The Parties acknowledge Off-Shore Resources may provide Services from within the United States. (ii) The term “On-Shore Resources” shall mean personnel resources originating from a primary workplace within the United States. (D) Fees. The hourly rates set forth in the table above shall be effective April 1, 2010 through December 31, 2010. Prices shall be adjusted by Vendor as provided in Article 8.6 - Increase in Fees beginning on January 1, 2011 and annually thereafter. (i) On-Shore Resources. Travel, hotel, housing, lodging, meals, transportation, visas or other work permits, entertainment expenses, personal expenses and any other expenses or costs to get Vendor Personnel to the location by which such Vendor Personnel shall perform the Services shall be included within the above rate. If Fidelity requests Vendor Personnel to travel to additional locations for special meetings, the any related travel, hotel, housing, lodging, meals, transportation, visas, or other work permits, entertainment expenses, personal expenses and any other expenses or costs are at Fidelity’s expense in accordance with Fidelity’s travel policies. Telecommunications from offsite staff to Fidelity’s locations are included. (ii) Off-Shore Resources. Off-Shore Resources shall be priced at the rates set forth in the table above regardless of whether the resource is providing Services from within India, or from within the United States if the Work Order duration of their stay is 3 months or less. If the Off-shore resource is providing Services from within the United States and the Work Order duration of their stay is longer than 3 months, the On-Shore Rates apply. Vendor agrees that these rates shall remain unchanged through December 31, 2010. (e) For all Off-Shore Resource rate scenarios, resource loading for project planning, scheduling, timelines, etc. will not exceed 9 hours per day per resource. (f) For Off-Shore Resource providing Services off-shore, travel, hotel, housing, lodging, meals, transportation, visas or other work permits, entertainment expenses, personal expenses and any other expenses or costs are included within the above hourly rate. (g) For Off-Shore Resources providing Services within the United States if the Work Order duration of their stay is 3 months or less, travel, hotel, housing, lodging, meals, transportation, visas or other work permits, entertainment expenses, personal expenses and any other expenses or costs are at Fidelity’s expense in accordance with Fidelity’s travel policies. (h) For Off-Shore Resources providing Services within the United States if the Work Order duration of their stay is longer than 3 months, Section D(i)) of this Exhibit shall apply. (E) Fidelity shall provide Vendor with access to all Fidelity Software required to perform the Services. When Vendor is performing at Fidelity’s location, Fidelity shall provide Vendor with all 103 necessary infrastructure, connectivity access, facilities, office space, office equipment and laptops/personal computer. 104 rdx) MASTER AGREEMENT EXHIBIT I Vendor’s Statement of Compliance with Fidelity’s Information/Technology Control Policies 105 MASTER AGREEMENT EXHIBIT J EU Privacy Addendum Addendum This Addendum supplements the Amended and Restated Master Service Provider Agreement between CSC Covansys and Fidelity National Information Services, Inc. dated, 2010 (the  “Agreement”). The Parties agree that the terms and sections of this Addendum and the performance hereunder applies only to Work Orders or that portion of any Work Order in which Fidelity procures Services that Vendor will perform on behalf of any United Kingdom and/or European Affiliate of Fidelity and will dictate and supersede any corresponding or conflicting terms and sections of the Agreement in connection with the procurement of Services by Fidelity that Vendor will perform on behalf of any United Kingdom and/or European Affiliate of Fidelity. Except where stated to the contrary the defined terms used in the Agreement shall have the same meaning in this Addendum. Section 5 Section 5.1(a)(iii) shall be replaced with the following wording: “(iii) authorized to work in India for the performance of the Services, authorized to work in the United States for the performance of any Services in the United States, in the United Kingdom for the performance of any Services in the United Kingdom, or in the appropriate jurisdiction for the performance of any Services in other Fidelity locations including, without limitation, Blanket L-l approvals and H-1B and other necessary visas for each of such Vendor Personnel.” Sections 5.6 (b) (iv) and (v) the requirements in this section for fingerprinting and drug testing Vendor Personnel shall not apply. Section 11 The following words shall be added to the second sentence of Section 11.1(d) after the words “The Protected Party must” “use reasonable endeavours to” The following words shall be added to Section 11.4(e) before the words “and applicable regulations”. “Directive 95/46ZEC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 24 October 1995 on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data, and all local implementing legislation.” • Section 21 Section 21.17 of the Agreement shall be replaced with the following wording: “Third Party Beneficiaries. Except as specified in this Agreement, the Parties do not intend to create any obligations or any rights, causes of action or benefits in favor of any person or entity other than Fidelity, a Fidelity Affiliate (as defined in the form of Work Order attached hereto) or Vendor. Vendor agrees that each Affiliate of Fidelity is an intended, third party beneficiary of this Agreement and is entitled to rely upon all rights, representations and warranties made by Vendor herein to the same extent as if such Affiliate were Fidelity hereunder. Subject to the foregoing, this Agreement does not create any rights under the Contracts (Rights of Third Parties) Act 1999 or other equivalent European legislation. Fidelity and Vendor may by agreement amend this Agreement without obtaining the consent of the Affiliates of Fidelity or any other third party notwithstanding that any such amendment may relate to benefits conferred on the Affiliates of Fidelity or any other third party.” • Section 21.24 The following words shall be added to a new Section 21.24 called TUPE: “21.24(a) The Parties agree that this Agreement shall not operate to transfer any employees and that the Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) Regulations 1981 (as amended from time to time) and other equivalent European legislation (“TUPE”) shall not apply to this Agreement. 21.24(b) If TUPE does apply to transfer any contract of employment or collective agreement of any employee of the Vendor (a “Transferred Employee”) to Fidelity pursuant to this Agreement, then: (i) Vendor shall forthwith make an offer of employment to each such Transferred Employee to re-employ them on the same terms and conditions as such contract of employment or collective agreement; and (ii) Fidelity may forthwith terminate the employment of such Transferred Employee; and (iii) Vendor agrees to indemnify Fidelity on an on-going basis against all costs, claims, liabilities and losses incurred by Fidelity in connection with the employment and the termination of the employment of the Transferred Employees.” 107 Data Protection The following clauses shall be incorporated into the Agreement as a new Section 22 called Data Protection. For the purposes of Article 26(2) of Directive 95/46/EC for the transfer of personal data to processors established in third countries which do not ensure an adequate level of data protection. Name of the data exporting organisation: Fidelity National Information Services, Inc. Address     Tel. Fax E- : : mail:       Other information needed to identify the organisation   (the data exporter) And Name of the data importing organisation: Covansys Address     Tel. Fax E- : : mail:       Other information needed to identify the organisation   (the data importer) 108 HAVE AGREED on the following Contractual Clauses (the Clauses) in order to adduce adequate safeguards with respect to the protection of privacy and fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals for the transfer by the data exporter to the data importer of the personal data specified in Appendix 1. Clause 1 Definitions For the purposes of the Clauses: (a) ‘personal data’, ‘special categories of data’, ‘process/processing’, ‘controller’, ‘processor’, ‘data subject’ and ‘supervisory authority’ shall have the same meaning as in Directive 95/46/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 24 October 1995 on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data (the Directive); (b) ‘the data exporter’ shall mean the controller who transfers the personal data; (c) ‘the data importer’ shall mean the processor who agrees to receive from the data exporter personal data intended for processing on his behalf after the transfer in accordance with his instructions and the terms of these Clauses and who is not subject to a third country’s system ensuring adequate protection; (d) ‘the applicable data protection law’ shall mean the legislation protecting the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons and, in particular, their right to privacy with respect to the processing of personal data applicable to a data controller in the Member State in which the data exporter is established; (e) ‘technical and organisational,security measures’ shall mean those measures aimed at protecting personal data against accidental or unlawful destruction or accidental loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure or access, in particular where the processing involves the transmission of data over a network, and against all other unlawful forms of processing. Clause 2 Details of the Transfer The details of the transfer and in particular the special categories of personal data where applicable are specified in Appendix 1 which forms an integral part of the Clauses. 109 Clause 3 Third-Party Beneficiary Clause The data subject can enforce against the data exporter this Clause, Clause 4(b) to (h), Clause 5(a) to (e), and (g), Clause 6(1) and (2), Clause 7, Clause 8(2), and Clauses 9, 10 and 11, as third-party beneficiaries. The data subject can enforce against the data importer this Clause, Clause 5(a) to (e) and (g), Clause 6(1) and (2), Clause 7, Clause 8(2), and Clauses 9, 10 and 11, in cases where the data exporter has factually disappeared or has ceased to exist in law. The Parties do not object to a data subject being represented by an association or other body if the data subject so expressly wishes and if permitted by national law. Clause 4 .Obligations of the Data Exporter The data exporter agrees and warrants: (a) that the processing, including the transfer itself, of the personal data has been and will continue to be carried out in accordance with the relevant provisions of the applicable data protection law (and, where applicable, has been notified to the relevant authorities of the Member State where the data exporter is established) and does not violate the relevant provisions of that State; (b) that he has instructed and throughout the duration of the personal data processing services shall instruct the data importer to process the personal data transferred only on the data exporter’s behalf and in accordance with the applicable data protection law and these clauses; (c) that the data importer shall provide sufficient guarantees in respect of the technical and organisational security measures specified in Appendix 2 to this contract; (d) that after assessment of the requirements of the applicable data protection law, the security measures are appropriate to protect personal data against accidental or unlawful destruction or accidental loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure or access, in particular where the processing involves the transmission of data over a network, and against all other unlawful forms of processing, and that these measures ensure a 110 level of security appropriate to the risks presented by the processing and the nature of the data to be protected having regard to the state of the art and the cost of their implementation; (e) that he will ensure compliance with the security measures; (f) that, if the transfer involves special categories of data, the data subject has been informed or will be informed before, or as soon as possible after, the transfer that his data could be transmitted to a third country not providing adequate protection; (g) that he agrees to forward the notification received from the data importer pursuant to Clause 5(b) to the data protection supervisory authority if he decides to continue the transfer or to lift his suspension; (h) to make available to the data subjects upon request a copy of the Clauses set out in this Annex, with the exception of Appendix 2 which shall be replaced by a summary description of the security measures. Clause 5 .Obligations of the Data Importer The data importer agrees and warrants: (i) to process the personal data only on behalf of the data exporter and in compliance with his instructions and the clauses; if he cannot provide such compliance for whatever reasons, he agrees to inform promptly the data exporter of his inability to comply, in which case the data exporter is entitled to suspend the transfer of data and/or terminate the contract; 0) that he has no reason to believe that the legislation applicable to him prevents him from fulfilling the instructions received from the data exporter and his obligations under the contract and that in the event of a change in this legislation which is likely to have a substantial adverse effect on the warranties and obligations provided by the Clauses, he will promptly notify the change to the data exporter as soon as he is aware, in which case the data exporter is entitled to suspend the transfer of data and/or terminate the contract; (k) that he has implemented the technical and organisational security measures specified in Appendix 2 before processing the personal data transferred; (l) that he shall promptly notify the data exporter about: m (i) any legally binding request for disclosure of the personal data by a law enforcement authority unless otherwise prohibited, such as a prohibition under criminal law to preserve the confidentiality of a law enforcement investigation; (ii) any accidental or unauthorised access; and (iii) any request received directly from the data subjects without responding to that request, unless he has been otherwise authorised to do so; (m) to deal promptly and properly with all inquiries from the data exporter relating to his processing of the personal data subject to the transfer and to abide by the advice of the supervisory authority with regard to the processing of the data transferred; (n) at the request of the data exporter to submit his data processing facilities for audit of the processing activities covered by the clauses which shall be carried out by the data exporter or an inspection body composed of independent members and in possession of the required professional qualifications bound by a duty of confidentiality, selected by the data exporter, where applicable, in agreement with the supervisory authority; (o) to make available to the data subject upon request a copy of the Clauses set out in this Annex, with the exception of Appendix 2 which shall be replaced by a summary description of the security measures in those cases where the data subject is unable to obtain a copy from the data exporter. 112 Clause 6 liability • The Parties agree that a data subject, who has suffered damage as a result of any violation of the provisions referred to in Clause 3 is entitled to receive compensation from the data exporter for the damage suffered. • If a data subject is not able to bring the action referred to in paragraph 1 arising out of a breach by the data importer of any of his obligations referred to in Clause 3 against the data exporter because the data exporter has disappeared factually or has ceased to exist in law or became insolvent, the data importer agrees that the data subject may issue a claim against the data importer as if he were the data exporter. Clause 7 Mediation and Jurisdiction 1 The data importer agrees that if the data subject invokes against him third-party beneficiary rights and/or claims compensation for damages under the clauses, the data importer will accept the decision of the data subject: (p) to refer the dispute to mediation, by an independent person or, where applicable, by the supervisory authority; (q) to refer the dispute to the courts in the Member State in which the data exporter is established. • The data importer agrees that, by agreement with the data subject, the resolution of a specific dispute can be referred to an arbitration body if the data importer is established in a country which has ratified the New York Convention on enforcement of arbitration awards. • The Parties agree that the choice made by the data subject will not prejudice his substantive or procedural rights to seek remedies in accordance with other provisions of national or international law. Clause 8 .Cooperation with Supervisory Authorities 2 The data exporter agrees to deposit a copy of this contract with the supervisory authority if it so requests or if such deposit is required under the applicable data protection law. 3 The Parties agree that the supervisory authority has the right to conduct an audit of the data importer which has the same scope and is subject to the same conditions as would apply to an audit of the data exporter under the applicable data protection law. Clause 9 .Governing Law The Clauses shall be governed by the law of the Member State in which the data exporter is established. Clause 10 .Variation of the Contract The Parties undertake not to vary or modify the terms of the Clauses. 114 Clause 11 .Obligation after the Termination of Personal Data Processing Services 4 The Parties agree that on the termination of the provision of data processing services, the data importer shall, at the choice of the data exporter, return all the personal data transferred and the copies thereof to the data exporter or shall destroy all the personal data and certify to the data exporter that he has done so, unless legislation imposed upon the data importer prevents him from returning or destroying all or part of the personal data transferred. In that case, the data importer warrants that he will guarantee the confidentiality of the personal data transferred and will not actively process the personal data transferred anymore. 5 The data importer warrants that upon request of the data exporter and/or of the supervisory authority, he will submit his data processing facilities for an audit of the measures referred to in paragraph 1. DocuSign Envelope ID: 43A80C49-0788-4EF2-BBDA-E8BB4A0C13AA MASTER SERVICES AGREEMENT BETWEEN: Worldpay, LLC and COGNIZANT WORLDWIDE LIMITED (Hereinafter referred to as “Service Partner”) Page 1 of 182 con-09385 DocuSign Envelope ID: 43A80C49-0788-4EF2-BBDA-E8BB4A0C13AA This Master Services Agreement (the “MSA” or “Agreement”) is made as of the 27th day of February, 2019 (the “Effective Date”), by and between, Cognizant Worldwide Limited, a United Kingdom limited liability company, having its registered office at 1 Kingdom Street, Paddington Central, London, United Kingdom W2 6BD (“Service Partner” or “Service Provider”), and Worldpay, LLC, a Delaware limited liability company, having a place of business at 8500 Governors Hill Drive, Symmes Township, Ohio 45241 (“Worldpay”) and replaces and supersedes that certain Master Services Agreement (the “Previous MSA” between Service Provider and Vantiv effective August 9th, 2017. In addition, Cognizant Technology Solutions U.S. Corporation (“CTS US”) shall execute this Agreement solely for the purpose of enabling and authorizing CTS US to enter into SOWs (as defined below) together with Service Partner, whereby CTS US shall provide the applicable local Services and Deliverables within the United States of America to Worldpay for Service Partner under such SOWs as provided in Section 4. WHEREAS, Worldpay desires to outsource the provision of certain business and/or information technology functions that Worldpay previously conducted itself. WHEREAS, the Service Partner is in the business of providing, among other things, the services described in this MSA; and WHEREAS, Worldpay and Service Partner (collectively, the “Parties” and each “Party”) desire to enter into this MSA to provide the terms and conditions to govern outsourcing services to be provided by Service Partner. WHEREAS, Service Partner has agreed to make available to Worldpay including its Affiliates and subsidiaries, and the Worldpay wishes to receive, the services, which shall be described in this MSA and the relevant Statement of Work (“SOW”). NOW THEREFORE, in consideration of the mutual promises and covenants contained herein, and for other good and valid consideration, the receipt and sufficiency of which is hereby acknowledged, the Parties hereby agree as follows: 1. BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVES 1.1 Performance and Management by Service Partner. Worldpay desires that certain services presently performed and managed by or for Worldpay, as each is described in this MSA and the relevant SOW, be performed and managed by Service Partner. Service Partner has carefully reviewed Worldpay’s requirements, has performed all due diligence it deems necessary, and desires to perform and manage such services for Worldpay and the Eligible Recipients. By entering into this MSA and SOWs, Service Partner represents that it has, and will have, the skills, qualification, expertise and experience necessary to perform and manage the Services described in this MSA and each SOW in an efficient, cost-effective manner and with a high degree of quality and responsiveness in conformance with then- current generally accepted United States of America industry standards and practices applicable to IT service providers in Worldpay’s industry. 1.2 Goals and Objectives. The Parties have agreed, Worldpay’s specific goals and objectives in entering into this MSA include, but are not limited to: a. Obtaining services of equal or better quality relative to current services and service levels, at a Page 2 of 182 con-09385 DocuSign Envelope ID: 43A80C49-0788-4EF2-BBDA-E8BB4A0C13AA significantly lower cost; b. Expanding the relationship with Service Partner based on flexibility and support of Worldpay’s business and/or information technology objectives; c. Obtaining world-class Service Partner support, including sufficient dedicated account management personnel to ensure the provision of superior support and service and guaranteed availability of resources both during the Term and during any period of transition at the end of the Agreement; d. Having a Service Partner that has guaranteed the availability of resources both during the Term of this MSA and any SOW and any period of Implementation and transition at the end of the applicable Term. e. The Service Partner will provide personnel and Application Development Resources to manage the services and Application Development project work as outlined in this MSA and all attached SOWs. All resources are to be flexible and responsive to the current and business requirements of Worldpay and that permits Worldpay to improve the performance of the in-scope Systems, to better manage its business operations and information technology costs, and to improve the systems management discipline to provide reliable in-scope Systems for end users and customers. f. Having a Service Partner that will provide value added information technology support that will support Worldpay in the achievement of its business objectives; g. Having a Service Partner that will provide performance standards for the services provided under this MSA that meet the requirements of Worldpay, that are aligned with Worldpay’s evolving business objectives and that are subject to continuous improvement; h. Having a Service Partner that will provide reporting of the quantity and quality of such services using various reporting requirements as stipulated in this MSA and the relevant SOWs. i. Maintaining standards of safety and soundness for the services at the same level as if the services were conducted by Worldpay itself. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary herein, the Parties acknowledge and agree that the foregoing Worldpay goals do not place any obligations on Service Provider or increase the scope of Services beyond, or otherwise modify or expand, the express obligations set forth in the applicable Statement or Work or the express terms of the remaining provisions of this Agreement. 2. DEFINITIONS 2.1 Definitions The following terms (and their derivatives) shall have the meanings ascribed to them below: “Acceptance” means written notice provided by Worldpay to Service Partner that the applicable Service, Equipment, Software, Materials or deliverable complies with the applicable Specifications or otherwise as provided under the Acceptance Procedure. “Acceptance Procedure” unless a different acceptance period is agreed upon in writing by the Parties under the applicable SOW with respect to particular Deliverables, Worldpay will have thirty (30) days from the date of completion of a Service or receipt of a Deliverable to accept or reject the same (the “Acceptance Period”). If Client fails to provide written notice of non-acceptance to Service Partner prior to the end of the Acceptance Period, then Service Partner may escalate in accordance with Schedule I. “Affiliate” means, with respect to any entity, any other entity controlling, controlled by or under common Control with such entity. Page 3 of 182 con-09385 DocuSign Envelope ID: 43A80C49-0788-4EF2-BBDA-E8BB4A0C13AA “Application Development” means the “in scope” requirements of Worldpay as set forth in the applicable SOW. This shall include (but not be limited to) delivery of the product and/ or services as defined in the project SOW and meeting all the service and quality parameters set by the Project SLA, in order to meet all the “in scope” requirements. It shall include (but not be limited to) requirement analysis, solution design, architecting, coding, testing, verifying, documenting, delivering, removing post delivery errors and omission, and implementing into production environment(s) the product that meets all the “in scope” requirements as and to the extent required under the applicable SOW. “Application Software” or “Applications” shall mean those programs and programming, including all supporting documentation and media that perform functions other than functions performed by the Systems Software (e.g., specific user-related data processing and telecommunications tasks). Applications Software shall include all such programs or programming in use as of the Effective Date of each SOW, and those as to which Service Partner received notice and/or access prior to the Effective Date of each SOW. Application Software also shall include all such programs or programming selected and/or developed by or for Worldpay on or after the Effective Date of each SOW. “Application Software Team” shall mean the team of Service Partner information technology employees assigned to Worldpay by Service Partner. “Business Day” whenever referred to in this MSA means each Monday to Friday from 8:00 a.m. to 5:30 P.M. EST excluding U.S. National Statutory Holidays (Service Provider Business Day may be expressly referred to in any SOW or other documents for computation purposes. Service Provider Business Day shall mean 9:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. IST.) . Business Day may be alternatively defined in the relevant SOW. TERM 3.1 Initial Term Unless terminated earlier in accordance with this MSA, the Term of this MSA shall commence on the Effective Date and continue until August 31, 2019 unless extended by mutual agreement of the Parties (“Initial Term”). 3.2 Extension Per Service Partner’s written request to receive notification to Worldpay, Worldpay will then give written notice to Service Partner no less than one hundred eighty (180) calendar days prior to the expiration date of the initial period of the Term of its desire to renew this MSA. Worldpay shall have the right to extend the Term for a further three (3) year period on the terms and conditions set forth in this MSA and incorporating any other changes as mutually agreed upon between the parties (“Renewal Term”). By giving written notice to Service Partner no less than one hundred eighty (180) calendar days prior to the expiration date of the first extension period of the Term, Worldpay shall have the right to extend the Term for a second three (3) year extension period on the terms and conditions set forth in this MSA and any other changes as mutually agreed upon between the parties. Unless otherwise expressly agreed in an SOW, it is anticipated that the Services will evolve and be supplemented, modified, enhanced or replaced over time to keep pace with advancements Page 12 of 182 con-09385 DocuSign Envelope ID: 43A80C49-0788-4EF2-BBDA-E8BB4A0C13AA and improvements in the methods of delivering the Services. These changes will modify the Services and will not be deemed to result in New Services unless the changed Service satisfies the definition of New Services under Section 4.5. (b) Obligation to Improve. Service Partner acknowledges that current technologies and processes employed throughout Worldpay will continue to evolve and change over time, and at a minimum, remain consistent with Worldpay’s business objectives and competitive needs. Service Partner will introduce and recommend Service Improvements to improve the provision of the Services and to ensure that it keeps pace with advancements or improvements in the marketplace consistent with industry practices over the Term of this MSA to enable Worldpay to remain competitive. (c) Monitoring Trends and Technology. Service Partner shall meet with Worldpay periodically to inform Worldpay of any new technology or technology trends and directions that Service Partner is developing or is otherwise aware of that could reasonably be expected to have an impact on Worldpay’s businesses in respect of the Services. Worldpay may elect to conduct periodic (but no more than annually) audits, at Worldpay’s discretion, to benchmark Service Partner against accepted industry practices. If any such audit reveals that the technology or processes are not at the level of “accepted industry practice,” then, at Worldpay’s request, Worldpay and Service Partner will review the results of the audit and establish and implement a plan to introduce any identified industry practices. (d) New Operational Processes. If Service Partner develops, implements, offers or uses operational process advances or changes to any Service Partner Systems used to provide functions to other Service Partner customers that are the same or substantially similar to the Services, or Service Partner develops, implements, offers or uses new or enhanced services, tools, products, or processes that it will offer to such customers (collectively, “New Systems”), subject to Section 12.1 of this MSA, Service Partner will : (i) offer Worldpay the opportunity to receive a demonstration in connection with the implementation of such New Systems; and (ii) even if Worldpay declines this opportunity, offer Worldpay the opportunity to avail itself of such New Systems when they become generally available to Service Partner's customer base to implement and receive the benefits of any New Systems. (e) Obligation to Propose. Service Partner will identify and propose the implementation of any technology or process that is likely to: (i) Improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the Services (including cost savings); (ii) Result in cost savings or revenue increases to Worldpay in areas of its business outside the Services; (iii) Enhance Worldpay's ability to conduct its business and serve its customers; or (iv) Achieve Worldpay's objectives, set out in this MSA or a SOW, faster or more efficiently than the then current strategies. (f) Annual Reviews. At least once each year or as requested by Worldpay, Service Partner will meet with Worldpay to: (i) explain how the systems Service Partner operates in connection with the provision of the Service work and are operated; (ii) explain how the Service is provided; and (iii) provide such training and documentation as Worldpay may reasonably require for Worldpay to understand and operate such Systems, and understand and provide the Services after the expiration or termination of this MSA. Within six (6) months of the Commencement Date and at agreed upon intervals thereafter, Service Partner and independent third parties engaged by Service Partner shall conduct satisfaction surveys of Worldpay management as requested by Worldpay. To the extent Service Partner engages an independent third party to perform all or any part of any satisfaction survey, such third party shall be approved in advance by Worldpay. If a Service Partner has a survey system in place, that system can be used provided that Worldpay has the right to review and comment on the survey process and questions and Service Partner agrees to make any changes reasonably requested by Worldpay. If the results of any pre-agreed satisfaction survey indicate that the level of satisfaction with Service Partner performance is less than the agreed upon target levels, Service Partner shall promptly: (i) analyze and report on the root cause of the management or user dissatisfaction; (ii) develop an action plan to address and improve the level of satisfaction; (iii) present such plan to Worldpay for its review, comment and approval and (iv) take action in accordance with the approved plan and as necessary to improve the level of satisfaction. Worldpay and Service Partner shall establish a schedule for completion of the root cause analysis and the preparation and approval of the action plan which shall be reasonable and consistent with the severity and materiality of the problem; provided that the time for completion of such tasks shall in no event exceed thirty (30) days from the date such user survey results are finalized and reported. Service Partner action plan developed hereunder shall include the specific measures to be taken by Service Partner and the dates by which each such action shall be completed. Following implementation of such action plan, Service Partner will conduct follow-up surveys with the affected Worldpay users and management to confirm that the cause of any dissatisfaction has been addressed and that the level of satisfaction has improved. If Service Partner fails to attain the agreed upon levels of satisfaction or fails to take the actions set forth in the action plan by the agreed upon dates, Worldpay shall be entitled to any remedies provided by this MSA or as agreed upon by the parties. Service Partner shall be responsible for all costs associated with conducting the customer satisfaction survey process. 5.5 Notice of Adverse Impact. However, the failure of a public telecommunications network or service will be considered to be a Force Majeure Event if such failure otherwise meets the definition of Force Majeure and Service Partner is unable notwithstanding all reasonable efforts to provide the Services using alternate or backup telecommunications facilities or providers that it has undertaken in a Service Agreement to have available for use in the event that the public telecommunications network or services are not available. Any Party so delayed in its performance will immediately notify the other by telephone or by the most timely means otherwise available (to be confirmed in writing within two (2) Business Days of the inception of such delay) and describe in reasonable detail the circumstances causing such delay. (e) If the period of non-performance exceeds fifteen days from the receipt of notice of the Force Majeure Event, and in the case of Service Partner, Service Partner has failed to implement the BCP related to the Services being terminated, the party whose ability to perform has not been so affected may give written notice to terminate this MSA. In addition, all amounts payable to Service Partner hereunder will be equitably adjusted in a manner such that Worldpay is not required to pay any amounts for Services that Worldpay is not receiving. (f) Without limiting Service Partner’s obligations under this Agreement, whenever a Force Majeure Event causes Service Partner to allocate limited resources between or among Service Partner’s customers, Worldpay will be treated at least as favorably as Service Partner’s other substantially similarly situated customers expending comparable amounts on an annual basis for the same or substantially the same or similar services and will be treated similarly with other of Service Partner’s substantially similarly situated customers . (g) Upon the occurrence of a Force Majeure Event, Service Partner will implement promptly, as appropriate, the disaster recovery and business continuity plans and provide disaster recovery and business continuity services in accordance therewith. The occurrence of a Force Majeure Event will not relieve Service Partner of its obligation to implement its disaster recovery or business continuity plan and provide disaster recovery or business continuity services. 17. DISPUTE RESOLUTION 17.1 Informal Dispute Resolution. Prior to the initiation of formal dispute resolution procedures, the Parties shall first attempt to resolve their dispute informally, as follows: The parties agree that Worldpay Offshore Contract Manager and the Service Partner Account Manager will attempt in good faith to resolve all disputes. In the event the Worldpay Offshore Program Manager and the Service Partner Account Manager are unable to resolve a dispute in an amount of time that either Party deems reasonable under the circumstances, such Party may refer the dispute for resolution to the senior managers specified in this Section 17.1 below upon written notice to the other Party. If, within five (5) business days of a notice under this Section 17 Worldpay Offshore Program Manager and the Service Partner Account Manager are unable to resolve a dispute in an amount of time that either Party deems reasonable under the circumstances, the Parties will each prepare and provide to the Service Partner Director of Services and the Worldpay Senior Vice President, International Systems, respectively, summaries of the relevant information and background of the dispute, along with any appropriate supporting documentation, for their review. The designated representatives will confer as often as they deem reasonably necessary in order to gather and furnish to the other all information with respect to the matter in issue which the parties believe to be appropriate and germane in connection with its resolution. The representatives shall discuss the problem and negotiate in good faith in an effort to resolve the dispute without the necessity of any formal proceeding. The specific format for the discussions will be left to the discretion of the designated representatives, but may include the preparation of agreed-upon statements of fact or written statements of Page 65 of 182 con-09385 DocuSign Envelope ID: 43A80C49-0788-4EF2-BBDA-E8BB4A0C13AA position. During the course of negotiations under this Section all reasonable requests made by one Party to another for non-privileged information, reasonably related to the dispute, will be honored in order that each of the parties may be fully advised of the other's position. 17.2 Arbitration. In the event that negotiations pursuant to Section 17.1 fail to resolve the controversy or claim within thirty days after the written notice, or such period as may be agreed in writing by the parties, such dispute shall be referred to arbitration in accordance with this Section 17.2; provided, however, that without limiting any rights a Party may have because of an improper termination of this MSA by the other Party, nothing contained in this MSA shall limit either Party's right to terminate this MSA pursuant to Section 18. (a) All disputes that have not been satisfactorily resolved pursuant to Section 17.1 shall be referred to arbitration before a sole arbitrator to be jointly appointed by the parties in dispute. In the event the parties are unable to agree on a sole arbitrator within thirty (30) days, or such period as may be agreed in writing by the parties, each party shall be entitled to appoint one arbitrator and a neutral arbitrator shall be chosen by the two arbitrators so selected; provided that neither party nor the neutral may appoint as an arbitrator any person that is or has ever been an officer, director, employee, assignee, representative, agent, or shareholder of that party. (b) The arbitration proceedings, whether before a single arbitrator or a panel of three (3) arbitrators, shall be carried out in accordance with the Rules of Arbitration of the International Chamber of Commerce in effect at the time any dispute is submitted to arbitration (the “ICC Rules”), and the place of arbitration shall be New York, New York, United States of America. The arbitration proceedings shall be conducted in the English language and any document not in English submitted by any party shall be accompanied by an English translation. A written transcript of the proceedings shall be made and furnished to the parties. The arbitrator or arbitration panel, as the case may be, shall determine the dispute in accordance with the laws of New York, New York without giving effect to any conflict of law rules or other rules that might render such laws inapplicable or unavailable, and shall apply this Agreement according to its terms. (c) The Parties in dispute shall equally share the costs of the fees of the arbitrator(s), but shall bear the costs of their own legal counsel engaged for the purposes of the arbitration, subject to the provisions of paragraph (h). Page 66 of 182 con-09385 DocuSign Envelope ID: 43A80C49-0788-4EF2-BBDA-E8BB4A0C13AA (d) Any award of the arbitrator or arbitral tribunal, as the case may be, pursuant to this Section shall be in writing and shall be final, conclusive, and binding upon the parties, and the parties shall be entitled (but not obliged) to enter judgment thereon in any one or more of the highest courts having jurisdiction. Any such award and any such enforcement thereof shall be subject to the provisions of the ICC Rules relative to such enforcement, but shall not be subject to any challenge, set aside, or objection to enforcement under the ICC Rules or otherwise, and neither party shall seek to resist the enforcement of any award in India or elsewhere on the basis that the award is not subject to such provisions. (e) The relevant courts of competent jurisdiction shall have the jurisdiction to entertain any proceedings for interim relief related to this Agreement whether during its term or after expiration or termination. (f) During the course of any arbitration under this Section, except for the matters under dispute, the parties shall continue to exercise their remaining rights and fulfil their remaining obligations under the Agreement. (g) Each party shall participate in good faith to expedite (to the extent practicable) the conduct of any arbitral proceedings commenced under this Section. Change Management CHANGE PROCESS Changes are defined as work activities not originally planned for as defined by the Project SOW and/or Project Work Schedule. Changes include but are not limited to: • Any scope items not listed in this SOW • Provision or development of Deliverables not included in this SOW • Changes impacting the overall delivery schedule • Any change that materially reduces the complexity of the configuration, and/or eliminates a phase of development. A formal Change Control Process will be used to identify, track, assess, and approve changes to the Project. Service Partner and Worldpay will follow this process to classify, prioritize, approve, or reject changes. Change requests need to be clearly defined, including cost and schedule implications, to allow Service Page 88 of 182 DocuSign Envelope ID: 43A80C49-0788-4EF2-BBDA-E8BB4A0C13AA Partner and Worldpay to make appropriate decisions. Service Partner will obtain prior authorization and approval of Worldpay before starting work on any changes. 9. SOW Changes Either Worldpay or Service Partner may request a change to this SOW subject to the following Project Change Control Process. The requesting Project Manager will submit all requests (a “Project Change Request” or “PCR”) for a change in writing to the other Project Manager. The PCR will describe at a reasonable level of detail the change, the rationale for the change and the impact the change may have on this SOW, both if it is accepted and if it is rejected. Service Partner Project Manager will be responsible for tracking all PCR Requests. The Worldpay Project Manager and Service Partner Project Manager will review the PCR and either: a. Authorize the change by signing the PCR; or b. Agree in writing to submit the PCR to Service Partner Project Manager for further investigation. The investigation will determine the technical merits and the effect on the price, schedule and other terms and conditions that may result from the implementation of the PCR. The Worldpay Project Manager and Service Partner Project Manager will then agree to mutually approve or reject the PCR; or c. Reject the PCR. If rejected, the PCR will be returned to the requesting individual along with the reason for rejection. This SOW is amended by a PCR if the PCR is accepted and signed unaltered by the Worldpay Project Manager and the Service Partner Project Manager and then becomes a change authorization. 10. Page 116 of 182 DocuSign Envelope ID: 43A80C49-0788-4EF2-BBDA-E8BB4A0C13AA Schedule H - Rate Adjustment Formula Worldpay’s Rates will be fixed for a 12-month period, initially through June 30, 2019. Rate adjustments will be made on July 1 annually, and will be in effect for the next 12-month period. The performance criteria and rate adjustment formula are as follows:
Description and Definitions Service Partner reserves the right to increase List Prices and Unit Prices for Service Partner Products no more than once in any consecutive twelve (12) month period, upon not less than ninety (90) days’ prior written notice, specifying such revised List Prices and Unit Prices, and based upon actual and documented increases in Service Partner’s direct labor and material costs. No annual increase for any Service Partner Product, (exclusive of any Discount) shall exceed the lesser of: (i) an amount no greater than the percentage of any increase over the preceding twelve (12) month period in the Consumer Price Index; or (ii) five percent (5%); provided, however, no such annual increase shall exceed Service Partner’s then- current published prices for the same or substantially similar products. Any Purchase Order delivered to Service Partner before the effective date of any price increase shall not be subject to such increase. Prices contained in any price quotation submitted by Service Partner to Worldpay shall remain firm for not less than ninety (90) days. “Consumer Price Index”, as of any date, means the Consumer Price Index (Current Series) for “All Urban Consumers, U.S. City Average, All Items, Not Seasonally Ad-justed,” as published by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, U.S. Department of Labor (base year 1982-84=100; if the base for the Index is so changed that 1982-84 prices are no longer taken as representing 100, an appropriate adjustment will be applied to the published indices so as to relate them to the aforesaid base in which 1982-84 prices are taken as represent-ing 100), as of the most recent calendar month for which the Index is published prior to such date. In the event the Consumer Price Index is discontinued, such other substantially similar governmental index or publication, as chosen by the Parties as a reasonable replacement, shall be substituted therefor.
Effective Date for First Adjustment July 1,2018
Adjustment Performance Requirement Service Partner must meet or exceed performance expectations as outlined in the MSA and SLA during the 12-month period ending _ (the Effective Period) to be Page 117 of 182
DocuSign Envelope ID: 43A80C49-0788-4EF2-BBDA-E8BB4A0C13AA Schedule H - Rate Adjustment Formula considered for a rate adjustment.
Adjustment Calculation Worldpay will calculate : For US, the adjustment shall be based on the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor (the “AHE”) Consumer Price Index Numbers for the most recently reported 12-month period. The information is available in the link below: http://data.bls.gov/timeseries/CES6000000008?data_tool= Xgtable For India, the adjustment shall be based on the Labor Bureau, Government of India, Consumer Price Index Numbers for Industrial Workers for the most recently reported 12-month period. The information is available in the link below: http://labourbureaunew.gov.in/LBO indexes.htm a.) Any rate adjustment will become effective for the next 12-month Effective Period.
Adjustment Cap Any rate adjustment will be capped to a maximum of 6% for any 12-month period.
Currency Fluctuations In the event that the value of the [currency of offshore country] fluctuates by (+) or (-) 10% during the Effective Period, either party shall have the right to initiate rate adjustment discussions outside of the regular annual adjustment.
Adjustment Approval Any rate adjustment must be approved by the Worldpay, Chief Sourcing Officer within 30 days of the expiration of the Effective Period.

A “business partner” relationship exists in situations where the work is integral to an area of Worldpay’s operations and the external organization’s contribution is beyond temporary staff augmentation. Responsibilities Ensuring confidentiality and protecting Worldpay’s information resources is a critical requirement that must be achieved to ensure privacy, perform fiduciary responsibilities, maintain shareholder and customer confidence and to comply with regulatory requirements. Worldpay requires that each business partner assign a primary and backup BISL. In the event that the primary BISL is unavailable, the backup BISL will take on the responsibilities of the position. The BISL will be responsible for the following: • Coordinating New Employee Access Requests • Reporting Employee Terminations or Re-assignments • Reporting Lost Security Tokens • Reporting Information Security Breaches • Performing Monthly Access Re-Certifications Please refer to Attachment J (BISL Responsibilities) below for more details regarding expected actions and timeframes. Acknowledgement of Responsibilities To ensure that the primary and backup BISL's understand and agree to perform the responsibilities defined above, signatures are obtained below and kept on file by Worldpay Information Security. In the event that a primary or backup BISL is replaced, a new form must be completed, signed and returned to Worldpay Information Security. For the purposes of this schedule, "Pilot Period" shall mean the period during which: 1) Service Partner recruits, hires and trains a sufficient number of Service Partner Personnel to establish a stable and competent workforce to perform the Service; and 2) Service Partner assumes increasingly greater responsibility for the performance of the Service in accordance with the provisions of the MSA and SOW. The Pilot Period commences on the SOW Effective Date and ends on the earlier of either: (i) the date specified in the SOW for the completion of the Pilot Period; or (ii) the date when Service Partner Personnel assume responsibility for performing one hundred percent (100%) of the volume of work constituting the Service. Any and all Service Partner Change control processes and procedures shall be in compliance with the general requirements set forth in this Schedule. I. Contractual Changes: 1. Not less than ninety (90) days prior to desired effective date of any proposed contractual Change, Service Partner shall deliver a written Change request to the appropriate Worldpay Contract Manager including, but not limited to: (i) A description of the Change being requested, together with proposed draft amended contractual language; (ii) The reason for the Change; (iii) An assessment of the impact the Change will have on Worldpay's and Service Partner's operations, costs, revenues, risks and Service performance; and (iv) Any and all other information or documentation necessary for Worldpay to adequately review the request. 2. Within thirty (30) days of Worldpay's receipt of Service Partner's Change request, the Worldpay Contract Manager will notify the appropriate Service Partner Account Manager of Worldpay's acceptance of the request, rejection of the request, or desire to enter into further discussions or good faith negotiations with Service Partner regarding the request. 3. As necessary and appropriate pursuant to Worldpay's acceptance of Service Partner's contractual Change request or the Parties successful negotiation of a contract Change, Worldpay will amend the relevant document(s) to reflect the agreed upon Change. II. Operational Changes: 1. Not less than thirty (30) days prior to the desired or required effective date of any proposed Change, or such shorter period as may be provided in the MSA or the applicable SOW, either Party may request an operational (procedural or process) Change in the performance of the Service. Any such request shall be made in writing between the Service Partner Account Manager and Worldpay Contract Manager and shall include, without limitation: (i) A description of the Change being requested; (ii) The reason for the Change; (iii) An assessment of the impact the Change will have on Worldpay's and Service Partner's operations, costs, revenues, risks and Service performance; (iv) Service Partner Personnel training/re-training requirements; and (v) An implementation and, if applicable, testing schedule for the requested Change. 2. Upon receipt of the Change request, the Party receiving the request will schedule a meeting with the Party issuing the request to review and discuss the Change request. As necessary, additional subsequent meetings between the Parties will be scheduled in order to arrive at an approval or rejection of the requested Change. 3. For any approved operational Changes, Service Partner will revise the applicable Policy and Procedures Manual to document such Changes and shall submit such updated manual to the Page 135 of 182 DocuSign Envelope ID: 43A80C49-0788-4EF2-BBDA-E8BB4A0C13AA Schedule N - Change Control Procedures Worldpay Contract Manager for review and final approval. 4. In the event an operational Change is required to be implemented on an emergency basis, the Change request, review and approval processes will be undertaken by the Parties on a verbal basis and Service Partner shall revise and Worldpay shall review the applicable Policy and Procedures Manual after implementation of such Change. III. Technical Changes: 1. Prior to implementing any Change to any Systems, Equipment or, otherwise, the technical environment or infrastructure supporting the performance of any Service, the Service Partner Account Manager is required to submit a Change request to the Worldpay Contract Manager. Such Change request must be received by Worldpay not less than thirty (30) days prior to the scheduled Change activity. Technical Change requests shall include, without limitation: (i) A description of the proposed Change; (ii) The reason for Change; (iii) An assessment of the Change impact; (iv) An implementation plan; (v) A test and validation plan; and (vi) A back-out plan. 2. Upon receipt of the Change request, the Worldpay Contract Manager will schedule a review meeting with Service Partner and the internal Worldpay stakeholders. Such meeting will result in one of three outcomes: (i) The approval of the Change request; (ii) A request for additional information and the scheduling of a subsequent Change review meeting between the Parties; or (iii) The rejection of the Change request. 3. Following implementation of an approved technical Change request, Service Partner shall submit a Change validation report corresponding to the test and validation plan documented in the Change request. Worldpay reserves the right to add, delete or modify the above frameworks for the processing of contractual, operational and technical Changes, from time to time upon notice to Service Partner, to reflect changes in Worldpay's Policies & Standards.
